column8: One of the few museums were you can really learn about local history and culture. Not too long, maybe 30-40 minutes.

column7: Worth spending at least a few minutes while in Patan Durbar Square.
column8: Part of the Durbar Square ticket. Worth spending at least a few minutes while in Patan Durbar Square. Excellent Buddhist statues. Architecturally interesting.

column7: An insight into Nepali history and culture
column8: Very interesting museum and complex. Very old and lots of stairs. Lots of temples and palaces and intricate models of Ganesh, Shiva, Buddha etc.  Well worth a visit.

column7: Mini tour of the history and culture of Nepal
column8: The small ancient town of Pathan with its various temples and palaces provides an excellent opportunity to learn about the history and culture of Nepal. There are several temples undergoing renovation. There are lso many shops selling Nepali souvenirs. Several local restaurants are also available. Plan to spend at least 4 the 5 hours in the entire Durham complex.

column7: Old is passionate museum in patan
column8: It was a amazing experience we are had here we has see here old thin it's was incredible things has here Archaeological objects we have to see in this museum

One of the ancient cities in Khatmandu that boasts Nepal's artistic heritage, touching both Buddhism and Hinduism coexistence- - - temples, Newari houses and buildings that were built since 13th century. Museum galleries that exhibits 1,500 artifacts. The place also house 'The Living Goddess Kumari'. The Kumari is believed to be an incarnation of the goddess Taleju - based on 32 criterias such as "eyelashes like a cow" and "thighs like a deer". A new Kumari is typically chosen once the previous one has started her menstruation cycle. The Kumari may only leave her palace on ceremonial occasions, her feet never touching the ground as she is carried around by family members and seeing the Kumari is considered to be 'good luck'.  Entrance fee for foreigner: NRS1000
It is a small museum but it is worth visiting. Many interesting facts about their culture and history.

What I like best about this place even though the sun was very hot , there was something about it the building is very cool inside, it felt like if there was a a/c inside, there was none though, very relaxing...rich history.
This is an interesting little museum. The info. that goes with the exhibits are well written and enlightening. The cafe is lovely.

The Patan Museum has a good collection of art and artifacts housed in a marvelous building. Patan is not as busy as Kathmandu so it is a good place to appreciate Nepalese architecture and style. It was also, very fortunate, to escape the massive damage of the earthquake of 2015 and while there was damage it was not as bad as Kathmandu. Spend time reading the explanations of art and explore the museum. Nowhere else in Nepal you will find such information readily available. Guides don’t know much about these treasures and will probably give you the wrong information. The entrance to the museum is included in the ticket for the entire complex.
A most interesting museum, with lots of features that interest. Cafe which is convenient. I particularly liked the old photographs.
This was the most interesting site we visited. The temples are beautiful although many are still being restored after the earthquake. The museum is worth a visit.

column7: Nearing the end of our visit to Nepal - perfect
column8: The ancient city of Patan is known in modern terminology as the 'City of Fine Arts'. Well, my husband and I thought this might be a bit lite. The main square is filled with Hindu temples and Buddhist monuments. The Royal Palace pretty much dominates the area in its granduer; the 16th C stone Krishna Mandira with 21 pinnacles dedicated the Lord Krishna does hold its own. But there's more: the Golden Temple and the terra cotta temple of Mahabouddha. By this time we were pretty much exhausted after three weeks of none stop travel. We gazed at all the above maybe more in a stupor than wonder. Now, by reviewing this extraordinary city, we fully appreciate what was to be our last great adventure in Nepal. Nameste.

column7: Interesting museum which is included in Durbar square ticket price
column8: Come in and learn about the restoration work to the Patan Palace, see the beautifully restored courtyards and galleries, and watch craftsmen working.

I along with my friends decided to visit some of the old and UNESCO listed heritage site of Nepal. First off we drove to Patan, an old city located a few kilometers from central Kathmandu. The Patan durbar square was fascinating. Some of the old temples and palace buildings were badly damaged by the earthquake but restoration work was in progress. Patan Museum showcased some interesting artifacts. I fully recommend a visit to this museum for people interested in oriental culture and Buddhism. There’s so much for you to discover here! Thank you!

displays were outstanding, in museum in the Royal Palace complex, with many monuments in the main square and smaller ones in the surrounding. A bustling local and traditional spices, fruits and household goods market is adjoining to the square. 'Gardens' contained tent/shelters where men were reassembling and when necessary remaking parts/trim damaged by earthquake which was very interesting. They were very skilled artisans.
I heard about this place since long but had no chance to visit but few days ago I been nice interesting who want to see historical things

column7: Interesting museum to learn the history of the area
column8: The Patan Museum is very informative with a lot of history to be learned here. The surrounding buildings, although damaged in the earthquake and still in various stages of repair, are extremely valuable in learning about the many carvings in both stone and wood that are found on them.  Inside the museum are many sculptures and art from past centuries. We did have a guide which made it easier for us to know what everything was. Enjoyed this area very much.
I visited last year and it has some very interesting artefacts.Friendly staff and easy access . Ideal visit along with Durbha Square, which is nearby.

column7: Loaded With History And A Good Collection Of Asian Art
column8: This was once the residence of the Malla kings and now houses a fine collection of religious art displayed in a series of brick and timber rooms. For the casual viewer it was a good museum and for those into Asian art it would be something special and for those not that tuned into the art scene it was interesting architecturally and historically.

Though it has not fully recovered from the earthquake it gives good insights into history and significance of area.  Some good images of pre earthquake days. The building is stunning. Wood carving beautiful, intricate. I particularly loved the fabric mural. Royal bath was amazing. Lots to see. Cafe is worth visiting for a lovely green space, excellent service and plenty of options for dining.

After getting out of the taxi from the short trip from Kathmandu, we were approached by a guide who offered his services for 500 Nepali rupees per person. It was worth paying him as we were in Patan during Dashain and he was able to give an explanation of the festival which includes the sacrifice of animals. Thankfully we only witnessed the aftermath The palace complex is fascinating with lots of opportunities for interesting photographs We were also taken to a shop selling the Healing Bowl,which is amazing,and another shop selling paintings which were beautiful Overall we spent around 3 hours and felt this was plenty of time to get a flavour of Patan

column7: Excellent displays in an outstanding example of traditional architecture
column8: Really an outstanding experience for those who want to explore the culture of the Kathmandu Valley. The restoration of the building itself rivals the excellent collection. All in all, a must!

For me the best museum of all Nepal. I have been there a few times, I enjoy taking friends and family there when they visit. An amazing museography work, wonderful pieces, great setting, and such a good care...

Whilst in Lalitpur, Patan durbar square should be on your short list. We had a great guide Ammar Raj Guni for Patan city tour, got great experience walking through one spot to another. My suggestion - do the walk to the museum especially, well maintained about Hinduism and Buddhism icons but then grab lunch at one of the roof top cafes to watch people.

This is one of the finest museums I have seen . Most of the artefacts and statues date back to the tenth century . The history and philosophy around each artefact is very well explained in English . The various poses of Buddha , the philosophy behind multiple arms of Hindu Gods , sects of Buddhism etc are interesting to read and learn ! Need good physical stamina to climb the stairs .

column7: Take your shoes off and enjoy!
column8: The museum is very interesting, in a very understated way. It is simplistic yet very very interesting. Note the details of the artifacts, they are stunning.You have to take your shoes off, as it is an earthen floor. Very unusual. Hint: Use the windows onto the courtyard for some nice pictures. Hint: Go to the gift shop and buy somethings. The people are very pleasant and the money goes back to the restoration effort. Definitely recommend.

column7: Learn more about the religions of this area, and metalworking
column8: This museum explains buddhism, hinduism and religious artefacts. When we were there certain parts were under renovation, but the exhibitions had moved around.  There is an interesting section on the different metalworking skills that are employed in making statues, masks.  It's very worthwhile to have lunch at the Patan Museum Cafe, operated by the Summit Hotel group.

column7: A Fascinating Journey into the Past
column8: I have visited Patan Durbar Square Museum on many occasions over the past four decades, and it is always an inspiring and learning experience! It is a great example of Seventeenth Century palace architecture! The building is an integrated, wholistic example of design born out of a “culture of construction,” reflecting a society’s social structure, management system, craftsmen and their skills and available materials!
very interesting and very nice to get to look at the ancient oraments! Nice and relax way to look at the history of Nepal. also really nice to wander around the area and relax with friends

I am not usually one to visit museums, however, seeing that I was visiting Patan Durbar Square without a guide, I decided to step in to find out a bit more about it all. I landed up staying a lot longer than expected, simply because it was genuinely interesting and I clearly had a lot to learn!

column7: Would have been a 5 if there hadn't been a power cut :)
column8: This is worth a visit and the tourist fee. It is a beautiful place that you can leisurely explore and learn. There is also a beautiful courtyard where you can sit and eat or drink along with a few shops. But the collection is vast and interesting and informative. Tip: find one of the window seats overlooking the square on the upper floor and hang out there for awhile!
The Patan museum is well worth a visit. It’s quite small but has some interesting artifacts and information. We really enjoyed a leisurely walk through and the entrance fee is minimal.

Patan Museum is located at Durbar Square, which is the very center of old town Patan. The building of the museum itself is a main attraction of Patan, but inside is also interesting. Although the entrance is a little bit expensive, it is worth seeing.

Lovely museum in the Royal Palace complex, some displays were outstanding. 'Gardens' contained tent/shelters where men were reassembling and when necessary remaking parts/trim damaged by earthquake which was very interesting. They were very skilled artisans.

column7: Patan Darbar and Museum...the Place to Be
column8: If you want to have a glimpse of the rich cultural heritage of Nepal, this is the place to be. More than the museum, the entire area is a living museum despite the on-going restoration of the palace and temples.  The design of the Hindu temples and the palace is unique. Not that I'm an archeologist or anthropologist but it makes you marvel at the artistry that went into it. The main materials used are red bricks and hard wood such as teakwood. The designs on the wooden columns and window frames are really intricate if not painstakingly done.  The place is really a cultural complex worthy of our time and attention.

The museum is very informative and speaks for Patan very much. The displays are well explained and there is a sitting arrangement at the top floor from where you can gaze at the full area and relax. The Newar culture is also a big part of this museum. The four faced shivalinga along with some other statues and piece of crafts are really attractive.
Interesting place to visit. Not very big but it's part of the Durbar Square. It reminds me of some scenes from Dr. Strange... Entrance fees also apply...

column7: Probably the best thing to do while in Patan
column8: The museum is located at Patan Durbar Square and is really informative. Entry to the museum is included in the price of Durbar Square ticket (1,000 rupees for foreigner). You need an hour or two to cover all of it comprehensively as all the artefacts have brief explanations next to them. What I found particularly interesting were explanations of sitting down positions and hand gestures of statues on a display as well as background information of religion. Second floor offers lovely view of Durbar Square and interior courtyard from the balcony. It also has a cafe and a gift shop.

Patan is a large series of temples and palaces. Visitors walk between the main buildings which might enclose several city blocks. There are some shops and eateries but we mostly viewed the historic sights. An example of classic architecture, this area was largely spared by the 2014 earthquake. If time is limited, and you have the choice to see Patan or Bhaktapur, I would choose the latter as more interesting (although more damaged) with more activity and museums.

column7: You need a couple of hours
column8: Entrance to the museum is via a tourist ticket purchased further down the road at a small kiosk. You then wear a badge which only marks you out as a tourist, bringing hawkers around you who are very persistent. The museum itself is on 3 levels, disabled access is not something that is readily available in this part of Kathmandu. Interesting exhibits and a lot to take in.

This is one of the most interesting museums I have ever been in. Most of the contents consists of small metal and stone sculptures. What makes it so interesting is the fact almost everyone is accompanied by an interesting and very well written description and/or story. I am attaching a photo of one showcase which exemplifies the displays and descriptions. It is small, but you can easily spend two hours if you read most of the commentary.

column7: very informative with clear descriptions and interesting sculptures
column8: I learned a lot reading about the items in this museum. I would have liked to see paintings also - which there were not many of

Patan Museum is one of the most interesting in Nepal. The collection of Buddhist and Hindu art is rich and diverse. Museum has not been damaged by earthquake and in my opinion is the main attraction in Patan.

The exhibition is very interesting. Many ancient object is displayed. The entrance fee is included in 1000 rps. If you love in history, must see! There have restaurant in the garden behind the museum.

Located in the patan darbar square houses all almost all when it comes to museum. At the entry as a tribute in the courtyard itself small wooden n clay sculpture os sparrow arre placed in front of the temple. This bird is now not seen and becoming extint. There are entry charges for the complex which is 250rs for the entire site. Due to earthquake some of the architecture have collapsed and are in restoration process

Really interesting museum dealing with artefacts found throughout Nepal. As an interested atheist it explained to me the different Buddhist deities and the meanings of assorted head, hand and body postures in statues etc as well as a historical overview of the faith generally. It is a joint venture between the governments of Austra and Nepal and as such benefits from a large injection of hard currency. It is well-labelled and laid-out and clear descritions in several languages help the visitor. Cafe also nice and this is set amidst lovely gardens with an English feel. Highly recommended, and a model for museums elsewhere.

The museum is in the Patan Square where the former residence of the King was. The royal family are no longer living there as the royal family was overthrown. Now the Residence is the museum. There are some very interesting relics inside the museum. Plus you can look out of the windows to see the other temples and the damage from the earthquake in 2015 (not that it is hard to find).

column7: 1000NPR is too much for this museum
column8: On our arrival day, we stayed nearby the museum and just walked by. The police came to ask us to pay entrance fee (1000NPR)  If you intend to visit Patan Durbar square and the museum, then you might find it interesting.  I mean the museum was interesting but not for the price we paid. If I compare it with Bhaktapur Durbar Square, I found Bhaktapur is much more interesting to see.

Best place to hangout with friends and enjoy the coffee in the coffee shop.its more interesting and fun to visit this place during morning or evening time.patan museum is the best place for the tourist in patan if they want to know more about patan. Food and drinks are also easily available here. Locals are also friendly with everyone.The best place to taste newari food in patan would be honacha! And for food and drinks I would like to recommend Dsquare cafe which is opposite the Krishna temple of patan Durbar square.

Got a guide with us for the museum who expounded on the religion and culture in Nepal as he brought us around the museum. It was part of an ancient palace. Learn a lot from the guide. You can also do the museum tour on your own. Lots of relics, exhibits and intricate architecture. Entrance fee is required.
Patan Museum is a main museum of the city. Is very interesting! Has a history of Buda, Hindu and much more. Go!

The museum is housed in a 3 tiered heritage building, which also gives one the feeling of being inside such a structure. Low ceiling height and long and narrow halls dominate the interiors. There are a large number of artefacts especially woodwork items. There is also a cafe in the adjacent courtyard. A must see attraction in Patan.

column7: Pricey but worth it for Art and Architectural Treasures
column8: I think the foreign entry price is a bit steep at NRP 1000 per person but it is actually a gorgeous museum. The descriptions of art iconography are illuminating and in depth, brought to life by true examples in sculpture or architecture. I found the step by step lost wax casting display wonderful. Currently (Jan 2017) Habitat for Humanity and a Nepali aid organization have children affected by earthquake trauma organized in the inner courtyard creating structures. Interesting! Go to the cafe after your visit, it's charming too.

This museum excels in explaining the Hindu and Buddhist religions. They combine interesting artefacts with clear explanations. The museum itself is in an excellent condition, especially given the current state of its surrounding buildings. Once you've absorbed all the information you should definitely go to the beautiful garden in the back for a coffee.  Please know that admittance to the museum is included in the (quite expensive) ticket price for visiting the square.

The Patan Museum located within the Durbar Square houses various little artefacts related to either Buddhism or Hinduism (or in some cases, both). The artwork is lovely and intricate, and the museum is well maintained.  The best part is that everything on display is properly labeled with desription. So you don't really need a guide to help you understand the meanings and significance of those artefacts.

The palace is turned into a museum and the artefacts on display are well placed. The write ups are interesting and all the exhibits hava a story to tell. The collection needs atleast an hour to run through. There is not much to see in the palace area. It is only the exhibits that are well displayed. The silver throne on display is beautiful.
This building used to house some of the royal family, and offers a chance to see what the inside looks like. Features artifacts, and photos exhibits

The museum is a quiet oasis in the middle of Patan with good explanations in English of the various Hindu and Buddhist artefacts displayed. There also is a cafe inside away from the dust and noise of the square.
A must if you visit Kathmandu as it will give you various insights about Culture and the history of the people.

A place to be and see  First of all dont forget to take a ticket outside the museum at the beggining of durbare square  We learn a lot about all the statues we see and who they are why are they in this or that position ... We also learn about how the make the statues We learn about hindouisme and bouddhisme  (Dont go to eat at the museum restaurant ...bad experience ...)

column7: A very interesting museum in a great historical place
column8: To see an historical museum inside a wonderful 17th century wooden palace is a great experience as it is but if in top of that it adds a lot of value to understand better the historical significance of the Kathmandu valley even more. Good to visit

This museum is a fascinating learning opportunity about Nepali culture and spiritual history. It's an experience not to be missed as the Royal Palace is a joy to explore, but older visitors beware - unfortunately access is by a series of steep ladders between floors only which excludes anyone with frailties or disabilities. The series of courtyards at ground level are wonderful to experience as long as the visitor is capable of stepping over high stone entrances. the Museum Cafe is a delight - a cool, shady oasis from the heat with top food and beverages. The Lonely Planet guidebook recommends taking time out here between tackling different floors of the museum and I agree. A fabulous dip into Nepal's past.

Before cars, before electricity, before indoor plumbing and running water ... masses of people in crowded narrow streets, allies, small homes, power and poverty, the smells of people, animals, street cooks, vendors selling various items .... step back in time and imagine.

column7: Worth including this if you have time
column8: This museum was really interesting if you are interested in religion, history or architecture. I admit it may not be high on the list to-do in Kathmandu, but it's interesting if you are a history or architectural buff.

Appreciate your time in Patan more if you stop at the museum first, spend an hour looking and reading the descriptions of the exhibits…then take a good long walk around the neighborhood. I find I see and learn something new every time!

Beautiful display of Hindu and Buddhist religious objects within a well-preserved building of classic Newari architecture. The building itself seems to be part of the museum’s displays. I found especially informative and interesting the Buddhist section, with displays about the spread of Buddhism outside India’s (and Nepal’s) birthplace, as well as meaning and significance of Buddhism monuments and postures. I found this place a quiet venue to understand and view together at a glance both religions’ features and contributions to the history of this Country (and not only); a contribution to mutual understanding as well, especially in the view of the fact that Buddhism has basically left India (and in Nepal too it is far behind Hinduism in terms of followers, and it is mostly alive thank to Tibetan influence).

Spent a lovely couple of hours walking around and learning. Beautifully restored but still a work in progress in some areas. Reasonably priced to enter, lovely cafe, tranquil setting away from the crowd and traffic.

After the dust and bustle of Durbar square I was very surprised to find this excellent museum in the historic centre of the town. The exhibits were clearly marked, well lit and interesting arranged. There was enough information but not too much. A tranquil and cool environment to learn more about Patan, religion and the people of Nepal. Well worth a visit

column7: One of the better museums in Nepal, if not the best
column8: I enjoyed wandering through the many rooms in the ancient and traditional building and looking at the exhibits, some of which are really interesting though more information would aid understanding of what I was looking at. It was not crowded even for a visit in the middle of the day in the spring tourist season.

column7: Interesting for art and history lovers
column8: A little history of the old palace of Patan, which is now the museum, and a wonderful collection of representations of Hindu deities with detailed explanations. Very interesting for art and culture lovers, or those interested in learning more about Hinduism and its many gods and goddesses. The complex also holds a hotel with a café and a beautiful garden, hidden behind the walls of the museum.

Nice museum that includes nepali and tibetan artifacts.  Only 400 rupees to visit and also includes a ticket to the architecture museum.  Power outages were frequent when I went so get in there when they open at 10:30. I went twice and lost power one day at 11am and the next at 12pm. It is difficult to see the exhibits and read the descriptions when it's dark.

column7: A bargain and an amazing place
column8: I love museums and I've been in a lot abroad where the exhibits are fascinating but hard to interpret as info isn't in English. At Patan Museum all of the information is in English and is very detailed. The museum focuses on the history of Hinduism and Buddhism in Patan and has lots of interesting statues. There is two parts to the museum both included in the ticket price of 400 rupees. While the main museum through the golden door is intact the second half through a neighbouring door off the main square has had some damage from the earthquake but this doesn't seem to have had much in it anyway. Definitely make a visit here.  Tip: I paid 1000 rupees for a guide as I wandered into patan square, and apart from showing me where the golden temple is he wasn't worth the price (though he was a nice person). Definitely don't get a guide for the museum as I saw one person being shown round quickly by the guide and he didn't see much of the exhibits. Do it at your own speed.

column7: Excellent Museum, one of the best
column8: Second time to visit the museum and Patan Durbar square. Some temples and statues gone, some braced, but everything continues. The museum has a beautiful collection of statuary, both metal cast and stone. The notes that accompany all the pieces are clear, concise, and informative. The architecture of the palace is very interesting, with window seats overlooking the square and streets below. On my first visit you could climb all the way up in the corner towers for a birds eye view of the square, but that was not accessible this visit. Good restaurant in the courtyard. Many things to see around and in the square but this museum is world class and worth a couple hours of your time IMHO.
Major sightseeing attraction. Be prepared for the men who want to guide you. It does help to have one who will then lead you to some shop. History is interesting.

just when i thought that there's nothing more to see in Nepal after the earthquake, my friend sunil brought me to this place and i was amazed and enchanted by it. I been wondering how it was made especially those perfectly carved art pieces. So, if your into history and arts this is a must visit place for you.

We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010.We had a nice experience visiting this museum with great collection of Hindu and Buddhist artifacts. The museum is located in old residential court of Patan Darbar, one of the royal palaces of the former Malla kings of the Kathmandu Valley. Its gilded door and window face one of the most beautiful squares in the world.There is a entrance fee for this museum.

column7: Unless you visit you will not appreciate what you are missing!
column8: Being Nepalese myself I was pleasantly surprised to see all artifacts of Patan Darbar square when I took my overseas colleague to there. Some of metal, stone and wood work are amazing and well presented.

I went inside the museum and I wasn't bothered regarding the tickets rate because I already knew how they would charge for locals, Indians and foreigners in nepal. I was with one of my foreign friends. I was amazed how they had managed the museum and I felt very nice. I got to see many new things and many new informations. there were many displays and there was even places on 2nd floor I guess where u could sit beside the window and rest. overall I liked the presentation and the display.. impressive
Is a unique place to see the art and architecture of the Malla kings of Patan. Some of the oldest photographs and paintings as well as metal arts will show the sketch of old Patan and Nepal.

column7: This is a must visit if you are a historian / history amazes you.
column8: a place with a great historical significance. Also known as Lalitpur, these were the courts / the royal complex in Nepal. The area has a lot of anciant temples, court rooms, monestries, etc. The most prominant is the Living Goddess Patan Kumari's temple. A seven year old girl living as a goddess in the temple & the stories aroung this religious belief is amazing. it was worthwhile understanding the culture, beliefs, etc of the local residents to familarise yourself with the culture. I was amazed by what I saw & herd.... cannot describe as I believe words are too less..... I'd rather say that you need to have a first hand experiance & you'd agree to what I say - "It is a once in a lifetime experiance".

Among others, a visit to the relatively newly opened Architect Museum was quite a delight and had me pleasantly amazed. The exhibits adequately showcases the unique architecture details of the Newar community that you will see across Kathmandu Valley and help you gain an understanding of all the lovely temples you will see in your visit.

This has to be one of the best you will ever see.  The Museum building, is in itself a World Heritage Treasure... and then you have the rest of the treasures that are housed within it. This is an unparalleled experience.  The gardens are tranquil, the Museum Restaurant is brilliant.  I spent an entire day here. I learned so much from my visit. The window seat settings are one of the highlights.  I will never forget it.

column7: High Quality and Interesting Alternative to Kathmandu Durbar
column8: We almost walked past this on our visit to Patan. The entry ticket (450 rupees) gets you into both the museum and the newly restored Palace. Both are fascinating and quite newly updated. The museum has a great introduction to Nepalese Hinduism and Buddhism that will appeal to complete newbies as well as those who know something about either.  We took a taxi out in the morning and walked back into town. The taxi fare is negotiable but generally 100 rupees per kilometer ($1/km) should be the upper limit. Our driver was very interested in doing a deal for the entire day which we declined.

column7: Interesting with lovely cafe/ restaurant out the back , try the orange lime bombs ! Mmm!
column8: Interesting museum that you can wander for an hour or two through, nice to step out of the busyness of the square, out the back is a restaurant /cafe in a garden that is run by the same people as the Summit hotel . Pleasant surroundings and good food . If it's warm it's a nice place to recuperate . Try their orange lime bombs, a lime flavoured very light icrcream/ mousse served in an orange that has been emptied of it's original contents, smooth cool and tangy! The museum has a fee but the restaurant you can just wander right to the back to get to for no charge.

This is a very nice museum where you can learn about Hindu and Buddhist religion and how the Nepalese people have lived with them for centuries. The structure of the building is worthwhile the visit. I was there with my nine years old daughter and she enjoyed the museum also.

column7: A peaceful place away from the busy Durbar Square
column8: We had spent a busy morning in and around Durbar square in Patan. It was particulary hectic that morning because a film crew was there filming scenes for an action movie. We opted to have an early lunch since our next stop had no lunch facilities. Good service, good food at a reasonable cost. It was a delightfully cool and peaceful environment. The buildings were interesting but, in the event, the schedule did not allow for a visit to the museum itself. But we emerged refreshed and ready to move on to our next destination. Highly recommended. The restaurant is run by the Summit Hotel.

This museum is awesome. It is packed with information about Nepal, including the details about history and religious symbols that will give you insights about the things you'll see when you visit the temples and stupas in Nepal. I visited the museum for 2 hours and after I went to several stupas and temples. I think it would be better to visit this museum first, so you could really appreciate and acknowledge the beautiful details lay at every stupa/temple.

column7: A World Class Museum in Patan
column8: I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of this recently renovated museum. Clearly a lot of thought and care was taken into making this palace a world-class museum experience. Although the place is quite small, it's a must-see for any travelers passing through Kathmandu.

This museum is a gem! Walking around Durbar Square in Patan is a fun activity in itself, but paying the extra $ to go to the museum is well worth it! It is clean and organized with so many interesting archeological and historical items that are well-placed with clear and informative wall-texts. It really gives you more background about history and religion in Nepal that will enhance your explorations of other sites around town and throughout the country.

The Patan Museum is truly a gem! Duck through the door in the middle of Dhurbar Square in Patan and enter into the museum courtyard. A second courtyard door takes you into the garden area and to the entrance stairs leading up to the exhibits. The place is exquisite, and done in typical Newari style.  Here, laid out in a very manageable format, is an incredible lesson in Buddhist and Hindu iconography, shown through a carefully chosen and exhibited selection of bronzes. One can either just enjoy a superficial view of some of the best bronzes or really learn about the attributes and symbolism of the different gods and goddesses that people the country of Nepal. Descriptions of the figures and pictured are clear and concise. The museum is relatively small, so the visitor is not overwhelmed by too many things to see.  Below in the courtyard the garden outside is a small restaurant, with tables tastefully placed under trees, near flowers or under a covered roof area. Food is fine - not overly gourmet - but an okay combination of Nepali (geared to non-spicy tastes) and western fare. Service is friendly, but can be slow, so be prepared. It helps to have a reservation during the busy lunch hours.

The PatAn Durbar square which was just a short distance from the Shaligram Hotel where I was staying is ideal for a couple hours of soaking in the atmosphere of a centuries old city. The museum is located bang in the middle of Patan Durbar square and the whole experience is a must for visitors to Kathmandu.

column7: Organized and explanatory; beautiful artifacts, and interesting photos
column8: Located in a former palace, this museum is well organized with excellent explanations, and not overwhelming. The building itself is beautifully restored, and not cluttered. The then and now photos in the clock tower were fascinating; with a good selection of representative artifacts (especially the throne) and accompanying narrative. The café in the rear gardens was refreshing. This museum is self supporting - a separate entry fee is required - but well worth it.
Such ancient history and such a part of the people of Nepal's culture these wonderful old buildings, was great to visit.

column7: one of the best in the wold
column8: Patan museum is one of the best in the world we can see how was nepal before 200 years ago and old things...really awesome and its not enough word to write about patan museum. thank you josh
A wonderful collection of art with very interesting informational panels that illuminate what you are seeing. A real bargain too!
My guide brought me here to see the Darbar Suare of Patan. I was not disappointed. It was clean with many interesting temples.

column7: Go to Patan to get away from Thamel and good shopping
column8: We didn't actually go into the museum, but the town inself is interesting. It boasts as having the most temples in any town of Nepal and after being there I agree it's got to be. The Durbar Square is much more mellow than Thamel's and you can better deals on shopping. There are also local markets where you can get some deals on Pashminas, Bhudas, Tonkas, etc. It's about 40 minutes away from Thamel and it costs 350-450 rupees by taxi to get there.

the place is small but worth a visit i went Patan Durbar Square with my friends and we were in rush but i insisted to visit the museum also and we all liked the place. entrance fee is not much for nepalese student it was just 10rs. i don't know for others. i liked patan museum more than hanuman dhoka museum of Kathmandu Durbar Square

This museum has the best collection of cast metal Hindu and Buddhist ornamentation I have seen anywhere. And it is presented in a very logical way. The other stuff is less interesting, but a visit for the artefacts alone is worthwhile.

This surprisingly interesting and well organized museum located in a royal palace houses several exhibitions. Do not miss the Patan photos collection and extremely interesting exhibition of bronze art techniques. I found the introduction to Nepali religions also very interesting Highly recommended

column7: Probably the best Museum in all Nepal
column8: Located in an old royal palace, in Patan Durbar Square houses a very unique collection of nepali art, mainly religious bronzes. The building -in a traditional nepali architecture- is a most during your visit to Patan. Also it has a very nice Cafe in the garden and a very special souvenir shop. Visit it!

This museum is the best we found in Nepal. It's in a restored palace complex. One enters by stepping through an enormous and grandly appointed golden gate. Once inside, the museum rooms are spread around two or three floors of the old palace complex. They overlook a central coutyard that had a small stupa in it. All the exhibitions were beautifully set-up and well illuminated. There were very informative placards for each exhibit, so one can learn a lot here. We spent at least two hours viewing the exhibitions. I'd also recommend the museum guidebook, which was beautifully photographed. The museum shops were also attractive, as was the very pleasant museum cafe. If you're in Patan, the museum is a must. If you're near Patan, a visit to this museum is almost a reason in itself for visiting Patan.

In Patan Museum, the attractions are both the building itself as well as the very interesting and well displayed and explained exhibits. What is also so striking is how the Buddhist and Hinduist traditions have lived (and continue to live) side-by-side often intermingling with each other. One can only wish for such harmony between cultures and religions elsewhere.

Even after the earthquake, still the best places inside the valley. Full of nepali culture, locals minding their own business, everyone seems happy. The staffs of museum are very friendly, the shops around the durbar add to the culture. Very peaceful but bursting with life. Great solo experience , as well as for couples and family; all from personal experience. A must visit.

After getting help with directions from our hotel staff, we traveled by public transportation out to Patan Durbar Square. The bus ride itself was an interesting experience in itself and many locals were able to assist us during the trip. Patan is another World Heritage site that is a must see if visiting Kathmandu. You can see by the architecture and building layout that the city was very wealthy during it's day. Even now the buildings have been restored to their original elegance. Of particular note is the Ancient Royal Palace that includes meticulous carvings and reflects the architecture of the ancient Newar peoples. There are a variety of temples to visit and explore throughout Patan while wandering along the side streets.

This fascinating historical and religious site is best toured with a guide to get full information on what you’re seeing. The temples, buildings, and courtyards are beautiful and interesting. Lots of good shopping as well.

Patan's Durbar Sq did not suffer as much damage as Kathmandu in 2015 earthquake and as a result, despite smaller, has more intact buildings. 1000R ticket includes admission to museum. A taxi from Thamel will run between 500 - 700Rs. Not as many tour guides as KTM but not as necessary due to information handout and interesting museum, which is worth it alone. Although small, the museum breaks down identifying diety poses and meanings & contains beautiful artifacts.

A must visit when visiting Kathmandu. It is easy to come from Kathmandu which we did a day trip combined with Bhaktapur Durbar Square for a morning half day trip for about 6 hours (including 1 hour lunch) with a negotiated price arranged with taxi driver through our hotel - Bodhi Boutique Hotel at Thamel district. The taxi fare for the entire trip was NPR 2,500 for the entire 6 hours. After double checked with hotel staff for the rough guide of taxi fare, single trip from Thamel to Baktapur cost NPR 1,000 (45 mins journey) and single trip from Baktapur to Patan is NPR500-600 (35 mins journey) plus single trip from Patan to Kathmandu is NPR500 (20 mins journey). Hence, the additional NPR400-500 is for the waiting time, depending on negotiation with driver. Unlike Baktapur Durbar Square, there are many entry points to Patan Durbar Square since the square is not fully fenced. There will be many security personnels with uniforms walking around to identify foreign tourists and bring them to ticketing office to pay for the tickets that cost NPR 1,000 per person per entry. We thought it was a scam initially, but soon we discovered that it is how it works when visiting to Patan Durbar Square. Locals are allowed to enter the square free of charge. The entrance fee is inclusive of the museum right in front of the square with good introduction and information about Hinduism history and culture in Patan (Latlipur). There are some interesting collections of the Hindu and Buddhist Gods statues, such as Shiva, Krishna, etc. The Square was a typical Newar Achitecture with beautiful wooden carvings, Hindu idols, etc. One of the highlights is the ancient royal palace where Malla Kings of Latlipur resided. We also saw the local devotees carried out the prayer rituals which was an interesting cultural sights. It is one of the three Durbar Squares (including Kathmandu & Baktapur) in the Kathmandu Valleys which is the UNESCO World Heritage Site that is under the threat of earthquake especially the most destructive volcanic eruption in 2015. Restoration effort is ongoing to preserve these valuable historical and cultural site.

we went to the Nepal last April 2019 for Everest base camp trek and I had a 2 day extra so we went to see the historical patan durbar square which is located in the center of Lalitpur district. A traditional Newari city patan has a unique traditions as well as identity. As we were with my tour guide we were lucky to know most of the things that patan durbar square has. The Main durbar square is so unique with its wooden architecture as you see there so much wood work everywhere. The main house used to be the living place of the Malla Kings family in the past and there are many courtyard and Chowk inside. All of this Chowk has it’s own significance. Siddhi Narsingh Malla was the king who built many temples and part of durbar in 17th Century B.C. Krishna Temple was the another attraction over that squre which is built by the stone only in sikhara style which took 25 years to build by King Siddhi Narsingh Malla. The place also popular for buddhisim as there are a lot of sakya family and it has a lot of Boudha Bihar. Hiranya Barna Mahavihar is one of the popular. Overall our experience to patan was great with my guide Sabin as I learned many things. I tried the Newari food which was awesome but quite spicy. You must visit patan if you are coming to Nepal. Highly Recommended.

The place was built during 11th Century. Lovely place with beautiful architectural construction. Lots of beautiful photo opportunities. It can get very crowded so make sure to take pix before starting a narrative tour.

column7: Get your entrance ticket extended at the time of purchase if you plan to visit the next day. Passport required.
column8: Get your entrance ticket extended at the time of purchase if you plan to visit the next day. Passport required. The square is interesting enough to visit more than once especially if you're staying nearby. The Patan Durbar Square is in better shape than the one in Kathmandu in September 2019.

In my opinion a must see during a trip to Nepal! Even better than Kathmandu's Durbar Square and even if the earthquake damaged some of the shrines and buildings the magic of this place is still intact. Very interesting also the visit to the inner courtyards and small museums (included in the entrance fee) hosted in the buildings on the right side of the square. Good info and detailed leaflet about other attractions located in Patan, not far from Durbar.

I was on a solo trip to Nepal earlier this year in January. Basically I wanted to explore and run some rivers on my Kayak. But during my visit there, I was told to visit this place by a friend. Just how wonderful Patan Durbar square is for a traveller to experience some of the tradition & heritage structures of Nepal. the oldest of the three cities in the Kathmandu valley. The square is made up of 136 courtyards and 55 temples. It was destroyed by earthquake few years back and some places are still under maintenance & rebuilding stage. However all the structures are amazing, heritage Hindu kingdom. There are a number of historic temples & they include some extraordinary erotic carvings on one of the temples in a traditional South Asian style. The Patan Museum is also simply amazing. Also the Mahabuddha temple is an easy walk from here. You might get lucky to witness some religious processions and performances in the square as well. Supposedly these are fairly regular. So if you want to time your visit accordingly may be you can contact the tourist office before visiting. As I was alone and also less crowd during the morning visit, I got absorbed and felt so spiritual. There is so much ancient culture in this thriving and beautiful place.  This is a must visit place for all travellers to Nepal. I ticked off another beautiful destination on my unknown places bucket list :)  I bow down to this land and the people of this land who have built & preserved this gem of a place for the world to experience.
For foreigners, this is a pricey place to visit. The "entrance fee" is pretty high compared to some other places. Bhaktapur Durbar Square is a nicer place to visit in my opinion!

column7: excellent walking adventure around Lalitpur and Patan Durbar Square
column8: As most Durbar squares in Nepal, we paid 1000 rupees. Most of the buildings are still under reconstruction but you can still admire the beauty of the Newari architecture.  We practically spent the whole day from mid morning until around six pm walking around the square and the side alleys of Lalitpur.  Try to avoid the evening as it is chaotic with all the cars, motorbikes and people walking around unless that is what you’re looking for.  The ticket gives you access to the museum which is a great way to learn about Buddhism and Hinduism through the sculptures, there is also a cafe inside. This was once part of the royal palace.  Avoid the museum shop which is extremely expensive and costs more than three times the prices of the shops around the town.  The square itself is very impressive with beautiful ancient buildings, a lot of buildings are still inaccessible due to the post earthquake reconstruction but the photo opportunities are constant.  The Newari architecture is phenomenal and the intricacy and detail of the arts and crafts is definitely something that is lacking within first world countries. The buildings in the adjacent streets and squares are stunning.  With incredible Stupas and shrines popping up in every corner and back street between houses and shops that have been there for centuries with most intact.  We encountered numerous Newari women working incessantly in the rebuilding of the area, carrying very heavy brick bags over their heads.  The streets are perfect for a shopping day with very impressive wood, metal and clay works available along with Mandala and Thaka art. Costing upwards of 1500 rupees for a student painting.  Barter for prices and compare one shop to another as some are double the price of others.  The roads are a bit crazy with motorcycles and cars passing all the time in tiny streets. But we felt very safe walking around and no one bothered us at all.  All in all an excellent walking adventure around Lalitpur and Patan Durbar Square.
Many beautiful temples and interesting to go into Patan Museum as well. Would love to see what it looks like once all the construction work is done

It was a pity that Patan Durbar Square was mostly under repairs. It was small but one can only imagine the beauty and grandeur before the earthquake. We spent some time in the museum appreciating the centuries old religious statues. An unexpected plus point was buying a beautiful Thangka painted by a master from the Tibeyan Thangka Buddhist Painting School and managed bargained it down to the price we had in mind. Spent an hour there learning how to differentiate between a student, professional and master painted Thanka, which was really educational and makes you appreciate the time and detailed work that goes into one. Now we have a beautiful momento to remind us of Nepal.

column7: UNESCO World Heritage Site in central Kathmandu
column8: Patan Durbar Square is an amazing treasure trove of Buddhist and Hindu temples, statues, and museums. It was substantially damaged in the 2015 earthquake, but repairs are underway. Absolutely beautiful, unique sights everywhere. The area can be toured in about 30 minutes, but if you have more time, there are several museums to check out. Lots of places to sit and have a coffee, shop, and enjoy the ambiance as well. It was an easy walk from my hotel, a wonderful quick sightseeing trip on last day of my business trip to Kathmandu.

column7: A rich of culture place need to be seen once being in Nepal
column8: I am not lucky but lucky to be able to visit this place after the terrified earthquake in 2015. A lot of renovation, construction works are going on. Though, I still found the squares being so charming. If time allow, I wish I could spend a whole day there just to look at the sparkling architectures, or listening to the whistling of the pigeons mixing with the noises from crows and the ring from the bells and the murmur of prayers arounds the temples. It is so unique and peaceful.
Nothing special really, just an arched entrance into Patan. There is a tourist collection booth there and it is a lovely and interesting walk to through the bahals and small roads.

column7: A good place to start exploring Patan
column8: We followed a Lonely Planet walking tour that started here and it was really interesting. This is far from the main tourist centre so you will be around mostly Nepali people. The temples in Patan are older and different from those in Kathmandu proper so it is worth checking out. In fact, I tend to like Patan more than Kathmandu and this walking tour was one of the reasons why.
It's just something that you might pass on your way. There is certainly no reason to make any effort to see it. It's not ancient or anything.

Its a strange experience to visit the palace. it seems like abandoned places, but still with some staff. Its dirty, dusty and the area where the shooting took place, strangely kept. As a backyard with no history.

I lived in Kathmandu for several years and tried many yoga teachers and studios as a beginner. For some reason I did not fully understand the instructions coming from the teachers and I did not experience any joy in the practice of yoga. When I started to work with Kanchan finally I started to learn and understand. He truly looks at the person in front of them and works to understand what they need in order to learn. Practicing yoga with him is a transforming experience. Since I left Kathmandu I have not managed to find so good a teacher. If you are in Kathmandu and you have the opportunity to work with him I really recommend it.

I went to Kanchan yoga studio first time two years ago, and was impressed with quality of lessons, how he teachs, informs you about importansy of connection between body, breath and mind, which you can reach through yoga! Now I came to Kathmandu again (he has also studio in Thamel - Charak yoga) and I’m so happy to practice with him again! He is the best teacher you can find in the whole universe!:))

We had a couple of yoga and meditation sessions in Kathmandú as part of our volunteering program and Kanchan was a great teacher, very interesting to hear about the core importance of yoga and the story behind it. The class was very relaxing and easy to follow. Recommended!

Namaste 🙏🏻  We had the great pleasure to meet with Kanchan in Kathmandou and to experience his talent for Yoga & Meditation 🧘‍♂️. On top of being an amazing human filled with kindness and happiness, Kanchan is very knowledgeable on the ancient techniques and is very good in transmitting the message. His track record, hard work and connection to the universe make him a wonderful encounter. We went back home with some good messages that we will put into practice. We HIGHLY recommend him.  Thanks a lot Kanchan, we hope to see you soon!  Driss & Henri.

I really liked the yoga lessons and meditation with Kanchan.He could manage lessons according to the wish of the participants.Nice atmosphere,unforgatable experience.hope to come back for deeper understanding of yoga.

I did a yoga retreat with Kansan and Sanyasi. It's was amazing. You were in a beautiful and peaceful place with a niice hiew on Katmandou. It was really intersting because it was complete with yoga asana, meditation and a lot of talk. These 2 teachers are really knowladgable and yoga is in there blood which i felt . Great teacher, great experience. I recommand this yoga school.

column7: Good place to be humble and learn
column8: Classes are great with the perfect blend of different yoga styles, even for the beginners. Our teacher Kanchan sir is exceptionally encouraging and comforting. He brings out the strength in everyone. The best thing is everyone feels at peace by the end of class and that is what a yoga class should do. It really is true spiritual practice.

I have done two yoga retreats and regular classes instructed by Kanchan and it has been purely amazing. Kanchan’s way of teaching is flexible, holistic and he has the ability to modify the classes for each participant’s level, from the beginners to the more advanced ones. The classes were gentle but also challenging enough. Kanchan’s holistic life style as a yogi showed up in his multidimensional expertise and deep and healing spirit that he could create into the classroom. Also his thorough knowledge on yoga philosophy brought depth to the experience. I felt like a different person after the 3-days retreat in a monastery - more open and calm, both physically and spiritually.  If you travel to Nepal and are looking for a great yoga experience, I definitively recommend to try Kanchan’s classes!

column7: A unique yogi from the Himalaya!!!
column8: Growing up in a yogic family in a small village in the Himalaya, Kanchan really internalized yoga in his blood. He provides authentic teachings of hatha and Ashtanga yoga and know all secret corners and treks in the Nepali Himalaya. Apart from this, he is a brilliant and exhilarating character! Very visionary and creative! We did a lot of yoga practice together. I would say he is a unique yoga teacher!

It has been a great pleasure to get to experience yoga with Kanchan! He is a person who has really special sensitivity to see individuals energy, and modify all classes observing participants bodytypes, level of energy and group dynamics. His strong knowledge about yoga and yogic lifestyle , bright and sensitive personality make classes and retreats more deep, more opening that I have ever experienced before.  Warmly recommend for those who want to practice yoga!

Kanchan is an inspiring yoga teacher and yogi. Many people can teach a great yoga class, and he is definitely one of them - but what makes Kanchan unique is his personal connections to and understanding of each of his students as individuals. As a “real” yogi, I think that’s something that’s very important to him as opposed to simply teaching yoga – and that’s what makes him special. He made my time in Kathmandu fulfilling in a way it wouldn’t have otherwise been, and I wish I could join one of his retreats and practice with him regularly! Anyone who is lucky enough to be in Kathmandu or Patan should definitely take his classes!

I had the chance to meet Kanchan during a Trek & Yoga in Nepal. Yoga is a philosophy of life for him. And he really likes to give us all the benefits of good practice. I had a good connection with his teaching of yoga and meditation, which brought me inner peace. I recommend the Charak Yoga Studio, ideally located in Thamel !! Namaste 🙏🏻 Nb : The most important thing in your life is your breath😉

After a severe heart attack Kachen helped me restore my health and well being. He worked one to one with me in a sensitive and caring way. I got stronger week by week with his help. His deep knowledge and experience comming from a long tradition is really very special.

column7: Private yoga lessons for my unstretchy self.
column8: I spent about 3 weeks in Nepal where I had the absolute pleasure of having one to one classes with Kanchan. I’ve never really done any yoga before and learnt a great deal from him. He was such a darling to talk to and felt so comfortable with him. It was my first big trip on my own so was grateful for his friendship and teachings. I hope to come back some day! Just a few tips on the studio. The traffic is shocking and can seem dangerous! So give the teachers some time as it’s very easy to get caught up in it and they can possibly be late. But they’re SO worth it. Thank you so much Kanchan ☯️
I learned yoga with Kanchan, he is a great and spiritual teacher he can share easily his experience . Thank you very much for your private classes . Namaste

column7: Most incredible Yoga teacher and experience
column8: Kanchan is the most incredible yoga teacher my wife and I experienced. We’ve seen a lot and he is by far the most dynamic and personalized yoga teacher we’ve met. We were blessed to find him.

In Durbar Square. Aside from staying in a beautiful and ancient architectural building, the staff are the warmest and most accommodating. The Inn is very clean and the rooms are so unique. Despite the Winter cold, the owner insured that the room remained warm by placing an electric heater in it along with an electric blanket. I love the Inn Patan and will hopefully return again some day.

column7: Interesting place to stay while in Patan. Location. Breakfast was only OK.
column8: We decided to book a stay at The Inn Patan since we were interested in having a more local experience and we wanted a hotel close to Durbar Square in Patan. Not up to western standards but clean, comfortable rooms. Breakfast was only OK - actually western food staples like eggs, toast, orange juice was served. Major problems with outlets to charge our devices.

Can recommend Shakya House Lalitpur Nepal for business or pleasure 🌺 Airport pickup, room service, friendly and warm staff and owner, good wifi connection. Nice patio and nooks and crannies. Sweet puppy too, a golden named Romeo that I enjoyed 😅

column7: Friendly, professional and clean as well as cosy
column8: I stayed at Shakya House on the recommendation of colleagues who always stay here when in Kathmandu. The owner Saajan and his family are friendly and always ready to help. The place is very clean and tidy and my room has a lovely terrace. The breakfast is simple but all you need (unless you want Nepali breakfast, but then, I never asked for that so maybe they can fix that too!). I also had to change money at quite short notice twice and they were able to help me out. I also recommend staying in Patan area where the guesthouse is (rather than the main Kathmandu tourist area Thamel) as its quieter, cleaner, much less touristy and hectic and also has a beautiful and interesting historical square - Patan Durbar square.

Very clean and comfortable - a valuable retreat space amidst the busyness of Kathmandu. If you need something, the Shakya House family will always help you as much as they can. 5 star experience as far as meeting my needs as a resident is concerned. Very highly recommended.

I did a class of Vinyasa in September (Wednesday 12th at 7.30) with Annie. She asked if we accept hands-on help, which I do because I appreciate. But as she asked us to do Urdhva-dhanurasana (wheel pose), she came to me telling me I wasn't doing it properly. She pushed me into going further into it until it became way to much for me, without giving me any support or hands-on help. She also made negative comment on my posture instead of helping me and making me feel safe. I have now been suffering from a bad kidney pain for two weeks, which my acupuncture doctor says is really bad and comparable to a punch in the kidneys. I strongly advise beginners not to go to Annie's class, which can be dangerous to people who don't have years of practice of Vinyasa. Very disappointed that such a "famous" studio doesn't tell which class is for beginners and which is for people who come for sweat and pain...
Patan Pranamaya Studio is my local favorite for yoga! I just hope they would have more daily options. Instead of just one morning and one afternoon session, there could be more options.

column7: great spot for finding the right yoga class/retreat
column8: I booked a three day yoga course wih the pranamaya Team in the Neydo monastery in the valley of kathmandu. It was a really great experience and I enjoyed the easy communication, the extraordinary people I met there and of course the special and energetic place the retreat was as much as the yoga style which I never heard about before (universal yoga).

I lived in Kathmandu in 2013 and discovered the great locations of Pranamaya Yoga. In addition I enjoyed their retreats as well. Whenever I go back to Kathmandu for holidays (at least once a year) I keep going back to Pranamaya.

I was on a work assignment in Patan (Lalitpur) for several weeks and attended several yoga classes at the local Pranayama Yoga branch. I tested 3 yoga styles I had never tried before, and I really loved the way they where taught. Interesting and friendly instructors, easy-to-drop-in-classes, clean mats and a lovely lemony scent - what more can one ask for ;-)

column7: Retreat at a Monastery - great experience
column8: I joined a 3 days retreat at a tibetan monastery with pranamaya Studio - and I just loved it! Anna was a great teacher, you could feel the depth of her own experiences in all of the teachings! We got a lot of interesting informations about tibetan buddishm and excellent yoga classes - I hope to be able to join again!

column7: Good classes but too many last minute cancelations
column8: Out of three Pranamaya yoga instructors I've practiced with, two were really great and led classes that were both relaxing and strengthening. The third instructor was extremely rude and unsupportive of a newcomer to the class who appeared to not have much experience in yoga - this was very surprising and off-putting and I will make sure not to take her classes again. The main issue with the Patan studio (I haven't used their other two locations) is that they cancel classes frequently, and often at the last minute. This month they have canceled eight sessions so far. It's very unprofessional and I don't think I will be renewing my membership.

For yoga lovers, Pranamaya Yoga offers yoga classes at different venues throughout Kathmandu. Their premises are clean with plenty of props which are part of modern yoga experience. The instructors are professionals and helpful; some are better than others. Popular venues become very crowded, like the one in Thamel. The policy seems to be to accommodate everyone inspire of the cramped conditions. I have often ended up with my nose very close to armpits or crotches! The yoga hall in the Thamel centre is long and narrow-ish. The instructor and practitioners are all on the same level. Often, trying to observe what the instructor is doing becomes difficult. I have ended with more than a few cricks in my neck, undoing the benefits of yoga practice. They seem to have raised their prices as well. I hope I can keep up my yoga lessons.

We were looking for some good yoga after trekking and we found it! We are yoga-spoiled coming from San Francisco, but we loved Pranamaya. We took an Astanga 2-3 class at the Patan studio and it was a fantastic class. We also did a 3-day Hatha retreat with Rupesh and Sam, and it was an incredible experience at the absolutely stunning Neydo Monastery outside Kathmandu. Great teachers, great group, and wonderful setting.  I highly recommend Pranamaya to any yogis in Kathmandu!!

column7: 3 day retreat to Neydo was amazing!
column8: The three day retreat to Nedyo monastery to practice yoga, meditation and learn about Buddhism with Sam and Rupesh was the highlight of my month long trip to Nepal and India. The setting, the food and the discussion with the people that joined us, was truly food for the soul. I am a beginner at yoga, and was concerned about my lack of skills, but did not have to worry about this at all. I was put at ease, gently touched to correct the posture and constantly reminded to listen to how my body and mind felt. I will forever remember breathing in and breathing out to the sounds of the monks chanting. The retreat was incredibly well organized. Thank you Sam and Rupesh!

column7: Perfect way to end a Nepal visit...
column8: Searching 'yoga in Kathmandu', I found this Yoga Studio and signed up for one of the 3 day yoga retreats. Thought it would be a perfect way to get ready for long plane fights back to Montana.  I was so impressed and happy with the whole event! They provide transport into the walls of the Neydo Monastery compound in Pharping, The wonderful room provided in a very, very nice accodation is right next to the temple and one can hear the music and prayers from your room balcony. The classes were amazing, full of information and sharing of knowledge from our very special instructor, Nicky...it gave me the one thing I had been looking for all over Nepal to take home with me...a real and lasting gift to myself...inspiration for one's yoga practice that money cannot buy!  I will recommend this to anyone looking for a wonderful experience. When I return to Nepal for the 3rd time, this will be at the top of my list.

column7: Very good classes offering different yoga styles
column8: I have been visiting Pranamaya Yoga Studio in Patan for 2 months. I find it very nice that the studio offers different kinds of classes with different teachers, so you can choose your own style and pace and get a better understanding of yoga. I gained some very rewarding experience from a number of teachers and a new insight into yoga thanks to my visits.

it vas very atractive and authentic spiritual and cultiral experience.perfect place, nice view around, during the days with good visibility you can see Himalays.perfect air and local villages , lot of atractions around.

If you are looking for a good place to start or continue your Yoga experience while in Nepal, go here. I started my Yoga experience with Pranamaya and I've continued practising it now for one and a half years with them - somehow got addicted.  The studio is located in Moksh complex in Lalitpur, very conveniently in between all the restaurants and coffee shops that make Patan so attractive. The studio is very clean and professionally managed. Most techers and students are westerners, which is a little drawback. If you want to get in touch with the Expat community in Nepal - that's probably the best starting point.  They offer drop-in classes by many different teachers which makes it very easy to try out the different styles of yoga. It's no problem for people without experience to join the classes, just come and grab a mat - that's finally what made me tryout yoga. Uncomplicated!

column7: Serene environment condusive to business or casual meet-ups
column8: Unfortunately, the setting and previous pleasant experience at this cafe was countered this time by serving staff demonstrably in a hurry (seemingly understaffed), a salad with nondescript watery dressing, coffee on the weak side, an extremely loud patron across from us and other minor irritants.

My hotel was very nearby, so I came here twice for breakfast since the first experience was very positive. I tried two of their omelettes...I'd recommend the Dhoikama omelette over the Farmer's personally. Nice dark bread toast, too, and I'm usually not much of a bread person. There is nice outdoor seating and a good selection of magazines and newspapers to read. Patan Bookstore is also in the same building and also worth checking out.

column7: Good experience but not a very special one
column8: this is a typical nepali Café for tourists. The atmosphere is quite nice, very relaxing and calm. The personnal is nice and gentle and will serve you with efficiency and professionalism. Prices are honest for such a place. Personaly i prefer less classy places where i can meet some nepali people and not only tourists.

Good is tasty & very reasonably priced, we will visit again.very wide range of dishes, tasty food, friendly environment with seating inside and outside. Good place to eat if you're in the Patan area i really appreciate.

column7: One of my all-time favorites in town!
column8: I've been a big fan of this joint for years. It's in the top-tier of eateries in Kathmandu, at least in terms of its menu range and prices. The quiet, hustle-free setting, lovely garden and trees just besides the eating tables, are a fresh change from most places in town. Have always enjoyed their food and cocktails, which, for a change, are quite better in terms of mixture and preparation, in comparison to most other bars in town. I've tried almost all their dishes, and I do appreciate the effort the kitchen and restaurant staff make. I'm proud to call Dhokaima one of the few places that I and my wife simply can just drop into whenever we're around Patan.

Wow really hard to put into words our experience here. As a chef and a person with a knowledge of the food industry I can honestly say that this was one of the worst dining experiences of my life.  I'll try be brief as I know how essay reviews are to read but seriously what I endured deserve one.  Yer well lovely looking place, nice sounding menu on the mid price range with some really tasty sounding options. Great. Lovely courtyard, perfect.  So my partner ordered the lasagna and I the Chinese inspired mushroom and pak choy. We had a great feeling as a place with great reviews and such a well presented location deserves high expectations. The lasagna came out only slightly warm and the middle still cold and as you can see from the photo not a lot of love to gratinate the cheese on top, a basic for any lasagna. We asked for it to me warmed and knowing a microwave would be the answer and sure enough after 2mins we received it warm of course but as expected the microwaved cheese leaking oil!!! Tasty!  My dish was actually very tasty exept for the 3rd bite including a rock. Okay, this for me is seriously unexectable, it is in no way a mistake, it tell me that the kitchen doesn't wash their pak choy!! This can pass for a street food dish but not a restaurant of this standard.  I called the waiter over, he took the dish away and then brought me the menu.... I of course asked for the manager. To be honest she handled the situation fairly well, after I suggested her to offer me a new complementary dish. The BLT that I ordered was tasty but really nothing special. Besides the fact that after the first bite she came running over to ask if "I loved the new dish." Seeing the waiters and the manager in the reflection standing around the cash register and looking over in my direction and laughing didn't help the already broken trust.  Wouldn't return and if I were you don't bother. Stick to a street side samosa.

Attentive service and lovely set up but food was mediocre, far from what was expected by the look of the place. I ordered a lasagna (i felt like a change from dhal bhat!) and it came cold... I asked them to warm it and obviously they didn't use an oven because the cheese was chewy, not crispy at all. I thought it was kind of my fault for ordering a ladagna in Kathmandu... But damn, for those prices they could put a little love and finish the job, because the flavour wasn't bad! The service was good though. I think the kitchen should raise the standards.

Dear readers, its a Cafe adjacent to Patan Dhoka(Gate) which looks quiet decent. We went there with some friends and had some hot alcoholic drink and nutrela item and enjoyed our sitting. I felt like we are charged bit more but the ambience, location are perfect and just as expected, the target group is expats and foreigners! Good place to be for coffee and light food..

column7: Perfect garden atmospher and excellent food!
column8: I read about Dhokaima Café on TA and it certainly appealed (and was less than a kilometre away from our hotel), so off we set, savouring the cool evening air and the endless new sights and sounds of Patan. Our food was delicious and the service excellent – fried dal and vegetable momos (with 3 spicy sauces) and margaritas (you would think we were in Mexico the times this featured in our beverage choices!). Would not hesitate to return - outstanding meal and experience.

Easy to find at the north gate. Had a lunch and a dinner there while on a short stay in Patan. Lunch was very nice- warm, sunny day sitting outside in the courtyard garden. Lots of sun or shade options. Wifi and newspapers available. Pleasant staff, pretty quick service. Extensive menu. Opted for a sandwich and cappuccino after 5 weeks of trekking type food- very good! Almost the best coffee to date for this trip- I'd go back for that alone. Chocolate cake was watery- ? Frozen/defrosted but still hit the spot. Free filtered water. Dinner was fine- different atmosphere. It had been raining and was quite cool so we sat inside- not as nice as the day time experience. Can recommend the spaghetti with pesto. Apparently outside toilets very clean, can't say the same for the inside one- dirty, with Mosquitos buzzing around. I had difficulty rating this cafe for my review- for day time cake and coffee i'd say very good, but for a dinner experience - Average.

My school is right next to this cafe so I visit it often after school. Most of the time, I go out with friends to have the chocolate truffle because its the best I had so far. But it gets too chocolaty as you eat so its better to share it with someone. I love the chicken mo:mo as it gives me the feeling that this is how mo:mo should taste. Its a little expensive but I think its worth the price. Dhokaima has a nice ambience and my favourite in Patan. You can eat inside or outside in the garden as well and you will also notice the interesting paintings hanging on the wall.

I stayed at Sarovar Service Apartment for 1 month during my assignment in Kathmandu. I felt warm and secured all the time. The room is very nice designed, clean, and fully equipped with kitchen materials. I enjoy self cooking very much. The AC (heater), hot water and other electric appliances are well functioned. I don’t have to worry about electricity cut off. The location is surrounded by restaurants, supermarket, food stores, fruit stores and many local stores. I received many advices about where to visit during weekends and holiday as well as very kind assistances when needed with prompt action. I feel like a VIP guest. I like coffee and breakfast in Sarovar’s restaurant very much. It is not only a place for stay but it is like a second home for me :) I would stay here

I don’t know where to start. I really enjoyed my stay here. Bhanu Joshi the head of operations went above and beyond to see that I was comfortable. He even upgraded my room from hotel type room to a 1 bedroom apartment. I felt like a king. Always had hot water with plenty of pressure. Bed was comfortable with a nice duvet to cover myself. Hey, I had 2 a/c -heaters in bedroom and in living room. Heenu and Rebica at front desk always gave me a warm and welcome smile every time I walked by. Plenty of plugs everywhere. I liked all the different types of lighting in each room. Having wall sconces next to my bed makes me feel like I’m home. Plenty of places to eat in walking distance. Today I took a $5 taxi to Thamil to do some more shopping. I’m so glad I’m not staying over there in

column7: Elephants One Side Bull On The Other
column8: You will find this one south of the Bhimson Temple which is an elaborate two tiered pagoda with interesting wood cravings and on one side two elephants at the door cruhsing a man with their foot and on the other side a bull. It was built so they say in 1627.

Wonderful architecture, enriched with wonderful works of art. Everywhere you look you can experience beautiful works. The monuments in the Durbar Square date back to the medieval Malla period from 16th to 18th century. Also Vishwanath Mandir Temple. The temple is built in Pagoda style and the temple is guarded by two stone elephants. Located near the Bhimsen Temple.
