Of special mention are the scrumptious Bohra Chicken Cutlets (nothing comes close to the ones served at TKK – even in Bombay which is known for this cutlet) with the mince succulent and a light coating of egg cooked just right; the innovative vegetarian seekh kabab delivering an intense burst of flavour; the fragrant mutton biryani and the equally aromatic vegetable biryani with the delectable pineapple raita; the delicious kababs and tandoor items – vegetarian and non vegetarian – perfectly grilled, lightly crusted on the outside, juicy on the inside.  Saving the best for last is Tasneem’s signature Butter Chicken prepared in a unique way. Instead of the usual chunky tikkas of chicken, you are served pulled chicken (marinated and cooked slowly till tender enough to be pulled into strips) in a rich, creamy gravy. The resultant dish is a luscious blend with the gravy going deep into every bit of chicken unlike the usual dish made with chunks of meat with the gravy only coating the tikka. The Butter Chicken made in Tasneem’s style is also easy to have with the pulled chicken lending itself to being wrapped and eaten in any roti of your choice unlike the tikka style as larger chunks do not hold well in rotis like the thicker tandoori and paratha. While on rotis, there is an assortment of Indian breads, the garlic butter naan being a personal favourite, as is the velvety phirni we ordered for dessert.  It is easy to see that Tasneem has not compromised in any way on the high standards she set for herself when starting out and catering to smaller groups of people with her wholesome and appetizing home catering. For instance, her mutton kababs still have no tallow added, something many commercial establishments resort to, to increase volume and quantity. The change: from catering from her home, her setting is now TKK – a warm and inviting place – where she and her husband make you feel at home, providing exceptional Indian food with the young and enthusiastic wait staff providing excellent service. Tasneem’s home catering set a benchmark in Kathmandu. Her restaurant sets it once again. Will be back for the Nihari and Kabsa. Good luck and best wishes.

Travelling from Mumbai to katmandu, and craving for authentic Moghul cuisine and Bohri Biryani in the moutain city, look no further than Tasneem's Kings Kitchen. Loved it and the owner is always there to guide you with some great new dishes to try. Lovely ambience and smiling staff adds up to the wholesome experience. No wonder many local and international celebrities visit Tasneem's. Don't miss it

column7: Third review in three years... and Tasneem's just gets better!
column8: If you've read my previous reviews of this restaurant, you know I was already a big fan of Tasneem's food and service. It has now been more than two years since I wrote my first review, and this is still without any doubt in my mind the best Indian restaurant in Kathmandu. They serve Bohri cuisine, which is much more flavorful than the typical chicken tikka masala and dry tandoori chicken I was used to. I cannot eat biryani anywhere else (in Kathmandu or back home in the U.S.), because Tasneem has spoiled me with the best!  I'm writing now because last night was an exceptional experience, even for Tasneem's. I was part of a large private group that rented out the whole restaurant. Most restaurants I know aren't capable of serving 50 people at once without running into delays in service and over- or undercooked dishes. We were an especially complicated (and demanding) group—a mix of thulo manche, professors, university students, and local project staff. Yet somehow in all of the chaos we created, Tasneem served us a magnificent, unforgettable feast that everyone was raving about the rest of the night.  We enjoyed Tasneem's signature kabsa as well as a very wide array of other dishes—veg, vegan, and meat. (Plus the best gazar ko halwa I've ever tasted.) Even the daal was amazing—no joke. The service and food were flawless, which let our group enjoy good spirits and great conversation all night long. I would definitely take a group here again. And again... and again. ;)
The ambience is really amazing, reminds you of your Indian roots 😊 a great place to have a good time with friends or family both 😊😊

column7: The night i rediscovered Indian food in Kathmandu
column8: A perfect blend of taste and ambiance. From unique menu in drinks, appetizers and the main course it just won me over a meal.. Planning to visit soon

column7: Delightful wholesome food for the body and soul in a calming ambiace
column8: If you are somebody who likes good home-style food served with pure flavours then this is the restaurant that you would like to visit. Lets start with the ambiance, we were a large group of friends of 18 and were seated in the portico surrounded by plants that contributed to a natural water conservation system that self sustains the restaurants water requirements. Well appointed solar panels that do not jar the sights also contribute towards the power requirements of the restaurant. All of this is discretely set in a very natural environment. A place where you would like to relax and enjoy your food.  Then to the food itself. Had 6 starters cannot decide which one should get a special mention. All had it's unique flavours and authenticity, a welcome change from restaurants that have a common base for all foods. Most of the starters had the "Bohra" touch. For those not in the know the "Bohra's" are a small community in India that is know for it's unique dishes that tickle every palate and want in you. The serving that night certainly stirred my want to come back to the restaurant again and I was still on my starters. The of course was the main course, difficult to beat the starters was my initial thought and kept my expectations not that high. The lamb stole my heart, the best I have had in the valley in terms of texture and taste served with freshly made Indian breads. Lets just say if you like Indian food and are in the Kathmandu Valley this hygienic, environmentally friendly restaurant is a MUST VISIT. Oh did I mention that this restaurant is run by a wonderful couple who are dedicated in ensuring that your visit is an experience and not just a meal.  PS The cocktails were gratifying, complementing the food

I had a big Indian feast when I visited Tasneem's Kitchen recently with my friends.They definitely have delicious food but is also accompanied by a warm homely atmosphere.The staff are friendly and will to make your visit an experience.I would definitely recommend the chicken patties for the starter's with a chilled local beer.Then followed by the bori biryani and angara chicken which they are famous for... A big thank you to the owners Harsha and Tasneem for their gracious hospitality .... Will definitely visit you on my next trip to Nepal
excellent ambience...welcoming owner :) ...friendly staff......at a great location ...great place for Biryani !!

I have been to this restaurant a few times and was never disappointed. Probably the best place for Indian food in Kathmandu. Even though they say Indian, the menu is different from traditional Indian menu. The items on their menu are very unique. The owners claim most of the recipes are from their family kitchens.  Loved their Chicken Multani Wings and Bohra Chicken Cutlets. Very unique that are not available outside. There are many other delicious items on the menu which require multiple visits.  Service is excellent. They make you feel at home.

column7: Khabsa , its a experience at TKK
column8: Saw a pic of Khabsa uploaded on Facebook . On my visit to Nepal , Invited my Biker friends for Khabsa . made reservations and 10 of met up . Both Tasneem and Harsh were there to Pamper us with food and serves . The...More

column7: An authentic Bohri Cuisine available in Kathmandu - very unique. Must go for all
column8: Normally there are very few Indian restaurants in Kathmandu which can serve authentic cuisine. TKK is one such restaurant which gives a feeling of delicacy and elegance. There Mutton Sigdi & Chicken Mughlai Tikka are mouth watering and Chicken Angara was quite a findings. My friends loved their Mutton Dum Biryani. The Decor and ambiance was quite interesting and innovative.

I like non veg mughlai and prefer it when it's chicken speciality and love it the most when it's typical Delhi halal delicacies.  Tasneem's Kings kitchen in Pulchowk, Lalitpur is one such restaurant that serves authentic Delhi food on a plate in Nepal. What's more the food comes with same personal one on one hospitality that makes the experience even more enjoyable. You may taste the spices and the different flavours, but according to me they serve their heart on the plate.  The butter chicken is delectable and so tender and spiced so perfect it is like perfect balance of mother's love and traditional cooking skills. The biryanis are perfection in traditional dum pukht cooking.  I would definitely recommend a visit once, from then on you will make it on your own once a week at least, can bet you on that.

column7: An amazing journey of taste and experience.
column8: Happened to pass by this place by chance and was greeted by a lady who happens to be the owner n her suggestion are worth trying.the butter chicken n biryani was scrumptious sd the spcl kela goti was a experience .

If you are in Kathmandu and happen to be connoisseur of good food and that too Mughali, you must visit Tasneem's Kings Kitchen. Pure gastronomic delight with excellent ambience. Lip smacking biriyani with Tasneem's signature butter chicken is really something you shouldn't miss. Naan with mutton nithari is another combination should definitely need to try. Kebabs and dessert as we were spared for some other day. Overall a great experience at decent enough cost and must go place for food lovers in Kathmandu.

Ambience & Aura: Calm, Soothing, Very Positive and comfortably full with seemingly satisfied patrons : -)  Decor : Elegantly allows the simplistic beauty of food to really shine : -) Owners & Staff : Incredibly kind and accomodating :-)  Menu : Interesting and Very Tempting Starters, Flavorful Curries, Mouth Melting Biryanis highly recomended and The Lovely Gajar halwa :-)  To Look For : Would recommend to follow TKK on facebook and instagram for Exciting offers and discounts :-)  Last but not least ones visit to nepal would be incomplete without experiencing TKK.
Great Indian food in Kathmandu. Tried a Biriani and the butter chicken and they were both excellent. Nice inner courtyard makes you feel miles away from the busy town just outside the door.

column7: good time spent in this sweet place run by a former indian
column8: very nice n dainty place.Small but cozy restaurant.A must visit for indian food. I am a vegetarian so ordered only veg. the food was lipsmacking.excellent food n good value for money. Apparently they hv had hollywood personalities visiting them n appreciating thier food.

This place is a godsend for those of us in Kathmandu who sometimes finds ourselves looking for authentic Mughlai food. Unbelievably delicious Bohra Muslim cuisine food at very affordable prices. The host and waiters are very attentive and service is good n friendly. Food arrived quickly and everything was made really well. We started our meal with Mutton Sigdi and Chicken Tikka kebabs. They were flavorful and moist; marinated and spiced just right. My fav dishes are the Butter Chicken and the Chicken Sheekh Biryani. The ingredients were fresh and cooked in an authentic dum pukht style. This place is a true gem and perfect dining experience!

column7: Authentic Indian food and great atmosphere
column8: The whole experience is superb. You'll find a nice garden filled with fruit trees, buttersoft meat and juicy naan's. We've had plenty of Indian food in, for instance, Thamel. Non get's close to the taste we've discovered at Tasneems! A must when you visit Patan. Especially because it's easy to acces from the main road between Patan and Thamel (though you'll only notice the silence when you sit here).

column7: TASNEEM'S KINGS KITCHEN WAS AN ABSOLUTE DELIGHT!
column8: A must-visit place to experience fine Mughlai food lovers. Setting is just perfect. Mainly catring to non-veg- tikkas and kababs are just perfect. Setting a benchmark for non-veg appetizers. This place and its breathtaking ambience call for a memorable dinner with friends and family! to sum things up, Superb ambience, Great food and Courteous staff. Must-Go!!

During my visit to Kathmandu for business. I had the opportunity to visit Tasneems Kings Kitchen restaurant...... Must say the experience left me delighted. The food was awesome !!! It was rich in taste & the portions were really big. The food was cooked in traditional manner & rich in spices. The authentic favours were mind blowing to say the least. Chicken butter masala is their signature dish & it wont disappoint you. The freshness & tenderness of the meat is to be experienced. It melts in your mouth & the flavours of the spices just take over all your senses. It really goes well with indian bread like nan or tandoori roti...... Now to their magical dish the biryani...... Its wow !!! I can endore that it was the best biryani i ever had...... Magnificent is the word to describe their biryani. Food is amazing so is the ambience & their service is fantastic. I wouldn't ask for more....... I can't wait to visit this place again. When in Kathmandu, those looking for authentic Indian mughlai halal food. Look no further than Tasneem's Kings Kitchen..... For foodies like myself, its an exhilarating experience......

I recently visited Kathmandu for Business and I can very comfortably say that Tasneem's is one of the best Indian food, I have eaten outside of India. Great variety with good portions. The food at Tasneem's was absolutely delicious. Freshly prepared, very flavoursome and extremely well presented. My colleagues and I really enjoyed the food here. Superb taste sensations and authentic Indian (Muslim Bohra) food.  All the items were equally good. In fact, it was challenging to rate one item better than the other. I specially recommend the Biryani. I always believed that the Dum Biryani in Hyderabad (the signature dish) was the best biryani ever, but after having Biryani at Tasneems' I can very comfortably endorse this as the Best Biryani EVER.  I would strongly recommend everyone to try it once and you will know what I mean.  I will definitely come back here whenever I come to Nepal again. In fact, I am looking forward to the experience ........

Second time I visited this place. This Nice restaurant has a wonderful interior and courtyard. They serve amazing indian dishes, but most of all , I liked the talking to the very classy ladie of the house! I'll come back !  Kind regards, nieke (from belgium)

column7: Authentic Indian Food by An Amazing Host
column8: Had an amazing dining experience with friends and family at this beautiful, cozy Indian restaurant in Kathmandu. Food is original and wonderfully flavorsome - even the mint chutney served with variety of Tikkas is super delicious. The spicy Mango Panna and Gazar Halwa was awesome. The highlight was the authentic butter chicken which is served by almost every Indian restaurant but not many have got it so right. A must experience for anyone visiting or living in Kathmandu. Our special thanks to the wonderful host Tasneem who goes out of her way to ensure that every guest is truly delighted.... so are we.

TKK is a restaurant that is difficult to miss on the Jhamsikhel Road in Patan. The restaurant offers both outdoor and indoor seating. The ambience is subtle with modest cots placed at the entrance and simple yet comfortable furniture to seat you. The decor is minimalistic, creative and tastefully done to present a unique dining experience. Rainwater harvesting at the restaurant speaks volumes about the owner's commitment to offer a sustainable culinary experience to it's customers. We have been to the restaurant twice and have already become great admirers of the food that they serve here. The chicken butter masala is a speciality of TKK and it's delicious. You have to try it to experience a whole new taste for this otherwise run of the mill dish. You can request for the dishes to be made spicy or not so spicy as preferred by you. We had also ordered for some chicken biryani and the chicken in the biryani literally melted in our mouths. I have never had chicken that soft ever in my life. My dad does not normally like eating outdoors. Even he ended up having more than his normal share of the food! The most important part of any dining experience for us is the hospitality. The TKK staff does a fine job here. Beginning with getting your hands washed using the bowl and pitcher, already makes you feel special. This is an experience you probably wouldn't find at many restaurants. Dishes are served with a smile and the owner, Tasneem can often be seen interacting with the guests at the restaurant. This restaurant has several items to offer and we have only explored a few. There's a lot more still remaining to have us visiting the place several times over!

TKK is the place to go especially if you want to impress your family and friends with the Indian cuisine where prominent flavors of exotic spices blend together with the main ingredient in such harmony that the luscious taste of the final outcome lingers on to their memories for long.  I love the way chef Tasneem comes over to each table once the guests are seated, to make sure that their expectations are met, with care.  My own experience with TKK regarding their service for home parties has been very pleasant, every time I sought for it. This is mainly because chef Tasneem loves to consider every little details that are important for you so that you get to host your parties with least hassles while reaping up raving reviews for the food :-)

Had the pleasure of stopping by for dinner while in kathmandu. Wound up spending a couple of hours in the delightful company of the owners and feasting on foods that reminded me of Bombay.  Thank you for keeping it real.  Nice ambience and I like the eco consciousness. Little things that go a long way.  Traveler tip :: butter chicken and kebabs.
Good food at the right price, with an interesting menu. Food is served hot and fast by competent staff.

Tasneem and her restaurant are simply amazing! Whether you are living in or just visiting Kathmandu, then Tasneem's is a must for at least one of your meals (though chances are you'll be very tempted to go again). I host a monthly dinner club in Kathmandu, and we went to Tasneem's for our most recent gathering. From the minute I created the event to when we were walking out of the door at the end of the evening, Tasneem and her staff were kind, accommodating, and professional. We had over 25 people come for the dinner club and Tasneem arranged two different spaces in her restaurant to accommodate our large group--one outside in the beautiful garden space, and another in the upstairs level of the restaurant in the case of rain. When I arrived at her restaurant, she promptly greeted me and gave me a tour of the space, and was present throughout the evening to make food recommendations and ensure that everyone was happy. And that doesn't even begin to describe the food, which is the best Indian food I have ever eaten. Tasneem has been in the food industry for over 10 years, and her experience shows. I only have a few weeks left in Kathmandu, but I am going to make returning to Tasneem's one of my priorities. It's affordable and simply delicious. I highly recommend the butter chicken and garlic naan.

column7: Simply best indian food in town at resonable price
column8: I visited Tasneem's King Kitchen during lunch hours. Owner personally greets all the customers at the restaurant. Place is beautifully set up with traditional indian and middle east theme. I ordered regular vegetarian mini meal which has everything required for a great lunch and is totally value for money.About the food , I must say I had probably the best palak paneer in ages. It was creamy and panner used was of great quality. I liked the dal served with it but i wised it could be more spicy like the ones we get in delhi. Roti was soft and great. There is no words to describe the briyani. Tasneem's Briyani is best known in town and it never disappoints. Thank you for the great lunch and would like people and tourist visits to Patan to definitely try Tasneem's restaurant.

The Kabsa experience at Tasneem's is to die for. Well done, well made and expertly presented. Recommend the Kabsa over everything else. Though I did hear the other food on the menu is equally good. The quality of the food was only overshadowed by the hospitality and service of Tasneem. The staff are very friendly and the proprietor herself is extremely hospitable and went out of her way to make the whole evening a memorable one. The food was customised to the likes of all in the party which made it even more special. Though the restaurant is not wheel chair accessible , the staff ensured all the right preparations to help one of us. Thank you guys.

column7: A very good choice for biryani.
column8: My one visit was during the fuel crisis, which limited the menu. The owner is very friendly and it really is good Mumbai Muslim halal cuisine, very hard to find in Nepal, but the waiters were downright weird, one told me - in English - that I looked "really sad," an inaccurate assumption that I did not appreciate. Another pressured me to order more than I wanted, so even though I lived very close for six months I never did go back.

column7: Best food in Kathmandu, hands down! (and halal!)
column8: My husband and I are regulars at Tasneem's now. We always have such a lovely experience - Tasneem herself is always so warm, charming & welcoming every time and the staff are efficient and attentive. We are always spoilt for choice with the menu, whether it is for lunch or dinner. The butter chicken is so delicious and always a favourite along with the daal and chicken tikka. Depending on the specials, I highly recommend the kasoori methi chicken as well which is just heavenly. Tasneem knows her flavors and this really is a go-to restaurant, especially if you are looking for halal food (which can be quite tricky in Kathmandu). Be sure to enjoy your dinner or drinks in the pretty courtyard, which is especially beautiful and romantic in the evening.

The foodmis cooked on charcoal and fantastically tasty. Oh my the butter chcicken, we have it almost every time. Check out rhw chocolates they are divine. The venue has interesting character and a great vibe. But mostly tasneem and the staff are so friendly she makes every visit feel like you are a special guest

I cannot say enough good things about this place. This is by far my favorite restaurant in Lalitpur. I went for the first time with my husband and 2 kids last night. We had a couple appetizers, Kashmir Chicken and Palak Paneer, Jaree rice and chipati bread. They also gave us a sample of their signature dish, Butter Chicken. The food we ordered was fantastic, but the Butter Chicken was divine. If you go, try their signature dish, but based on our experience, you cant go wrong no matter what you order. I get the impression that our dishes were not as spicy as they normally make them as we had two small children with us and we asked them to keep it spiced for the kids. My husband had gone with a friend on a different occasion and he said that the food was much spicier (and delicious!).  But the food was only the half of it. The owner is so kind and engaging. Made us feel so welcome. Our waiter made recommendations on how much to order (perfect amount!), the food came out fast but without making us feel hurried. The best part was that we had brought our 16 month old and 3 year old with us, and the staff helped us entertain them so we could enjoy our meal. I don't expect that can happen every time (eg if its a particularly busy night), but it made the whole experience perfect.

My husband and I went there a week ago for the second time..the food was simply delicious, great tasting, well cooked and hygienic. Tasneem offered a complimentary taste of a mouth watering and very tender chicken dish which name I have forgotten even after asking twice...So sorry!!! The eco friendly and clean environment and the nice hindi lounge music, loud enough to be enjoyed and low enough to allow conversation, made the experience even better. Of course you can find cheaper places, but having been living here 8 months now, I prefer to cook my own food in order to save my money and preserve my health, and go to a restaurant only when it's worth it. Tasneem's restaurant is definitely worth visiting! Keep up the good job!

Only things in this world which can satisfy all 5 senses are Food and Sex and these are the senses of Sight, Sound, Taste, Touch and Smell. To me a good gastronomic experience is only if I can put a smiley accross all 5 of these. At TKK they take their business very seriously. They dont want their food to reach only your stomach. They want it to reach your soul. Thanks TKK for making my soul burrp. That butter chicken and biryani (like everything else you serve) has my senses going haywire everytime I think of your food. Keep up the good work.

I went here with my family right after the earthquake in May and what a refresh it was! I am a hardcore meat-arian, but I couldn't eat meat on that particular day I visited. I do not like eating veggie too much but wow, was I blown away by just the vegetarian food there!  One of the nicest things about that night was how courteous the staff was. They catered to every one of my elderly grandmother's needs. Even the owner came to talk to us about the food. That is definitely a good sign of a good owner!  One last little thing that I wish were different is the serving portions. If they were a little bigger, I would love it.  I have yet to taste the popular Biryani there. I have reserved that experience for a special occasion coming soon. I bet it it will be awesome! :D

My husband and I stumbled on this gem of a restaurant while out exploring our new neighborhood. I had the butter chicken and, I can't stress this enough, it was the best butter chicken I have ever tasted. Spicy without being over the top, smooth sauce, and chicken that almost melts in your mouth. Unfortunately, we were to full to try the briyani...but we will be back! I highly recommend this restaurant. Your Nepal experience won't be complete without it!

column7: Real food from people who care
column8: Two of my friends and I arrived in Kathmandu, and we were very hungry. We were told to go here, so we made the walk. Upon arrival, we were greeted by a friendly hostess and promptly sat outside in the patio area. The decorations and aura gave this place an authentic feel for an Indian restaurant.  We got our menus and started thinking about our order, when a lady (who turned out to be Tasneem herself) came by to help us decide what to order. I am an American who cannot normally handle a lot of heat from the spices, but I was traveling with two guys who love spicy food. She encouraged us to get a couple appetizers as well as some different dishes.  My absolute favorites were the Mutton Appetizer and the House Special Butter Chicken. The Mutton is pounded flat, then spiced and fried. It is still moist, but crispy. The flavour seems to just be jam-packed in this bite. Then came the Butter Chicken. I haven't had a dish that tasted this delicious in a while. The food textures of meat and gravy melt together leaving this savory experience. Pair this with their garlic butten naan, and you have a winner.  They had some happy hour specials on local beers and cocktails. The mocktails are made with fresh juices.  We then met Tasneem's husband. They were very kind and gave us recommendations for things to do in Kathmandu and surrounding areas. I strongly recommend going to see Tasneem if you visit. You will not be disappointed. We liked it so much, we came back for a second meal in 4 days there.  The second time, we ended up ordering pretty much the same; we just knew what to expect. We were able to add a little heat to the dishes this time, and it was still amazing for all of us.  It is nice in the patio area, with the cool breezes and the ambiance. There is no wifi as they encourage you to talk with your table, but this does not mean that they are not engaged with their customers. The owners take pride in the ability to listen to customers and their experiences.  Do yourself a favour and check this place out.

column7: Best indian food and very attentive service
column8: The restaurant is decorated in a minimalistic, modern and refined manner. Not much plush and plunder. Only the stuff itbrealy needs. no WiFi as concept: people should enjoy the food and communicate with each other. Nice little courtyard. The staff withoutbexemption was very attemptive, friendly, and flexible. That contributes well to the unique atmosphere. All the food was extremely tasty and all was prepared fresh. What we can especially recommend: chicken tikka, kadai ghosh, mutton birvani (as soft and tender as it can be), paneer tawa, navaratna korma and Kashmiri aloo.  We will certainly come again!

Loved the whole Mumbai experience. The food is straight from bylines of Mumbai. The Kababs, tikka and the innovative Chicken Tikka Momo, mixing Indian and Nepali cuisine... nice touch Madam Tasneem. Had heard so much of the biryanis, so skipped the gravies and went straight for the Biryanis. Made a good choice, the mutton biryani was perfect. Soft succulent tender pieces of meat with well balanced spices and flavor of long grain basmati nice. Heavenly combination! Next time will hit gravies hard with a vengeance, until then Tasneem. Au revere... until we meet again.

column7: Outstanding quality : to be appreciated and enjoyed
column8: Good Indian food and is Hard to find here in Kathmandu.  The place has a nice interior, with a slightly elegant feel to it. Staffs are friendly, and will greet you with a smile before directing you to your seat. We ordered Biryanis and they have various options. I enjoyed every single bite.  They have a sizeable menu with something for everyone even Vegetarians are well accommodated.

Located at the less desirable end of Jhamshikhel Road, there’s a danger of giving up before you’ve found it. But persevere, because the attractive building draws you in: tempting colours and lights at night. Through wide doors into the courtyard terrace – compellingly nice and the interior looks good too. Very attentive and pleasant service, perhaps because the eponymous Tasneem is in constant attendance, with friendly greetings and goodbyes to customers. Food is good but far from startling. I had a competently cooked Dahl and some paneer but it didn’t sing with flavour as the food does in the better Indian restaurants. Maybe it needed waking up with some fresh herbs or something? I left feeling happy with the evening, but wondering if there’s been overinvestment in the lovely building and too little investment in the food. Time for a recipe review?

Tasneem is an amazing personalised experience with sumptous delicious Indian meal. The service is super quick with excellent starters. Make sure you have a Sweet Lassi to start with. Ambience, Service, Food, Hospitality - All 5 Star.....

column7: feast like a king at Tasneem's Kings Kitchen
column8: No visit to Kathmandu would be complete without a visit to Tasneems king kitchen who serves the most amazing and mouth watering biryanis and kebabs. thoroughly enjoyed the overall dinning experience with a ever smiling face of Tasneem the lady running the show along with her team. the kebabs melt away in your mouth as you bite into them which has amazing aroma and taste which would linger in your sense for a long time and would make me visit them again and again.  Thank you for serving the best biryanis and kebabs in town ...

column7: A century old recipie relived.A legacy. And the taste of the royals. Muhglai Extravazanza
column8: Ooh god when will Nepal start having good Indian Restaurant. Guys any place for Biryanis??  These are juz a couple of questions we discuss thinkinhthinking about Mughlai food in Nepal.  Tasneems is now open for a mouthwatering experience. A place where your tastebuds starts dancing. dekho kaise Jeeb Laplapai Is a statement for Tasneems.  Wonderfully designed menu and magic of the Indian Chefs specially who bring the legacy of Bora Mughlai Food. A blend of taste and tradition.  Go for it and see .

Delicious is an understatement... If ever u r in Nepal n feel the urge to eat authentic Indian dishes... Then this is the place to go to. The warmth of the place n the richness of the food are incomparable. We wish we could have sampled everything on the menu... Ahh maybe next time it will b a complete foodie trip.

column7: One of the best in town with an unique menu.
column8: If you want an unique menu this is the place. The ambience is very creative. I have been to many restaurants during my stay in Kathmandu in the past couple of years, but I haven't come across a menu as in Tasneems. I understand it changes daily. Chicken cutlets melt in your mouth. I would definitely go back for Chicken tandoori drum sticks and chicken-sheekh-kabob biriyani.

column7: Amazing!! This is as good as it gets!!!
column8: Where to begin? Wow this place is amazing! I've been to most every top restaurant in Kathmadu Valley over these last 2 years here on business, and as a former restaurant owner and exec, I am critical on both quality of food and service.  I've gotten hooked on Tasneem's biryanis and curries. The chicken is moist and succulent. Nothing is over-spiced or over salted here...(as most restaurants are infamous for as a way to mask the lower quality of meats and lack of experience needed to execute a dish properly). At Tasneem's you will find skilled chefs generationally trained in proper authentic techniques, and all using from what I've come to know, very fresh and quality ingredients.  The kitchen is more than clean. See for yourself! And the staff is warm and friendly. I see a long bright success for Tasneem's King's Kitchen, and I'll tell you the main reason...it's ownership. It's a husband and wife duo, a sincere family effort, and they can be found there most any night. And in my professional experience, that can't be beat.  This is what a family fine dining experience should be :)  Long Live Tasneem's King's Kitchen!!!  Respectfully, David Lubov Henderson

I ate here for two weeks and every time it felt like I was at home. Super friendly staff and we always checked in with each other. If you are staying at the Five 14 Bed and breakfast (which I was) the breakfast (from a...More
I thoroughly enjoyed the ambience and cookie and (gluten-free) coffee I enjoyed here. They tell me that the shepherd’s pie is gluten free too, which is a big plus in my books.
The ambience of the cafe was really nice, and it was very well complemented by some nice food. The menu had plenty of interesting items that I would love to try on my next visit.

This cafe takes pride in customer service and it shows in its employees. I visited four times in one week and they were always courteous, prompt and attentive.  You’ll have plenty of food options and breakfast is all day. Unique drinks like the turmeric twist add a fun alternative to other local cafes. However, the delivery of these items always felt a little slow. Maybe it’s because I’m American but 5 min for a latte and 15 min for a sandwich at such a small cafe seemed strange.  Indoor seating will be very limited but if it’s warm outside they have a great covered outdoor seating area to include a couple comfy couches with room for up to five people.

I enjoyed the room I stayed in with my trekking group. We had bunk beds and our own bathroom because it was the biggest room. The cafe was nice. Good coffee, and if in doubt of where to eat, a safe place to get food. I would recommend Kairos Cafe if your in Kathmandu!

Kairos Cafe offers a wide selection of refreshing beverages and has a great menu of food options with choices both local and western. They also keep cleanliness in high regard and everything is very sanitary. Overall, an amazing experience!
Kairos is a great place to just sit and relax with awesome music, great staff and food. I always have a great experience
The black coffee is the some of the very best I have had in Kathmandu and I enjoy watching them make siphon coffee too. The baristas are friendly and professional.

I tried multiple cafes around the area that I stayed in Kathmandu, and Kairos is definitely the best! The staff is warm and welcoming, the drinks are delicious and the food was amazing! I can't say enough about my experience with Kairos cafe. Also...best coffee in town! You need to come check it out! Try their pumpkin spice latte, French press or any other drink - you won't be disappointed!

this place is awesome! the barista is amazing she is cheerful all the time if you go there often enough she remembers your order! The coffee and tea are really good! and they are very good with getting your food in good timing, and the...More

I ordered shepard's pie, and I have to say it was the best meal I have had in Nepal so far! It was amazing! The flavor was so delicious. The staff was very friendly and courteous, they made sure that I enjoyed my meal. It was also nice to have wifi available for free.

It's a place where I feel myself at home. Very pleasant staff and interesting menu. You need to read the "kar.ma coffee" book to get in touch with the history of this place and to discover how and where all the ceramic pots are made, how everything related to coffee is handmade.  The organic coffee beans are provided by local farms located over 1000m altitude.  I already spend a couple of hours here chilling out from the perpetual Thamel rush.  You can buy from here coffee related stuff, even soap and candles made from grounded coffee.

Almost the whole cafe sprawls across a long terrace on the second floor of the complex where this cafe is located. There are indoor seatings, but because the winter in Kathmandu valley is mostly mild and sunny I decided to sit outside and bask in the pleasant morning sun that hits the outdoor seating area.  It's a really pretty place in a quieter side of Jamsikhel. The meticulously arranged seatings and the overall decor of the cafe is very inviting. The tables and the decoration that sits of those tables are clean, and so are the chairs, the floor, the utensils (you got the point!).  I think the staff have a hard time striking the balance between being professional and laidback.  Here's my experience: On my first visit when I made it to the second floor I saw a lady perching out of the balcony. I went inside the cafe and having seen no one came right back out. Then, I asked the lady whom I had seen earlier if she worked there. She smiled and replied affirmatively.  So I told her that it was my first time there and she immediately pointed towards the menu board. She did not recommend anything. No worries, I thought to myself. Right before I ordered another staff member had entered and so the two had started to engage in a lengthy conversation.  So, finally after catching the lady's attention I ordered a cup of drip coffee ( which was ok) and asked her how and where I should pay. She said pay here and I could sit anywhere I would like (inside or outside). Then, they started engaging in, I am guessing, an important conversation.  The trinkets that were on display caught my attention and started looking at them. I was really impressed by what they had on display so I hurriedly asked the servers (now there were two of them) if they were on sale and exclaimed how beautiful they were in Nepalese.  [So, here is the thing I haven't lived in Nepal for 20 (I'm 28, almost) years, so having lived in the West for so long my Nepalese accent is a bit blah.]  Immediately after I asked them those questions, a burst of laughter cracked. Now I am not sure if that was directed towards me or they were laughing at whatever they were talking to each other about. I felt embarrassed, nonetheless.  After a minute or so, the other lady jumped and told me that they were all on sale. I thanked her for her response. Then I asked the lady who took my order if I can pay (again). Now she was sitting down and replied that I could. At this point I was a bit annoyed because of what had transpired and I wasn't particularly sure where to pay, so I looked at her straight and said "so can I pay now." Anyway, I don't think she got my point. I paid and got myself a table. That same lady brought the coffee to my table. I thanked her. I sent out an email (they have free wi-fi, yippie!) and left.  In retrospect, I really think this was all a big misunderstanding, and I sure hope that they were not laughing at me.  I am saying that this was all a big misunderstanding because don't think anyone can be that rude, especially not Nepalese people. But, I don't see how I can go back to this otherwise nice place.

I've been there twice already and I cannot wait to go back. kar.ma COFFEE stands out among all the Coffee places because of its unique interior and a very laid back atmosphere with very pleasant staffs and one of the best coffees in Kathmandu.
A nice place to be. A good experience and VERY GOOD COFFEE. A nice atmosphere. A good place to enjoy weekend holidays.

Really great coffee and a lovely relaxing place to sit. Love the products and havent seen anything like it in Kathmandu but it was a shame that there weren't many biscuits without nuts in as I'm allergic.

Love this place and their unusual and interesting idea - pay what you like for coffee. Went there a few times and each time the coffee tasted different. They do the pour over style and it is hard to make it strong enough for me, but their heart is in the right place so I don't care. Kind of bare bones and tiny place. Be nice it they served food. Not easy to find, on the third floor far in from the street, but everything is hard to find in Nepal.

Even though I am not a "coffee drinker" but rather go for tea, I keep on getting stuck in this coffee shop since it opened a few months ago. It is run by an Austrian lady and she keeps on adding new products to her portofolio constantly. The place is coffee-shop and showroom at the same time, where you can not only drink coffee but also shop for locally produced, recycled or imported products related to coffee. Lucky for me, they have added tea to their menue some time ago, which is also grown in Nepal - like the coffee - and of outstanding quality.  The "kar.ma" in the name probably refers to the pricing system for the coffee specialities - there is no menue - you just pay what you think it's worth. Because of that it's not one of the many overpriced restaurants in the area where you usually only meet foreigners or rich Nepalis, but just about everyone that likes to have a coffee or tea once in a while. The coffee-shop has quickly developed into a meeting place for many ex-pats living in the area and people working in nearby offices. Many customers are also coming from the "Pranamaya Yoga Studio" below the place or the "Kathmandu Jazz Conservatory" right above. Interesting conversations and new friendships are nearly inevitable which makes it a perfect starting point if you are new to the area. If there is no one around to talk to, you can always use the free Wifi to surf the net until somebody interesting shows up. Be careful as this place is somehow addictive. For me and some of my friends it has become something like an external living room!  They don't have a food menue as such but sell various home-made organic cookies. As they cooperate with nearby restaurants, you can ask them to order sandwiches or other simple foods which are then delivered to the coffee-shop.

Thank you so much for taking such wonderful care of our family during our visit to Roadhouse cafe pulchowk. your staff were so very accommodating and recommend about about the best food. The food was absolutely wonderful and a good presentation. We especially enjoyed the...More

It's an awesome little place. The food is great. The service is equally good too. The lighting, the ambiance... It's all simply magical. Me and my girlfriend had a wonderful time. The food is good in quality and quantity. they provided good heating as well....More

We had heard such great things about this place so maybe we had our hopes set higher than we should have. The flavors of the food was good. My wife said her pizza was very good. However, my son and I have the chicken Parmesan and we were disappointed with the tomato sauce on the pasta. As well as the chicken was much smaller than the hard crusty battered shell it was in. For dessert we had the sizzling brownie. The flavor of the brownie was excellent however as it was served sizzling, it was continually cooking and ended up a bit burnt on the bottom. The staff were excellent and very attentive to our table and cleared the dishes off the tables as soon as they were emptied. All in all it was a good experience and the food was not bad. So I have no qualms recommending this place to others. Be aware that it is a bit pricier than other places. But worth the try.
Good ambience and good food. Food is well presented and tasty. Service too is good and quick. Worth a visit
We are in our winter vacation at Katmandu we are travelling so many ancient places and restaurants now finally we are here to experience Awesome coffee here we enjoying a lots nice coffee.

What makes a restaurant a good restaurant? Service? Food? Ambiance? If so, I would like to take the one star away from roadhouse pulchowk. I'm not sure why people would spend thousands of Rs. on such a horrible service. The servers seemed lost and not a single server had a smile or enthusiasm to serve and make it a wonderful experience for the guest. The food was average and the ambience was average as well. Every time I pass through roadhouse and see people either waiting to eat or coming out from the restaurant, I feel sad for them.

Good food notwithstanding, our dining experience was marred by an incomprehensibly condescending staff of waiters. The clientele at this restaurant is almost exclusively a bunch of white expatriates. If you can ignore the poor manners, visit the restaurant by all means, because they have some inventive appetizers and rich desserts. The main pasta courses are pretty ordinary (descriptively-speaking) but the pizzas offer more variety.

The place has a view of the street outside and the interiors are eye catching. The food is also delicious..The firewood pizza adds a flavour to your taste..A bit noisy but full with friends..A good place to chat with friends, families and colleagues.

column7: Pizza is good but Ambience not attractive
column8: Keeping up with the brand, the food is good and tasty. Serves hot and fresh prepared pizza. And offers same spread of options for your meal but the ambience is nowhere in comparison to their Naxal outlet. This place was very bright, washroom's are also not that clean and properly maintained, some construction work was going on above ground floor and thus lot of noises. Not enjoyable.

I am the companion FredSmithsonian talked about (see his review). After this certainly disgusting spitting-experience (fancy some of this in your food - at least in your imagination?) I continued trying to contact that "manager" during the next days. I always called at those times I was informed, this person would be around. Of course I never reached him. I was then giving my phone number and asked to return the call - which never happened. Why was I not surprised. In other words, the staff misbehaves and tries to conceal, and the management does not care.

column7: Piano B, on a league of its own.
column8: If you want to set a standard for quality food in Kathmandu, Piano B is the standard. I very often get disappointed with the quality of food in restaurants, but never in Piano B. You will just keep going back. The best thing is that the menu is seasonal so you can keep trying out new things. Feeling confused, just ask GianAntonio.

I visited Piano B as a large group of 9. The restaurant is a lovely little place with a nice atmosphere. The menu is small, but with enough variety (although more adult friendly). I had a simple margherita pizza which was delicious and huge! The service was ok. As a large group, obviously not all of the food could come together, but it was a bit disappointing to have people finishing their meals before some people received their food. Overall, a lovely quaint restaurant with good food, but is quite expensive for the experience.

Visited this delightful restaurant on a Saturday for lunch. Not too busy, so service was quick. My ravioli was light and tasty. My friend had chicken meatballs, which were great. My son had penne,, which was fine. For dolci, my friend had chocolate lava and gelato, which was very tasty. My own choice was millefogile, which was nicely presented and very smooth. All in all a great experience!!

With great ambience, this little eatery is a real find in Nepal. Plenty of wines and interesting Italian style meats and cheeses are on offer and understandably this restaurant seems popular with the ex pats.

column7: Cosy Italian Trattoria style ambience at its best!
column8: Piano B is the place to go in Kathmandu for genuine Italian food wine, coffee and homemade ice cream! Small place with a typical Italian ambience and family style friendly services. The menu is limited and changes daily but has always classics like homemade pasta, pizza or roast lamb, prepared with great care and fresh ingredients. Very attentive and friendly staff add to the experience and the world class top of the line homemade chocolate ice cream rounds it up as a no miss out Kathmandu experience! Open all days from lunch until 10pm except Sundays when it’s closed!

column7: Nice food, a little over priced. Popular with expats.
column8: A nice place to eat with a wide range of food and drink (especially beers from around the world). A little over-priced and 'a place to be seen at' but don't let that dissuade you from eating there. I enjoyed my visit but there are other places around that are equally appealing.
The restaurant has an interesting and delicious menu and the B&B is great value for money with nicely decorated rooms that make you feel at home.
When friends come this is the first place we check. They have modern rooms, AC and an amazing breakfast. They are close to Patan Durbar. The staff is really awesome too.

column7: Best Restaurant in Nepal - Hands Down
column8: Where to begin?  I arrived on a Sunday evening (I was staying at the Piano B&B above the restaurant). I walked in and instantly knew this was somewhere I could trust. I told the owner, Antonio that I was too tired to think and to just choose what he thought I should eat. There are very few restaurants I would be happy to have choose the food for me, Piano B is one of them. The food is absolutely delicious! I mean every single thing they make is delicious, from the fresh bread, olive oil and balsamic to nibble on while you order, to the cheese and meat plater to the perfectly al dente pasta dishes to the high quality wine they store.  Antonio has established an amazing little restaurant and to anyone in Kathmandu who has heard of Piano B but never visited, you really need to go there. This guy is working his butt off to deliver quality and having spent 7 weeks in Kathmandu this summer, I have seen the time and effort he is putting into his place.  Having stayed at the B&B above I had the pleasure of eating many many times at this restaurant, its hard to find food this good in my current city of Boston, never mind Kathmandu. And if you're reading this thinking, "Italian food? In Nepal? Why?" then you've the same thought my colleagues had when they travelled to Nepal for 4 days last week towards the end of my trip. After I took them there, one commented in the morning that he dreamt of the Spinach Ravioli and despite the two thinking I was crazy to take them to an Italian on their four day visit to Nepal, they insisted we go back the very next night, and were again served with the same amazing food.  Like the B&B the restaurant is well managed, the staff are polite and professional, the ambience is tasteful as is the music. They stock real beer, real wine, real COFFEE, and trust me all of it meets the highest of standards of a classy Italian restaurant. I would say this is the best restaurant in all of Kathmandu and probably Nepal, yes its not traditional Nepali food, but quality is quality!  So just go there! And get the little onion dish starter thing. Oh and the chocolate lava cake. And an espresso to finish. And drink their house white.  I'm coming back!

I love this restaurant!!! Like every Italian I'm always suspiciuos about Italian Restaurant situated outside my country...but i was wrong. Restaurant is very clean and staff is quite professional. An excellent quality of ingredients and a lovely feeling for the "visual part" of the plate complete this marvellous experience. A must try

column7: Like an oasis in a desert
column8: I stayed in Piano B&B for two months (March - April) this year and as a first time visitor to Nepal having fantastic meals every night was a real life saver. Antonio (the owner) and his staff go to lengths to ensure that your experience in Piano B is a pleasant one. The food is fantastic, the pasta (on many occasions home made by Antonio - his ravioli are 5 star) is delicious, the restaurant has a very fine selection of beers and wine which although might seem expensive to some (based on some other reviews I was reading) is still cheaper than other places in Kathmandu. Highly recommended!
The food is good the ambience is warm, nice and cosy service in courteous. All make a good evening dining experience, but found portions small for the price they charge.

column7: Back again and it didn't disappoint
column8: My return visit to Piano B was well worth it. Too cold to sit outside but the restaurant was packed inside. Still serving up good pasta and chianti by the glass, I enjoyed a great evening. There are always a few specials on the blackboard behind the bar, this night I ordered the bruschetta, which came with a huge offering of ripe, delicious tomatoes.

I only write reviews when an experience stands head and shoulders above the rest. This is exactly what I get at Piano B. Feeling adventurous - I recently ordered the Octopus as part of a fish skewer. It was worth it.  The Fish pieces and the octopus were cooked well, with beautiful seasoning and topped with a flavoursome sauce. It has been a long time since that I have eaten such delicacies so to have the privilege in Kathmandu felt super special. A great addition to the food scene of Ktm.  The staff team, the food and the atmosphere is always great. A great find and would definitely recommend.

Everything about this place is wonderful. The owner is a wonderful Italian man who deserves praise for making a special place in this part of town. I felt like I was in a restaurant along a street in Rome on a hot summer night. The...More

column7: Great Italian Joint with great beer selection in Kathmandu
column8: So, this is an interesting place started by two italian friends who came to Nepal to teach. However, they ran out of money, so decided to open a restaurant serving authentic Italian Food. The owners are always there taking the orders and also cooking. Love their spirit.  And, they have done a great job. All the dishes are very well prepared. I ordered the Zuccini & Beet Soup, the Shrimp Pasta, and the Bruschetta. Everything was yummy and authentic.  To make things better, it had a great selection of beers. A must visit in Nepal.

column7: Piano B is one of the best restaurants in Nepal
column8: I enjoyed marvelous dinners and lunches at Piano B in Patan. Amazing wines and fresh Italian food in a very nice ambient, with a lovely host, Bubu! One of the best restaurants you MUST try :-)

We discovered Piano B while searching our hotel in Patan, after a long motorbike ride on the mountains. It was dark in the evening, but we recognised something familiar, this little, cozy and modern italian restaurant. Nice atmosphere and excellent food, just like in Italy, very unusual to find outside Italy, homemade pasta cooked "al dente". A very friendly place and nice host, like an old friend. Very recommended.

The warmth and atmosphere of a real trattoria welcomes you as you get in, indulge in Gian' unique Venetian spritz aperitive, the rare selection of Italian affettati then is a logistic miracle, the large collection of Italian wines, taste the Apulian Primitvo. And then indulge in the unique selection of home made pastas, my favorite, the crespelle ai funghi. Generous with portions and table space Piano B was the missing item of the menu in the endless list of places in Kathmandu, a definite must, worth a visit and even more a relapse.

A great little Italian restaurant, authentic and warm. You can feel the owner's love through the beautiful food, wine, music, and decor. I love having the option of the long bar for sociable nibbles and cocktails, or a more intimate experience wining and dining at...More

This is the place to be for a perfect( handmade!!!) pasta, lasagna. The whines are great and the place itself makes you feel like you are in Italy.  Price quality is good, the menu prices are included the 13% VAT. The owner is italian and knows what he is doing.  Can't wait to visit this place again when I'm back in Nepal

I just wish I lived closer to Piano B - really the authentic Italian taste - all exceptionally fresh ingredients and anything that is not available locally, is imported from Italy eg. the salame. I loved the antipasto - vegetables pickled in olive oil and the perfectly cooked pasta (al dente) with a delicious funghi sauce. The creme caramel was also a real treat. The ambience is like an Italian bar. It was a great experience with a group of friends and a few glasses of wine.

column7: Great hospitality and food. Thank you Jenish !!
column8: I passed by this restaurant upon my arrival in Patan and was invited in to see the place and description of cuisine typical Newark ! I went there a couple of nights later and was very nicely welcomed again and recommended to a few typical dishes which I enjoyed very much. Jenish was particularly attentive to my questions and was very helpful. The terrasse was very nice but the top floor seemed very fun as well. A place I recommend for all new in Patan !!
This restaurant has a nice terrace where I enjoyed a very good nepalese set meal. They offer fresh seasonale juices. Good service and reasonable prices.

We came early for dinner attracted by the pleasant atmosphere had a few drinks and then ordered the Newari set and c momo's. Both were delicious and beautifully presented. The Newari here is hard to beat! But what really sets this place apart is the professional conscientious service. Overall a lovely experience - will definitely return. All inclusive pricing is a very nice touch also.

Good zoo ,have lake with activities like boating ,with many coffee shop around . We spend good time even though It's painful to see the animals in cage ,but it's the only chance to see animals are housed within enclosures, cared for, displayed to the public, and in some cases bred Modern zoos also aim to help teach visitors the importance on animal conservation, often through letting visitors witness the animals firsthand. Some critics and the majority of animal rights activists say that zoos, no matter what their intentions are, or how noble they are, are immoral and serve as nothing but to fulfill human leisure at the expense of the animals (which is an opinion that has spread over the years). However, zoo advocates argue that their efforts make a difference in wildlife conservation and education. Many zoos work to improve their animal enclosures and make it fit the animals' needs, although constraints such as size and expense make it difficult to create ideal captive environments for many species. Animals in zoos often exhibit behaviors that are abnormal in their frequency, intensity, or would not normally be part of their behavioural repertoire. These are usually indicative of stress. For example, elephants sometimes perform head-bobbing, bears sometimes pace repeatedly around the limits of their enclosure, wild cats sometimes groom themselves obsessively, and birds pluck out their own feathers. Some critics of zoos claim that the animals are always under physical and mental stress, regardless of the quality of care towards the animals.

The zoo is center for experience wild life in city area. The birds, Tiger, Rhino, Elephant are the most exciting wild animals you will ever see in jungles. And also you will have chance of riding elephant and boating in the large pool in here.

When You are tired of Kathmandu city life then it is time to take a moment and relax in Patan Central zoo. No suprises but nice to peacefully and enjoy a moment of nature. I liked most to see bengali tiger and pelican. Entrance fee was 700 nepali rupias from western visitor (adult).

Central zoo of kathmandu valley is located 30 min drive from kathmandu Durbar square to Lalitpur. This zoo was establish more than 100yr old is by Rana primeminister. At that time it was one of the best and lovely place to visit for the animals of Nepal. In the courses of time it could not be modified only very little changes are done to accommodate more animals. Instead of more animals in the zoo we found less animals but more people due to the growth of population and there is no place for children to take. People come here to see people instead animals. Unfortunately one of the beautiful historic zoo of Kathamandu turned ugly zoo.

My husband and I spent a very enjoyable morning with our 3 grandsons (5, 7 and 9 years old) walking through this shady, well-laid-out zoo. We felt we could observe most of the animals well and were impressed with the variety. Seeing the elephant take a stroll through the zoo was an added surprise.

column7: Be sure to know the price before you go
column8: Be sure you know the price of entry before you go... otherwise they will see that you are a tourist and charge you more. Nice to see the animals... definitely not the care they get other places. The animals are nice to see. We felt like we were more of an attraction than the animals... the locals wanted to take pictures with the tourists.

I went to the zoo today with my Dad having stayed at Chitwan for 3 nights. We got to see all of the animals we had seen in the wild. It's sad to see them in such small cages but I think the zoo was quite badly affected by the earthquake and their funding is possibly going in to repairs. It was good to see the tigers up close as we'd only caught a glimpse in the wild (apparently we were quite fortunate to have done so).

We want to the too during our recent holiday trip to Kathmandu. For locals and Indians ticket is NC-100 for rest it is 500. It has got any animals you look forward to see during a visit to zoo. Boating is also available inside the zoo. There are quite a few eating option outside zoo. Overall had a nice time specially kids enjoy a lot.

column7: A nice activity for a relaxing day
column8: Some of the animal cages seem too small. There is an elephant for riding, looking rather sad. But they have a variety of interesting animals, among others one of the endangered white rhinos and a giant tiger. Especially the beautiful birds were worth the entrance fee though, and the walk around the premises is nice. All in all I have mixed feelings about this place. It's definitely not a must-see, but if you have a day to spare in Lalitpur and nothing to do, it's a nice place to take younger kids. They have pedal-boats in a pond in the centre of the park and a teeny-tiny fun park.

This Zoo has a great variety of animals that I´ve never seen before. They´ve got both hippo, rhino, leopard, elephants, all kinds of birds, bears and the famous Bengali Tiger. I got to feed the tiger for only 2 dollars. This is by far the cheapest and most exciting experience I´ve ever encountered. The zoo has two fairs for kids (a chapter and a train) which is cheap an good fun for children upto 5-6 years. As everything in Nepal, the zoo has had its glory days, but worth visiting for the entire family.

I get it. Nepali children need to learn about wildlife and conservation, and a zoo has the potential to teach them about these important topics. But I am not sure this zoo does either, and even if it does, it's not a place for tourists. I'm not convinced the animals are treated humanely, or even fed well. So my advice iif you are a tourist: avoid like the plague.
There are many different kinds of animals. I liked it and visit . only thing that I don't like is its area...it should be expanded so that animals would have sufficient place.

I went to visit the zoo with my Nepalese host family and although I had to pay 500 rupees when the locals only pay 100 it was a nice experience.  There seems to be a lot of construction work happening and a large number of empty pens but on the whole the animals seemed to be well cared for and I was surprised at the number of local species and delighted as an Aussie to see Emus, cockies, and other native birds.  The locals love their zoo and the little girl I took as her birthday treat was totally 'wrapped'.  If you have the time, grab a green bus and for a 40 rupee trip it is a nice break from the dust and noise.

The zoo was a fun experience. It's a lot cheaper than other attractions (I think it was 250 rupees for a foreigner). The zoo others elephant rides (for an addition cost) and has a lot of interesting Himalayan animals you would not see in western zoos.  I went there from my hostel in Thamel by catching a bus (nearby Thamel) for 20 rupees each way. It makes for a cheap interesting day in Kathmandu.
The food is a welcome and comforting experience. The pastries are fresh, the coffee is great. The atmosphere, WIFI and clean of the place makes it all a great experience.

Top of the world coffee has provided the best breakfast experience for the ever developing Patan area. It Has got beautiful ambience, great choice in breakfast menu and great and polite staffs. Just 10 mins away from the Patan Heritage site, they provide one of the best brewed coffee in Kathmandu.
I love to drink coffee as much as much and i had good coffee . thank you for your team efforts . see you soon.

Few places in Nepal can offer coffee prepared to the same standard as Top of the World. We've been purchasing their coffee since they started roasting and adding flavours long before the Coffee Shop opened. Now anyone can call in and experience the taste of locally roasted coffee and meticulously prepared food while benefiting from high speed internet, pleasant surroundings and warm friendly staff. Top of the World, the latest addition to the essential Nepal experience.
Very pleasant atmosphere, good food, excellent coffee, friendly staff, great service, A most enjoyable experience!

I love to buy their coffee and brew it for my clients in my Salon. I enjoy having my meeting at Top of the World and enjoy the food and the great prices. This is a good place to take friends and hang out.

This little coffee shop surprised us, it was just around the corner from our guesthouse in a "touristy" area of Kathmandu. The coffee was absolutely delicious and the cake fresh. The atmosphere was sooooo relaxing! Good books to read and comfortable sofa's. The staff was exceptionally friendly and it felt like we've been friends forever!  The fact there is free WiFi is an added bonus to catch up on the travel diaries.  This will be another place that I will definitely visit again on my next trip to Nepal.

column7: No one wanted to take our order
column8: An odd place. We were drawn in by the roof top location with nice views over the square. However, we kept asking politely for someone to take our order but no one did. It also felt like a strange place. We gave up in the...More

We went to this place because of the rooftop. Of our dishes two were correct but the vegetable sandwich was a real disaster, we had to send it back. While prices were already expensive, there was a 13% tax AND a 10% extra service fee....More

At midday I am very much hungry and searched restaurants, I found café with rooftop area behind of the Patan Durbar Square. The service was very slow. We waste 1 hour and 45 minutes for food. Chicken Momo test was good but no chicken flavor...More

column7: Good food and nice view of durbar square
column8: My partner and I had lunch at the rooftop restaurant, which offered a really nice view of Patan Durbar Square. We ordered chicken curry, which tasted good. The owner of the restaurant also owns Temple House in Patan, so he offered us a discount for the meals. Overall experience was good.

column7: Everything too average but the price
column8: The food was absolutely the worst I have had in Nepal. Except for the location, everything else was below expectation. I was really disappointed with overall experience.

column7: Service was so bad we left before eating!
column8: Our most disappointing restaurant experience in Nepal- during a month long visit. We’re not that fussy even street momos & home made Raksi you buy in the villages make this place look like such a rort! The service was unbelievably slow, only to find much of he menu was also not available. When we agreed to order a bottle of the Nepali white wine (as none of their foreign varieties listed on menu were available)- They tried to sell us a bottle which was already open.... Goodness knows for how long? After waiting 45 mins for the cocktail my fiancé ordered only to find it undrinkable, we cut our losses, paid the bill and left as quickly as possible.

We went and sat at the terrace. There were some foreign guests as well. The waiter saw us and came up and went down 3/4 times to serve them but didn't attend us with the menu. We waited for about 15 minutes but still we were left unattended. External Tourists are valuable but there should be respect for internal tourist as well.

column7: Cafe du Temple overlooks the scaffolding on several nearby temples.
column8: Cafe du Temple overlooks the scaffolding on several nearby temples. They have a roof garden and they serve meals as well as tea and some local deserts. I had a cup of tea an interesting curd desert with a little bit of honey, seeds, and nuts.

We came in as a group of 5, expecting something unique given the pretty exterior. Below average food which we were then overcharged for. Didn't feel like the place was hygienic and we definitely do not recommend. Can see some OK views from the rooftop but not worth the bill.

column7: Great view of Durbar Square from the roof
column8: We had ring side seats and enjoyed a great view from our table. The restaurant caters entirely for tourisits but it does it very well. We enjoyed a decent lunch with good service in a unique place

column7: Come for the location, the food is just OK
column8: Cafe Du Temple is located right opposite Patan Durbar Square and its pretty much impossible to avoid getting a table that does not have a view on to it (unless you try really hard!). The food is OK, so don't come here if thats your priority. But being here at evening time and nursing a beer and some moms while the sun sets over Patan Durbar Square....well, lets just say that it is an amazing experience.

I enjoyed breakfast and lunch here. The masala eggs for breakfast were delicious as was the lemon ginger tea. For lunch I ordered a burger and it was very good. Setting is lovely, service attentive and there’s plenty of choice. Bar offers choice of drinks...More

I didn't have the pleasure of staying here, but I certainly would. And will if I get the chance. A small 10 roomed boutique hotel in Patan. Perfect. Lovingly restored with quality design. Know you're in Nepal in the best possible taste.

column7: Cute little place in perfect location for Patan
column8: Old beautiful building, super cute and with a nice vibe.  The location is excellent. You walk out and you are in Patan Square so for that area of the city it is ideal.  The room - we had a room up on 2nd floor looking into the courtyard. It was extremely spacious, nicely decorated, good shower and a unique style.  The staff - we didn't really interact with anybody too much but overall they were all very polite  Breakfast - very decent, ok coffee  I would definitely recommend for exploring Patan.  Tip: there is a nice organic restaurant just outside Patan Inn. Nice food and friendly staff

The Inn Patan is undoubtedly a hidden treasure of Patan. It is an example how local traditional house can be turned into a boutique Hotel.  As soon as we enter the Hotel gate, we felt that we are entering to local house but once we checked in to our room, we are amazed to see how beautifully the rooms are decorated with local touch yet blended with modern facilities.  The food and service are good. I liked the friendly staff.  We are more than happy to spend time in this hotel and highly recommend this hotel to check it out. I am sure that nobody wants to leave this place simply.  Keep it up the great work.

column7: Manny's brought tapas to Kathmandu - and it's a restaurant with a heart
column8: A lovely setting surrounded by trees, a great location, Manny's offers really delectable Thai dishes made by his chef who is passionate about trying new things. The special tofu dish is not to be missed while the cocktails are made with a real expert touch...More

I have eaten at Manny's numbers of times over the past few years when in Kathmandu and every experience has been great. The food is great with good diversity including local delicacies and more western options and the staff is extremely courteous and friendly. I...More

column7: Excellent food and ambiance. Great place to have business meetings, reunions with friends or breakfast/lunch/dinner.
column8: The option of inside or outside dining, varied and interesting menu, excellent service, and good location with parking make Manny's a great place to go. If you are staying at the Shaligram it is perfect and even provides room service! Plus there are foot stomping...More

UNESCO had designated three (3) town squares in Nepal as World Heritage Sites (Cultural): (1) Kathmandu Durbar Square, (2) Bhaktapur Durbar Square and (3) Patan Durbar Square - all three of these Squares are must see places while traveling through Nepal and they are all different in their own way. The Patan Durbar Square has many distinctive and interesting temples and structures: Krishna Temple, Royal Palace Patan, Jagannarayan Temple, Keshav Narayan Temple, Char Naarayan Temple, Golden Temple and others. When we had visited Patan Durbar Square on November 2019, we found most all of the structures here had been either not affected by the 2015 earthquake or were repaired quickly - we saw only a couple of structures that were being "repaired". This is in contrast to the Kathmandu Durbar Square which had multiple structures that are still in need of earthquake damage repair when we had visited that location. In summary, the Patan Durbar Square is in excellent shape - almost all the structures show no earthquake damage and the whole area is visually quite stunning as you enter the Square. The Ancient Nepal architecture here at the Square looks very impressive and makes for good photography. Highly recommend seeing the Patan Durbar Square, and if you have time walk down through some of the side streets to see the residential areas that surrounds the Square - interesting!

column7: Don't miss this when visiting Kathmandu
column8: I would highly recommend to get a guide for this tout as there is so much interesting history associated with this site. Truly wonderful examples of Patan's heritage of wood carving.

column7: Large area with much under renovation and restoration
column8: Busy area at front of square, once ticket purchased and through chain fence it becomes less noisy. Plenty of Pidgeon’s on the roofs of temples and a few cows roaming around. Maybe better signage that told what is happening in different locations as in whether it’s being restored or repaired after earthquake. We came to an exit point but weren’t allowed to exit there but had to back track through building restoration area where there are hard hat signs and planks of wood as ramps - serious trip and hazard issues! Interesting to see. There were markets happening at the exit end as it was Sunday.

column7: Not to miss but crowded on the outside.
column8: We arrive in KTM today and our first stop was Patan Durbar Square. A not to miss place in KTM as it displays the history in Buddhism and Hinduism however, the square is to crowded which makes less interesting. The temple outside was full of people even sitting on the temple itself. Too much construction going on.

Patan was damaged less than Kathmandu’s Durbur Sq in the earthquake so the ability to experience the location was better even if KTM seemed a bit bigger. Lots of neat buildings and temples to view and visit.
What a pity the earthquake damaged so much of this lovely area.The history of the area is amazing.Long way to go in the rebuilding process.

When we were dropped off at Patan Durbar Square we were immediately gathered up by a tour guide named Sorros as soon as our feet hit the pavement. They will show you where the entrance is and tell you how much you need to pay which incidentally was 1000 Nepalese Rupee each. They generally have a tour guide license. After I asked he said a tour would cost 1000 Nepalese Rupee each and a tip is expected. At least they are upfront about the costs so it’s always fair. One of the temples in Patan Durbar Square (the Golden Temple) had a cost of 100 Nepalese Rupee each, bringing the total cost to 3200 Nepalese Rupee for two people, excluding the tip. Our guide took us to a place where they showed us healing/singing bowls. They put the bowl on your head and strike it gently with what looks like a rubber mallet which creates a soothing massaging effect. They also put the bowl on your back and do much the same. They also put water in the bowl and roll the rubber mallet around the edge and the water jumps up like a fountain because of the vibration. “It’s magic!” I said to the vendor. “No, it’s just physics,” he responded. We were at Patan Durbar Square from about 9:15am to 10:30am.
Many beautiful historic buildings and temples to see. An interesting view of this old city. Worth a visit.

Being an old area, Patan Durbar Square is an extremely interesting historic square with many temples including the three-tiered Krishna Mandir Temple plus other buildings. On one side of the square is the former royal palace which dates from1734 and is nor a museum. It is also interesting to wander up some of the narrow streets leading off the square where there are shops and homes.
