A must-see place. Despite the fact there was much repair work in progress, the beauty of the place is unique. After completing your tour, take some time to enjoy a coffee at the top roof of the restaurant/cafe on the square and have views from the top.

There are several different Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu area. I choose to visit this square as it is listed in the Lonely Planet's Ultimate travelist. It is 1000 NPR for a foreigner to visit the square and that includes the Patan Museum.  This square experienced a lot of damage due to the earthquake of 2015 and it is still being worked on. The buildings are very interesting and I especially liked the Patan Museum.  We would have gotten more from seeing this square if we had used a guide. However, the local guides were asking too much so we went without one.

column7: Extensive damage here from the earthquake but still worth a visit
column8: This is a nice square despite the earthquake damage. Our guide spent a lot of time telling us about the reconstruction, and it appears that it is going well and will look as it did before the earthquake when finished. Almost every building is propped up with huge boards to stabilize them, and large cracks are seen everywhere.  There are still plenty of beautiful carvings to see on the buildings and carved stone figures and statues throughout. We went to visit the house of the Kumari Devi (the Living Goddess). We could not go in but were allowed in the courtyard to see if she would make an appearance at a window. No photos allowed if she appeared. She did appear and looked out at everyone. This goddess is a 5 year old girl who lives apart from her family until she reaches puberty. It was quite an interesting story.  Worth a visit even though some people complained about the entrance fee. The entrance fee is worth it if this trip is something that you will probably never do again, so why not?
the square and surrounding area suffered immensely from the 2015 earthquake it is slowly being restored but it still has a unique atmosphere with the little stalls and the lovely people

column7: Patan Museum is a Big Plus
column8: They say that the Patan Durbar Square is the best of all three in Nepal and after visiting the outskirts of the Kathmandu Durbar Square, I would be inclined to agree (can't completely do so since I haven't been to Bhaktapur.) I didn't enter Kathmandu Durbar Square cause of the expensive entrance fee but it seemed in complete disarray and didn't think there would be much to see.  The Patan Durbar Square also has a lot of rehabilitation going on but it's not as tight and stressful to get into as the Kathmandu one. There's a lot more space to move around and most of the main building has been preserved.  A huge plus about going to Patan Durbar Square is that it houses the Patan Museum, which is easily the best museum I've been to in Nepal. It was very informative and described facts about Hindi and Buddhist history, iconography, symbolisms, and belief systems. I really appreciated that. Because of this, you wouldn't need a tour guide anymore.  Some groups got a tour guide and they sometimes spoke loudly to be heard. Because of that, I would get some interesting new information at random and that was a nice little surprise.  I highly recommend going to this place!

column7: Beautiful historical site severely earthquake damaged.
column8: From previous pictures the Durbar Square is a mere shadow of its former glory. International tourists are ticketed at R1000 entry, which in part goes towards the extensive rebuilding required as large parts of the square are currently being rebuilt. Expect lots of bracing of the temples and areas under significant reconstruction, supported largely by foreign aid. There is extensive earthquake damage to masonry and timber features, and yet still makes for a fascinating visit. Expect to get pretty harangued by hawkers in the area, they are polite and will generally leave you alone after the first “no” but it does detract from observing what is clearly still a functioning religious site. There are guides that hang around the entry that can walk you round but it’s probably easier to forego that and just experience the area.

The Durbar square in still under repair after earthquake but there is still plenty to see and photograph. Also interesting to observe how locals do the hard work one brick at a time and women mixing cement with their bare feet...

After visiting all three Durbar Squares, Patan, Kathmandu and Bhaktapur, this was certainly the nicest out of the three. We had a local guide that was organized for us through Global Holidays (also, highly recommended) and he was very helpful in guiding us through the square and telling us the stories and history of the place.  The old palace is amazing, and has been turned into a very informative museum. The detail in the wood carving is ridiculous! It must have taken many hours of work to do all of the fine etching that is evident. The details are incredible. The Newari architecture is very interesting and picturesque.  The area was hit by the earthquake and is still evident, but much of the restoration has already been started, The 1000 Ru entry fee is well worth it, especially if part of the money helps the locals restore the site (which is all being done by hand). Definitely worth seeing.

column7: The whole area, museum and buildings included, are fantastic
column8: I enjoyed Patan Durbar square much more than Kathmandu's. There seem to be more buildings you can go in and look around all while being much less crowded. It is much more relaxed than in Kathmandu and seems cleaner as well.

There are a lot of activities to reconstruct the city after the 2015 earthquake but walking around the city one can appreciate the mystical atmosphere of Patan. Start your walks from the Durbar and get a bit lost to appreciate the many beauties of the city and the central area. Absolutely not to miss in a tour of the Kathmandu valley.
We visited all three Durbars' during our visit. This Durbar was very advanced as far as reconstruction and information for tourists goes! Worth the visit! Very interesting.
It is very interesting and beautiful place, wonderful for Europeans and Russians! Don't be fast and enjoy archetecture long time!

Many temples and interesting things to see in the museum. Sadly there is a lot of damage from the earthquake which is sad to see but you can see the restoration work being completed and there is an informative exhibition detailing the earthquake and rebuilding of the square. Tourist price is quite high but you can get multiple visits with it for the duration of your visa. Definitely worth visiting while in Kathmandu .

Super cool to learn about history in the square and in the nearby museum. Marvel's movie Doctor Strange was filmed here! Definitely full of tourists. You could do this site by yourself, we went as part of a tour with a guide and felt like we were herded through a bit. Most of the museum is in English so you can read all the wall text without help.

It is the best representation of Nepalese art and architecture. It is very interesting ancient temple represent world heritage site. There are very interesting art about god and goddess. Some of the common monuments are Krishna Mandir, Patan durbar square, Mahabouddha, Hiranya Verna Mahavihar, Kumlwshwor.
This square is worth visiting for the different temples. Visited in November and weather was great and not too crowded.

The ancient city of Patan .  Patan is situated in Lalitpur ,a town ,a few Kms from Kathmandu. Known for beautiful palaces and temples side by side ,it's a UNESCO World heritage site. Interesting mix of Hinduism and Buddhism ,it has 136 courtyards and 55 temples of various Gods of Hinduism and incarnates of Buddhism . The Krishna temple is most important one in this complex . Built in 16th century by the Malla king ,it has three stories and temple of Radha Krishna on 1st floor , Siva on the second and Buddha on the third . Unfortunately , in the 2015 earthquake ,it was badly damaged , and is being renovated now . Bhimsen temple was built by Srinivasa Malla in 1680. It is renowned for its three interconnected golden windows. Bhimsen is a great hero in Mahabharata. He was known to be very brave and strong. In Newa tradition, he is worshipped as a god of business and trade. (Wikipedia) The three main courtyards in the palace are Mul Chok, Sundari Chok and Keshav Narayan Chok. Besides these courtyards, the complex boasts impressive temples, religious shrines, and historical places, all noted for their exquisite carvings and beautiful display of ancient Newari architecture (Wikipedia) Hiraṇyavarṇa Mahāvihāra (Nepali: हिरण्यवर्ण महाविहार), also Kwa Bahal (Nepali: क्वबहा:) informally called The Golden Temple with literal meaning "Gold-colored Great Monastery" is a historical vihara (Buddhist monastery) situated in Patan, Nepal. It is known locally as the "Golden Temple" and it is famous for feeding rats. This three-storey golden pagoda of Shakyamuni Buddha was built in the twelfth century by King Bhaskar Varman. Inside the upper storey of the pagoda is the golden image and a large prayer wheel.(Wikipedia)

column7: Most Beautiful Durbar Square in Kathmandu Valley
column8: I immensly enjoyed our privately guided tour to Patan: the Durbar Square is at leas as impressive and interesting as the Kathmandu and Baktapur one. It felt cleaner in comparison though, which might make it a better start for European tourists.
History is embedded deep within Kathmandu and the people interact with it daily in many ways. This is a good place to learn about Nepal and its history as well as how people interact today.

column7: Too expensive for the amount of restoration going on.
column8: Yes it is an interesting place to visit but all five people in our group felt that the entry fee was quite expensive for the amount of intact buildings standing. We could however clearly see that real effort is being made in this area to restore all affected buildings.

Admission 1,000r. Much more intact than Kathmandu’s Durbar Square, more interesting, with far fewer trinket sellers in the main area. There is also included in the admission cost a very interesting museum including depictions of various deities. We were approached by a guide who offered his services for 2,000r, we declined this offer.

We stayed in Patan for two nights. The square is still being rebuilt from the earthquake in 2015 and there is still a lot of work left, still very interesting. Durbar Square in Bhaktapur is in much better condition.

Great place to visit. Unfortunately there was a lot of reconstruction work going on after the earthquake a couple of years ago. Didn’t need a guide as easy to find way around. Great bars nearby with views of the square the museum is also interesting place to visit.

This square was damaged in the last earthquake but they are in the process of rebuilding and there is still a lot to see. We spent a whole day exploring the square and it's buildings. The museum is well worth the time and there are far fewer tourists and vendors hawking their wares here then in Kathmandu's Durbar Square. I was very pleased to have chosen Patan as our point of entry to Nepal particularly because this square was so interesting to visit.

We visited from 10.00am so it was nice and quiet peaceful and enchanting. The architecture is stunning, dates from several periods in history and reflects the melting pot of faith in this city. Truly beautiful ornate buildings, pools and sculptures of Hindu/Buddhist gods. As some of the structures were damaged in the earthquake and are being repaired you can see the stored pillared up close inside the first building. Uniquely beautiful. A lovely shaded restaurant serves refreshments including light lunch in the third building. Nearby there is a very good shop where you can see ringing bowls demonstrated for aligning chackra. No pressure to buy at all. Carry on 50m past the third temple building, left hand side of street.

Like other previous reviews, we had a great time exploring culture, architectural and historical features at Patan Durbar Square. We spend almost 4 hours wandering around the area to appreciate the beauty of it until we accidentally witness a religious ceremony that perform by locals inside the temple: they behead a baby buffalo( sacrificing to some Gods). Unprepared for what was going on back then,we were in shock and the image of them pulling the next buffalo up to be beheaded(while the poor buffalo clearly shivering and hesitated to walk ahead) more or less kill the mood for the rest of the day. We were out of that temple right after seconds comprehending what was going on,very upset.  We respect the local culture and religious belief but just for the experience: if you don't want to see unexpected slaughter,as soon as you see animals (buffaloes , goats,etc at their unusual residence) +some kind of rituals going on+a crowd around it,don't look and walk away,we are sure there are lot of other ways to experience Nepal than witnessing some animals slaughtered.

I loved this place. Very typical Nepali architecture and symbolic of its tradition and the rich cultural legacy. A walk around the durbar is really awesome. And it is great to see so many people in the area still on to their ancestral trade. I went to a small restaurant in the area and had a traditional Nepali meal. The owner claimed that his family has been running the restaurant for more than 300 years. Amazing.  This place is a visual treat. I would recommend all tourists to visit this place.
Amazing to see and experience the cultural marvels that have withstood time and earthquakes.  Definite picture worthy moments!

The site is recovering from the 2015 earthquake. The majestic beauty must be rebuilt which takes time. There are a number of before and after pictures but you will need to come back post reconstruction to appreciate it's grander.

I been this city with my girl friend.i felt incredible here with amazing and historical art of these temple ,museum and the houses surrounding here ,when you go go there just take a tour guide who tell you tell to interesting history of this city.

The Patan Durbar Square was very nice! A taxi from the Thamel tourist area should cost you around 250 rupees- don't give in to drivers who are asking for more (I had a man ask for 900 rupees!)! If you are looking between the Kathmandu Durbar Square or the Patan Durbar Square, the one in Patan is in better shape with more to see. There is also a very interesting museum that you can go in to see more information about post-earthquake restoration efforts and different religious symbols. I definitely recommend going to the Patan Durbar Square if you can.

We were dropped by taxi in the middle of the square (unbeknownst to us), and were surprised that after paying for a ticket (having been noticed by a security guard) that we had already seen all the main sights.  Let's be honest here. Patan's Durbar Square is a shadow of its former grandeur, and every structure is largely hidden under extensive scaffolding. The Museum (which is part of your 1,000rp ticket) only had 1/8th of its exhibition space open for public use, with the rest being refurbished/repaired.  My partner and I are empathetic with the earthquake repair process, and are happy considering our payment there as a donation. However, it is disingenuous (and honestly somewhat manipulative) to pretend otherwise.  The very high price of entry is a donation towards mending the damage of the earthquake, and should not be taken as indicative of the quality of the experience in Patan's Durbar Square.  Left feeling quite deflated and disappointed.

We went there and guards quickly came to us even tho we wasnt even in yet. 1000 rupees would be ok price for tourists if that money goes directly to repairing those temples. Also there was only one temple what wasnt covered with repairing tools and stuff. The most interesting thing there was couple of hawks who tried to catch pidgeons. Damn those are excellent flyers! But visiting worth of 1000NPR if temples arent broken.

column7: A hub of activity and history
column8: So close to Kathmandu itself, Patan's Durbar Square presents a more manageable, rich cultural experience. The streets are busy and definitely touristy, but strike a balance between commerce and history and culture.

I Went to patan Durbar Square with some friends.. visited there after almost 5 years..many things has changed especially post earthquake... However, the historical significance of Durbar Square is still there... Firstly, streets were lively, full of people... and the monuments were beautiful.. I was there for around 3-4 hours... we roamed around and finally ate in a typical Newari restaurant... the food was amazing.... Secondly, the shops around patan are not expensive at all... whether it is about good food or nice clothes, patan gives you the best at best prices!!! In the evening we saw the “arati” of lord Krishna in the Krishna Temple... that was very soothing...Though I was there for few hours,my overall experience here was amazing :)
Beautiful historic place with beautiful temple and pure Newari Culture. Wood work on the temple are very unique and creative. Its a must visit place if you are in Kathmandu.

Visit Patan is a special experience. The central square is interesting, full of magnificent buildings, temples, shops and always a lot of people. It is located 5 km south of central Kathmandu, across the Bagmati River. Like everything in Nepal and this city has a rich history. Patan is founded in the 3rd century A.D by King Veera Dev. Durbar Square is enriched by the magnificent ancient Royal Palace. The monuments in this square date back to the Medieval Malla period from 16th to 18th century. Bhimsen Temple, Vishwa Nath Temple, Temple Jagnath leave visitors breathless.

Interesting to see the ongoing restoration work, not hurried but focused on getting it right. Still a lot to see and not many western tourists, we felt very safe walking around on our own and stayed at The Inn Patan in the area for a total of four nights. After 10 nights touring Nepal we bought our souvenirs at a little shop just off Swotha street, cheaper than anywhere else.

Patan Durbar Square suffered enormous earthquake damage. However, it is quite interesting to see the reconstruction efforts and the resilience of the local people. It’s amazing to see some things which were not affected by the earthquake and marvel at how they survived it. Definitely worth a visit, even if it’s not as majestic as it once was. It looks like it will be rebuilt to it’s former glory eventually.

Dubar Square in Patan is a high light of touristic attractions. Several old monuments are assembled in this square. It is like a museum village, and you might feel as if the time stopped forever. Some monuments were damaged by an earthquake, and the repair work is currently undertaken.

Durbar square has a lovely ambiance, and the restoration after the earthquake is under way. The fret work and wooden pavilions are beautiful and intricate. Small shops and handicrafts are typically priced for tourists but some of the women selling trinkets around the square have lovely items for sale. Perhaps the most interesting part of the visit was the walk through the old town, where you can see the real day-to-day lives of Nepalis and even taste some famous (and delicious) yoghurt typical to the region.

In 2017 foreigners have to pay 250 for SAARC member countries and 1000 for non SAARC member countries. Glad too see there's a tourist Police office. I enjoyed walking around the alley ways that surround the square. I remember the place used to be cleaner back in 1987 and there were more old houses

every town in Nepal has a Durbar square the one of Patan is my favourite even if with a lot of signs of erathquake Not too much big but really interesting to visit and walk around  In the night become magic  U can find everything you want, restaurant, cafes and souvenirs shops

column7: A Square full of ancient monuments, Temples and chowks in The old Royal Palace
column8: Patan Durbar Square is even more interesting than Kathmandu Durbar Square. Also here there are damages from The earthquacke in 2015, but The Royal Palace with The 3 beautiful courtyards (chowks), and the Patan museum still stands, and the restoration of the area is in progress, so all the Temples Will be rebuild.  The Square is in centrum of Patan, and "runs" in an acks from north to South. And this Durbar Square is without influenze from Europe, (The two other Durbar Square Borth have a little European arcitecture also).
Beautifull temples and a amazing building with a very nice museum worth to be visited. Close by there is an interesting square, the pottery one.
Fun experience for a taste of traditional Nepal. Good shopping options & friendly locals. Tasty eatery snacks & coffee along the way

The place is still under renovation but its charm and historic vibe can be felt in the area. Be prepared to pay around 1000 NPR for foreigners. Tour guides are all over the place if you want to avail one.
I am so happy to be a part of history by being amongst the people and the history behind these marvelous historical structures. One just needs to visit to appreciate.

column7: Full of history, but also full of ...
column8: I had a wonderful guide with me to visit Durbar Square. Still I found it a challenge to fully fall in love with this site. The temples are interesting, but after earth quake, the buildings are in rather poor condition and are crying for a proper restoration.  I am also scared by a massive group of pigeons. You can feed them with corns and there are quite a few vendors at the square. But pigeons are not good for the buildings and temples at the square.

I enjoyed our tour of the square, despite the mixed reviews. My friend and I purchased our tickets with ease from a ticket box and were approached by a number of guides. The guide we chose was wonderful, previously a trekking guide for 13 years. Ask the guides questions before you accept their service, sight their certification if they claim to be certified, and agree on a price. We paid 1500 NPR ($20 AUD) and felt this was a fair price. We saw the Living Goddess when she came to her window and learned all about the culture and religion of the Nepalese. It would be a shame to travel to Kathmandu without visiting the square.

This is the third Durbar we saw in Kathmandu. Each was a bit different. This had great examples of temples and building destroyed by the earthquake - you could see the rebuilding and what everything looked like before the damage. This was also the least dusty of the three. It also housed the Patan Museum which is a must-see in my book.

column7: Interesting Place but now being rebuilt
column8: The Durbar square proclaims the history of Kathmandu but the place is being rebuilt and so is dusty( like the rest of the town). Good place to walk around and observe the Nepali heritage and the damage the earthquake did.

This is an interesting area to walk around and watch people. After I visited here I found out you're supposed to pay to get in but I hadn't noticed the booths and no one had challenged me. I had to walk through here to get to my hotel anyway. Quite a bit of construction going on.
It's a touristic place but still authentic. Very interesting to walk all around and take time to explore every single corner.

column7: Absorbing and interesting - better than Kathmandu
column8: A more relaxing and interesting experience than Kathmandu Durbar square (not that that isn't enjoyable). The Museum on the Square especially is interesting and highly recommended, as is the Yala Layeku restaurant which overlooks the square. An interesting and absorbing experience (though at 1000R you'd hope it was!)

column7: The architecture is heavy into details
column8: Very nice architecture, much to be appreciated. A little quieter than other areas of Nepal. So many of the highlights are so close together. Good to have a local guide at least for a brief overview. Happened upon a small area of outdoor market with mostly women selling trinkets, jewelry etc. I was in my glory. Found a few very interesting pieces of jewelry, old and new.

column7: Better than Durbar Square in Kathmandu
column8: Less crowded, with plenty to see. I enjoyed buying from the market, wandering through the temples and backstreets, and eating the local food.

Spending nine days in Kathmandu while husband is at a conference here. Am taking half day tours to various cities and venues. Today I visited Durbar Square in Patan, not far from Kathmandu. My guide asked me "Do you want to see a living goddess?" I replied " You mean The Kumari?" He said "You know The Kumari" and I explained that I studied the Nepali tradition of worshipping living goddesses. We went to the home she lives in with her family. My guide said to wait as he would see if she was sleeping. She saw me. What a thrill! The living goddess is seven years old and two years into her "reign" and she appeared to be stoic, fearless, and very very special. She gave me a blessing and I asked for blessings for some docent friends who would appreciate the gesture. The Kumari then rubbed a red paste pigment on my forehead. I placed a small donation on her large tray near her throne. I have great respect for cultural traditions that do not harm people. Durbar Square is worth seeing. Many cities in Nepal have a square called Durbar Square in which a former palace was built. Most of the palaces in this region were damaged in,and restored after, the earthquake of 2015. Many countries and charities donated to the efforts and it is remarkable how quickly buildings were restored. Stroll through the side paths of the square, get "lost" alone or with a guide, see chickens, people working, people making food, embroidering cloths, eat at a local place to taste their cuisine, TALK to the people, at least try. Students like to practice their English with tourists. Yes, as others have noted, pay the 1000 or 1500 rupees entrance fee to these UNESCO sites and take it all in. They are worth every rupee!

I saw Durbar Square in Kathmandu prior to coming to this one just south of Kathmandu, and this one is much better. When I was there I saw people that were at work rebuilding the towers and statues. It was a better experience than in Kathmandu.
museum very interesting damage from earthquake very visible interesting shops and very crowded be careful and buy face mask for extreme pollution

It’s 1000 Nepalese Rupees to be able to take a look in and around the temples. You must pay at the Kiosk at the front otherwise Guards will direct you to purchase a pass. This is helping to re build some of the temples due the destruction of the earthquake in 2015. You will be approached by a tour guide and this is also at an additional cost. I visited The Golden Temple but luckily this was not effected in the earthquake and is very beautiful. Also be careful that there are Nepalese people around to take your money from you if they start showing you around the Temple! There is also another cost to enter! Interesting visit.

I enjoyed exploring Patan Durbar Square on my own, without a guide, admiring the buildings, architecture, art, carvings and restoration. The fee to enter for out-of-country visitors was about $10 when I visited, which seems high for Nepal, but felt like a worthwhile contribution to help with the much-needed repair work. I also enjoyed the gardens and seeing the lovely restaurant/cafe in the Patan Museum which you could enter without the additional museum fee.

We enjoyed our visit to Patan Durban Square, the carvings were amazing so intricate, the museum whilst small had some interesting pieces. We then spent sometime wandering the streets many of the shops were selling bronze pieces.

There is very little to see, only two courtyards, as the rest is under restoration. There are no entry signs everywhere. You can't go into any building or near any temples.  A complete waste of money.  The Nepalese government should be ashamed of themselves for what they are charging, 1000nrp. They think they have something special here then they should explore the rest of the world a little.  The surrounding area is more interesting and free to see.
I had two local students with me so my day was wonderful. they were able to explain so much to me. Be sure to tour the palace grounds also. Lots of pigeons!

column7: not on my must do list
column8: We had already visited the other 2 Durbar squares in Kathmandu and what we could see of the Patan square, we could not justify paying the 1000IR entrance fee.  Sadly, most of the temples/stupas were destroyed or badly damaged by the 25/4/15 earthquake. Little restoration has commenced since the earthquake.  I can appreciate that the reconstruction has to be paid by someone, however, 500IR would be a more appropriate entrance fee given the current condition.

Patan Darbar Square is listed on the World Heritage Site. There are many Pagoda style temples and visit to inner court , with a wide array of stone and wood craving is stunningly beautiful. One of the remarkable monuments in Patan Durbar square is a 17th century temple dedicated to the Hindu God Krishna. The temple is built entirely on stone. Visit to inner bahal and courtyard gives you a wonderful experience to see the daily life of its inhabitants.
Culture and religious center with many centuries old buildings which reflect unique architectural features like intricately carved teak wood panels and elaborate doors posts.

Patan Durbar Square is more compact and quaint than the main square of Kathmandu. The temples are in varying states of repair post earthquake but the general sense of the place is intact and the museum interesting, the surrounding streets narrow and full of life.

We gladly paid the entrance fee and then we were worked by a local guide and finally caved. He was knowledgable and this did enhance our experience but then we found ourselves at "the singing bowl guy" and "the mandala guy", although this may be true, both had prices well above anywhere else. The area of historical interest is actually quite small. It wasn't as spectacular as I had imagined.

column7: Beautiful area you don't want to miss!
column8: We went to Durbar on an afternoon tour with a private guide. This area was damaged less by the earthquake than other areas but still has some damage that is currently being repaired. Very beautiful square with much history. The museum cost $10 to enter but the money goes to supporting the rebuilding efforts. Some interesting items in the museum plus you get to see the inside of the palaces. Very much worth seeing.

Having been to Durbar square in Bhaktapur and in Katmandu we were disappointed with Durbar square in Patan. There were fewer temples and many of them were not accessible due to renovations and rebuilding after the 2015 earthquake. We went through the Patan museum which was interesting, but I would definitely choose to spend my 1000 rupee entrance fee at one of the other Durbar squares.

column7: Don't leave out this square in your itinerary
column8: The square is full of temples with a very long and interesting history. It is in desperate need of restoration after the 2015 earthquake.

column7: Better than the Durbar Square near Thamel
column8: I enjoyed this one more than the Durbar square near Thamel - also there's some good restaurants with rooftop views over Patan Durbar Square.
Durber Central is a cacophony of activity. Ot can be very overwhelming so prepare yourself. But it is something one should experience when in Kathmandu.

column7: Still to recover from the earthquake but a lovely place
column8: We greatly enjoyed Patan and its Durbar square. It is well kept, with a sacred temple every meter basically. All very interesting, even though not all allow entry to non-Hindus. Sadly, the place was also quite badly hit from the earthquake and this is still visible around the square. Hopefully, the entrance fee will somehow help its quicker recovery. In all cases, it is still very much worth a visit. Make sure to also walk around the square, into the market streets and experience the place to its fullest.
Really interesting, lots of see, the price is a bit high but it's worth it. Very enjoyable time spent here.
I went with a guide to this square. Most interesting although quite a bit of damage to the structures from the earthquake. Well worth a trip. Some nice restaurants with rooftop views nearby.
It should a must visit place in your Kathmandu itinerary. A lot of damage has been done during earth quake. Campus had got many lot of thing each having its unique history. Better to have a guide

column7: Must not miss when in Kathmandu
column8: It takes 20 minutes from Thamel to get to Darbar Square. I suggest you go with a guide because there is so much history in this place. From the Kumari Ghar to the Royal Palace, each temple or landmark has its unique story. The major repairs post-earthquake are well under way. This is definitely a place not to be missed as it is a beautiful mix of pan-Asian architecture and art. We will definitely have to come back to see the hippie temple where Jimmy Hendrix used to hang out at. The re-construction has not started.

Patan is an ancient historical place located in Lalitpur city, 30 minutes far from Kathmandu.It is a beautiful place listed in world heritage sites by UNESCO. This site is very much rich in Hindu temples & monuments which are wonderfully carved with stones, the beautiful fine arts, & ornate architecture. The visitors can enjoy the scenic view of area, Krishna temple, golden temple, mahabouddha temple, Golden window, Patan Museum, Bhimsen temple, are the major attraction of this place. More Newar peoples are the resident of this area so, it is rich in Newari culture, and visitors can also enjoy the taste of Newari street food. Overall Patan is beautiful area with lots of things to view around in a peaceful & calm area.The eartquake hitted some parts of Patan but not all, it is still worth to visit.

It was an interesting visit to say the least. You get to see some very impressive historical places in the middle of the hussles and bustles of daily life. The striking thing for anyone visiting is the state of some of the buildings a year after the earthquake which does put things into perspective. One piece of advice - unless your from south Asia I wouldn't advice you to visit during the summer because it can get really hot and humid!

column7: By Going Now - you support post-earthquake restoration
column8: Nepal's massive earthquake and aftershock was one year-ago. The is the perfect time to visit Kathmandu and the nearby, world heritage site of the old city centre of Patan's, Durbar Square. A trip there is now especially gratifying, as the local economy is heavily dependent on tourism, which has significantly fallen from pre-earthquake days. From Kathmandu, it is an easy, thirty minute taxi ride to this living museum. While there is evidence of earthquake damage, most of the splendid buildings remain intact. There is a palpable vibrancy and optimism that adds to the energy of the place. Walking amidst the magnificently carved ancient wooden temples is a powerful experience. The very impressive Patan Museum in the historic town centre is not be missed. (And the delicious veggie momos in the museum's terrace café make for a splendid break!)

column7: Extraordinary mix of the everyday and the religious
column8: How do these places get to be built all together? Its a great experience to see the skills that have gone into this jumble of buildings and watch the passers by go through.

column7: Durbar Square Patan so sad but still plenty to see.
column8: Although Durbar Square in Patan is a shadow of it former self (5 temples gone) there are still reasons to visit, perhaps the first is just to realise just what we have lost. Sitting somewhere like the rooftop of Cafe Du Temple it is easy to imagine what this square looked like hundreds of years ago, if you get the chance stay a little later or even the night so you can experience it when it's a little quieter. The entrance fee is 500R for a day visit, if you plan to spend more than a day, take your passport and have Visa expiry date written on the back of your ticket so you can visit again.
Interesting visit. Some damage from the 2015 earthquake, so pay the visitors fee with a smile that you are contributing to its restoration.

column7: Amazing square with so much history
column8: Patan really is well worth the short 20 minute drive from the centre of Kathmandu. Although damaged by the 2015 earthquake many buildings and monuments are still intact and have their own unique story to tell. The atmosphere was relaxed and peaceful and we were able to wander around and enjoy the sights. Only negative is that some of the debris from the earthquake is still scattered around and could be cleared up.
Its easier to get an overview of the temples, but overall I felt it was less lively and interesting than durbar square in kathmandu. The streets around with the workshops are worth some of your time.

column7: Very badly impacted by the Earthquakes
column8: A quaint and interesting place located in the city centre. Full of locals and tourists. Unfortunately the earthquake has had a significant impact and some of the buildings are no longer, some partly damaged and most in need of repair.  A good tip is to check out one of the rooftop cafe's and enjoy a meal or drink. The views from the Little Door Café were well enjoyed by myself and the tour group.

I paid NPR 1000 (around USD 10) for the entrance fee, it was a bit expensive for me. Here you can find very nice heritage from the former kingdom of Nepal. The management authority was struggling hard to renovate most of the building there which impacted by the earthquake in 2015. It was one of the tourist spot in Kathmandu. it was a good experience for me.

I was here in October/November 2015. Different than the squares in Kathmandu and Bakhtapur, the Durbar Square of Lalitpur hardly shows any signs of the destruction anymore, rubble has been removed and buildings are being rebuilt. The super interesting Patan Museum and its nice (and a little expensive) garden café was open (apart from a few, destroyed parts of the building everything was accessible) and the square is less busy than its two counterparts in the valley. It is a great place to hang out, stroll around and witness everyday life in Nepal. Across the street, above the market stalls and up a narrow staircase, there is an amazing café/restaurant (sadly, I don't remember the name) with the most beautiful woodcarved windows, through which you can watch the square and its inhabitants while enjoying a plate of momos and a cup of sweet chia. You'll have a great view of the central Vishnu temple and the Garud statue, as well as most of the old palace, which is now the Patan Museum.
We did hire a guide and I'm glad we did as he told us a lot more history than we would have known otherwise. We did end up in the obligatory singing bowl display but it was worth a laugh.

The main attraction of the city and it does not disappoint. Can be busy during the day but is a bit more calm in the morning. 7:30 am seems to be a good time to go.  Be wary of guides peddling their services to you.

column7: Patan Durbar is a main attraction in Kathmandu Valley
column8: This Durbar consists of various pagodas (two of them damaged by the earthquake of 2015) and stone temples. Entering from the main gate, on the right Hand side there is the mighty King's Palace, which includes a rewarding Museum at his end. The place lives, locals are coming and going, children play and foreigners admire the beauty of the unique Newar architecture. Entry fee is asked for at the gate.

Lalitpur means "City of Beauty" and there were lots of beautiful buildings. The square was also very peaceful. Our guide gave us a fair bit of free time here and it was nice to sit and relax with the locals and watch the world go by. Our guide took us to a building where many were killed during the earthquake. He had been there 30 minutes prior. His own house was destroyed but he said that he was blessed as no one from his family was injured in any way. Houses will eventually be rebuilt. Our visit to the "singing bowl master" was interesting but he seemed to expect a purchase for about £100 for a large bowl. I offered a tip of about £2 for his time and it was declined almost as insult. Elsewhere tips were most graciously received.

column7: Beautiful artistic city... Should be included in your trip!
column8: It is a twin city of Kathmandu but much less crowded... Definitely visit if you have an extra day in kathmandu. We book a tour through our hotel concierge of total $100 for our group. It is a short drive from Kathmandu.  There are many shops in the area. The square did have some damage from the April earthquake but overall it is in pretty good shape comparing to Dubar square in Kathmandu.  The art museum is located in the royal palace. We did have time to visit. The golden temple is within walking distance from the main square. Here, you can take picture of the young priest watching over the temple.  From there, we walked to the Inn of Patan for lunch. The place is very beautiful with spot clean western bathrooms.  We visit the meditation center located in the square to learn about their meditated bowls...  I would definitely come back and spend more time here next trip to Nepal.

Patan Darbar Square is situated in the heart of Lalitpur, Mangal Bazar. There are a lot many tour places near by,i.e Patan Musium, Krishna Mandir,achyasin Dewal and manyother historic places where people keep interest to have experiences. Furthermore within 5 minute walking distance we can reach Hiranyabarna Mahadihar, the Golden Temple of Gautam Budha. Irecommend people to have heavenly experience.

Ok there is a fuel crisis and I had to pay 1600 rupees to get from centre of Kathmandu to patan in a taxi but otherwise it's free to wander around patan square. I made the mistake of hiring a guide which for 1000 rupees wasn't worth it- he was nice and showed me where the golden temple was (just off the square) and getting in the museum (through the golden door). He told me about the buildings in the square and their significance and what had been lost in the earthquake (only 2 pagodas so not much) but in hindsight I didn't need to pay for someone to show me round. Tip- do pay 400 rupees to go in the museum through the golden door- it's worth every penny to learn about Hinduism and Buddhism and see lots of statues.

column7: Not a good time to visit
column8: Because of the earthquake, there is heavy damage and some construction. The poles holding up the temple and other buildings make it hard to get around. Surely this was spectacular before the earthquake. Now, not so much.

We went to Durbar square near the end of our two week trip to the Kathmandu Valley. Though I didn't begrudge having to pay 500 NPR to gain entry as a foreigner per se, I was disappointed that by going around the back of the square you basically got the same experience for free. The other think I did not like was that a number of the Temples and monuments had locals sitting all over them. Like Thamel - foreigners are immediately targeted by sales people, beggars etc. I don't mean to sound crass but it does get annoying (the sales people).  In any event - it's neat, there are lots of shops in the nearby alleys and really 500 NPR is not expensive.
Patan has suffered much less than Durbar Square in Kathmandu and most of the temples are intact. There are many interesting temples here and a lovely garden

you will be amazes by the architectural designs of the temples and buildings that surrounds it, the museum is very interesting,great artifacts, paintings and sculptures. the place itself will tell you how artistic the people in nepal are. a must visit place.

Caveat: This review predates the devastating earthquake that afflicted this and many other sites in Nepal with terrible damage to some amazing architecture.  I visited Patan Durbar with my wife and a new friend and we enjoyed the trip very much. The entrance fee was negligible and the locals were extremely courteous and helpful. Bring some spending money for souvenirs as there are a number of vendors in the area with hand-made crafts. There's also a cultural museum that has a number of interesting displays. I'd suggest allocating 2-3 hours if you'd like to see all that this square has to offer and get a snack or meal in one of the surrounding restaurants.

column7: Great to see repairs going on at this great site
column8: It is sad to see so much damage in Kathmandu after the earthquake, but as well it's great to see so much repair work going on. There are still hundreds living in tents around the city, and this is a dreadful thing that needs attention. But there is support from the Japanese and the Germans (among others) to repair the ancient sites in Kathmandu, and that is marvellous. You still can experience the wonder of this place, and there are very few tourists at the moment, everything is extremely cheap; it's a great time to visit!

column7: Worth a wander through, beautiful buildings, not as chaotic as the kathmandu durbar square
column8: A people hub surrounding by interesting buildings. I liked the museum too which was informative and peaceful to wander through. Have food somewhere overlooking the square at sunset - beautiful views of the building.

column7: A harmony of people and place
column8: I came on the evening. It was lots of crowd. People were sitting and talking each other. Some people were working to fixed road, seemed freely to do it. Felt like all have sense of belonging to this place. Seeing those people with artistic and beautiful buildings around, becoming an unforgettable memory.

column7: If you have short stay this is place to go!
column8: My high profile friends have limited time between flights and she wants to see something unique to Nepalese art, culture and way of life. I took her to Patan Darbar square for quick snapshots of Nepal. She was so happy to see landscape of Darbar square, life around there and museum in side Darbar square. Stone, metal and wood carving skills are astonishing.

it was was a nice experience for me to visit. very traditional buildings and liked the structure. took lots of photo. but I went there after the earthquake.. so found some buildings being supported with logs or iron rods... overall it was pretty cool experience. I will visit again once they repair the damage caused my earthquake...

Walking around the square takes one back to a time where life was less chaotic.  Make sure to purchase your ticket before you go into the various buildings. I had the fortune to actually see a taping of a show where the actors all wore period costumes. It was a sight to behold. To see people dressed in costumes amidst the setting, it was definitely an experience.  The place was crowded during my visit, but in spite of the crowd, once can still feel the history emanating from within the walls of this sacred place.
like i say.. the beauty is still there even after the earthquake .. just stunning. Lots of pigeon which adding to the unique beauty of the place

patan durbar square is situated in patan.it is the one of the three royal cities in the kathmandu.it builds in 17th century in rules of malla king,s.i really impress many attractive temple.many visitors are come to visit this palace.krishna mandir is most famous in the patan durbar.it builds by the stone and it built in 16th century.in other words patan durbar square is the artistic place when i went to the patan durbar i really happy after saw the architecture of the palace and beautyful temple .and i went to the rani pokhari of the pyatan .it was really beautyfull and many white ducks are swiming in the ponds it,s really beautyfull .and ,many small cafes are situated in the patan durbar square area .

column7: History Past and Present in Dubar Square.
column8: I enjoyed this day very much. A day filled with history. I went with a Nepali friend and an english speaking guide. For me, this was a great introduction to Nepali customs and culture.
A wonderful place to go and see old Kathmandu. Very interesting and beautiful place to walk around. Tourists do have to pay to get in.

I have to say, this could be the most beautiful durbar square (even though there are some serious competition with Bhaktapur Durbar Square). And you can easily see the reason why, once you step your foot there. while the main architecture are more or less the same with other durbar square, there are more details and beautiful temples around that makes this durbar square more interesting and appreciable.

column7: Great to explore Patan with a local guide
column8: Patan is worth spending at least half a day. I usually tend not to take local guides in touristy places like Patan Durbar Square. This time I agreed to have a guided tour and it was a wise decision. The Durbar Square itself, with plenty of different temples and shrines, can probably be visited by your own, but the rest of the city including Golden Temple, Mahabudha Temple or Rudra Varna Mahavihar is as interesting as the main square, but the temples are not so easy to be found as they are hidden in the courtyards and not visible from the streets. Also, the story of the monks in the Golden Temple or sacrifices at the main square are worth listening to. Great place!

No visit to Kathmandu would be complete without visiting Darbar Square. For a taste of the non-tourist experience, visit the museum in Hanuman Dhoka: with its (somewhat dusty and not exceptionally artful) displays of old armaments, coins, and an exhibit dedicated to the Shah kings, it is more popular with locals than with tourists. The views from the inner towers, too, aren't to be missed.

column7: Patan Durbar Square - How to Travel by Bus
column8: I am assuming your starting point is Thamel. Before you start, open google maps and key in the following four locations to get the route overview which will help me to explain.  A) "Ratna Park" or "Ratna Park Micro" or "Ratna Park Bus Stop, B) Koteshwor, Kathmandu, Nepal C) Lagankhel Bus Station, Lalitpur, Central Region, Nepal D) Patan Durbar Square, Lalitpur, Nepal  1. Walked from my Hotel Access Nepal in Thamel to Ratna Park(A), around 2 kms. 2. There just ask for which bus goes to Koteshwor(B). The bus I took continued from the Ring Road to the Arakino Highway instead of turning left towards (B). So keep that in mind and ensure you get down accordingly and cross the road to the point (B). 3. From (B), the few buses I asked were unable to understand Patan Durbar Square!! Instead ask for Lagankhle Bus Stop (C) and you will have several buses to take you there. 4. From (C), you have to walk to Patan Durbar. It's a interesting walk and you wont regret it.  Note ------- 1. You probably could check if a direct bus to Lagankhale is there from "Ratna Park". I was not aware of the name Lagankhel at that time. 2. Keep small changes handy as the buses are going to be crowded and cramped and you may not be able to dig deep in your pockets ! 3. Start early as possible to avoid the traffic and the crowd. 4. Sit as close to the door of the bus as possible.

À visit to Durbar Square is overwhelming, it is difficult to decide where to look first! The historical palace, the beautiful temples, the sacrificial sites, the women meditating at the temple, the many doves, it is an experience you should not miss! We went there three times and each time was exciting!

Durbar Square in Patan is much more interesting and photogenic than the one in Katmandu, with a line of variuos Hindu Temples with different architectures opposite the palace. Entry is just $7.50 and its also worth hiring a guide for $15 for a couple of hours. For lunch go to the garden cafe in the palace (no extra charge) which is in a realxing beautiful courtyard. Then visit the museum (extra charge) one of the finest in Asia.
While the basic structure of all 3 Durbar squares of Kathmandu valley are the same, each of them have their own charm. A must see for its unique temples

If you cannot get to Bactapur, Patan will show you what old Nepalese architecture and regal style existed once upon a time. Elegance and spatial design provide a real wow factor. Add nearby boutique hotels, good eating options, laneways and retail to the mix for a pleasant half day experience
Of the MANY Durbar Squares (Kat, Baktapur, etc) that you can visit easily from Kathmandu, this was my favorite. Cleaner, more interesting, easier to get around--worth the time for a visit.

Most people arrive and leave from Kathmandu. If you can take a day to see nearby cities in the valley, you'll get a broader view of the history and culture that are unique to the Nepali, and particularly the Newar, people. Patan (Lalitpur) has a beautiful, compact, and well preserved durbar temple complex that is well worth the visit.

in comparison with Thamel and Bakhtapur, it's less touristy and authentic.  Every morning there's chants praising Hindu Gods. It's an tranquil experience sitting there listen to the chants, at the same time seeing children feeding pigeons at the square...the palaces are most worth going

Kathmandu is known as Kasthamandap, the source of the name Kathmandu means ‘made from the timber of a single tree’. Also known as Kantipur, the capital Kathmandu is the hub of Nepal's art and culture. It is a place for rest, relaxation and easy-day sightseeing of historic and artistic temples and monuments. Kathmandu Durbar Square with its arrays of temples, Seto Machhindranath and the ancient palace of the former Nepali Royals enriches your experience of the centuries old civilisation.

If the hanuman dhoka durbar square has unique combination of malls and shah period architecture,patan durbar square on the other hand reflects singular malla architecture.It has a unique architecture style manga hiti,the sunken stone water spout and the magnificent Krishna temple,a shikhara style temple built of stone are really perfect.  I enjoy a lot, visiting different courtyard of patandurbar square.The mangalbazar where square lies is very good place to see the monument and different arts and different temple in different style. I love to visit and enjoy this place so i often loke to visit here when i am in Kathmandu.

There are 3 main squares in Kathmandu and this is one of them. The square is a 15 - 20 minute ride from Kathmandu. Its not as large as the Kathmandu square, but it seems a lot more vibrant and interesting. Its laid out also slightly better so that you can walk around comfortably. Visit the museum. Its stunning. Walk into the cafes and enjoy the views. Take a lot of photographs. You won't be disappointed.

We were sceptical to enter the museum at first but real glad that we did. The museum was well maintained and there's many interesting exhibits. There's also a restaurant at the rear courtyard, while the food is average, it has a nice atmosphere.

column7: Beautiful square with temples and stupas
column8: It is not a large area, and quite crowded with temples, stupas, and people. The only real complication is the entry ticket, as the area is open and you could easily walk in without realising you've missed the ticket booth. As others have mentioned, the ticket checkers who come around can be annoying but once you have a ticket it lasts a few days. If you've seen other Durbar squares, you can just get a drink at the terrace of one of the cafes overlooking the square and appreciate it from outside. Worth seeing if you are in Patan.

column7: Very nice place! You can't miss it
column8: Patan is near Kathmandu, in Lalitpur. Is an old little place, with a few blocks, with incredible temples, squares, alleys where you will see incredible places. You have to pay to get inside this place. Inside Patan you will find de Golden Temple is an exquisite place. The Museum is very interesting but I didn"t have time to visit it. Very interesting. it's a nice place to walk for a while...if you can sit in a stais or in a temple to see people going by is a nice sempsation, kids playing, Old people sitting in benchs each aafternoon to see life passing by....a really good choice!!!

There are two, if not three, Durbar (or Darbar) Squares in what one thinks of as Kathmandu. This Durbar Square is, however, in Patan which, at one time, would have been separate from old Kathmandu. Kathmandu has extended so much it has now swallowed areas that might have, historically, been townships in their own right.  Patan Durbar Square has more impressive temples and historic sights than its counterpart in Kathmandu. Don't visit Nepal without seeing both, however, as each has something to offer.  A pleasant thing about Durbar Square is that one isn't hassled, or at least not too much, by persons offering to act as a guide, sell one souvenirs, etc. Be sure to bargain with taxi drivers, as they will almost inevitably try and overcharge you. The same applies to shops and stalls selling handicrafts, Pashmina shawls and souvenirs. One can end up paying very considerably less than what the seller initially demands. A good time to buy is nearing the end of the day. Traders find it hard to avoid the temptation to make one last sale and some real bargains can be obtained in these circumstances.

Where else can you see so many amazing temples so close to each other! By day or by evening we lived it. Great to not have to dodge vehicles while you admire and take pictures of your surroundings! Be careful, you may find yourselves invited in to a wedding spontaneously like we did! Go for it, amazing!

column7: Up there with some of the best sites in the world
column8: This was really quite an experience. There's a real awe that hits you as you walk in and you're instantly transported to a time when this would have been the central point for this ancient kingdom. It's a feast for your eyes and camera! Would be silly to visit Kathmandu and not at least see this. On par, if not better, than the central durbar in Kathmandu

Try to visit this place when you have some spare time. The temple at the square is very old and the carvings are erotic. Have a good look. Vendors and shopkeepers do not overcharge if you can bargain. I find it bad that western tourists have to pay to visit this place when anybody else can walk in and out. School kids are everywhere, one cannot take a decent picture of a monument or statue without some kids sitting on it. This was the same in Bahktapur where I had regretted that I had paid 10 euro when I saw that so many walked in without paying. A visit to the museum still has to be paid extra anyway. In Patan, they try to avoid that people walk in without paying (only if you look western, speaking of discrimination) by obliging you to hang the large ticket around your neck. Just awful. It spoiled my appreciation of this wonderful old place, having this thing around my neck. I felt like an animal for sale. Why not make the entrance free for all without discrimination and charge for separate visits of the temple, the museum, etc... Tourists are more than just milk cows that are only good for their money.

Patan, known as the "city of Art", is mainly an old Buddhist area and the first impact on us was how much cleaner the area around the Durbar Square was compared to the more chaotic Kathmandu Durbar Square. It was very interesting just walking through the various laneways and courtyards (bahals) just seeing how the local people live. One site that was very impressive but just outside the main Square was Mahabuddha Temple where there are according to the locals more than 9,000 stone carvings of Lord Buddha. We had a nice lunch at the Vala Layekh Kitchen which was just opposite to the main entrance and overlooking the Square. Highly recommend a visit this Square ... more impressive than Kathmandu Durbar Square.
The guards are a little ambitious about hounding travelers to pay for access, but the square is honestly a marvel to see. I highly recommend going to this attraction.

column7: Felt like walking into a history book!
column8: Beautiful historical square couple with fascinating architecture of the temples. Great place to spend the afternoon, immersing in the local history, culture & people-watch. If you only have 1 afternoon, I would recommend Patan Durbar Square instead of Kathmandu Durbar Square!
was a great experience. Lots of goods, affordable and the area was full of people. Very noisy as well.

While walking down from the tourist bus park vehicles and traffic jam you need to face and after 10 mins walk I was surprise to see lots of monuments in a single place. It's was mind blowing to see the artist and architecture. It is said that patan durbar square is oldest durbar than Kathmandu and bhaktapur. While entering the premises of durbar you'll see three idiots Ganesha said to be Siddhi, Narshiama itself and Hanuman said to be Mall in combine its know as Siddhi Narshimha Malla who build the durbar. You can see the Taleju temple, shiva temple, bhimsen temple and other small small temples but eye catchy is Krishna temple said to be made of single stone where details of Mahabharata war story is sculptures very finely. But don't forget to visit the museum and if you were lucky during visit at june- July other rooms of courtyard will be open because lots of festivals falls at these mothe so you'll get chance to see the bhandarkhal garden, Mulchowk and stone bed of malls king siddhi naraingha. Century old ston tap is near by where still people queing to fetch for water during dry season. It was more interesting if you go and see by you own eyes. Must visit place of Nepal.

I loved the surrounding. I could see lots of effort for maintaining the part of history. However, harassment from street sellers was way too annoying. Something must be done otherwise the whole experience becomes bitter.

spent an afternoon walking around the area, seeing alot of interesting sight, especially very different from home. I was at the square for the whole afternoon, sitting around at a corner can gives you quite some story. Architure here are also quite interesting to watch, those red bricks and wood carving are some amazing work.
Durbar (central) Square is old palce of rular in nepal and it has the unique ancent architeque of wooden sculpture. Anybody having an interest of arts and history would has to visit

Both the culture and architecture here are equally captivative, I enjoy walking and photographing this place of interest. Is interesting to be sitting at one of the cafe and watch the crowd, also enjoyed strolling around the square admiring all the details that going on in the square. Good get away from the hust and bussle of Kathmandu city.

The temples and other buildings were breathtakingly beautiful when considering the minute attention to detail that has gone into constructing them.  You need at least a half day to walk though these ancient city centres.  Also enjoyed browsing among the trinkets and (supposedly old) artefacts.  Didn't like the pesky touts, though! - that's for sure. But I certainly didn't like the touts.

What an amazing experience, breathtakingly beautiful temples, monuments, and museums in the square that is still the center of this active community. People worshiping, mechants selling goods, locals bathing and washing in the community fountains, friendly young people just hanging out, all surrounded by features dating back a millenium. In the side alleys that radiate out from the square there are tiny shops where craftsmen hammer metal or loom fabrics that are immediately for sale.  We enjoyed staying in Patan and we came back to the square after the tourists go back to Thamel and shared some Baktipour (sp?) yogurt from a local dairy on the steps of the temple just lit by accent lights. It was a magical memory.

We were staying at a hotel on the side of the square where there are lots of trinklets for sale and where the local took water (holy water??) from. For a start, we got up early and caught the stall owners setting up stall. We had a great time browsing and do friendly bargaining with the stall owners. After that, we strolled into the square. There were no barriers nor signage indicating that we are indeed entering the square.  A short way into the square and after 2 photos, it was just past 9am, we were stopped by a young lady who asked if we have had tickets. We didn't so we were told to purchase tickets. I went to get my Dad and daughter to go purchase the tickets but my Dad decided not to as he strolled the square yesterday evening and that there is nothing much there. Then, we were approached by the girl's superior (probably), a large young Nepalese. When we said that we have decided that we do not want to purchase the tickets, he got really aggressive, asked us why then are we in the square! (There were no indication of boundary in the first place!!!) Then he told us to leave the square immediately. The girl told him that we have taken photos and told us to delete them! Wow! What a lousy experience.  I mean, I was with my parents who are close to 70 years old and a 11 year old girl, is it necessary to be that rude? It just totally spoiled it for us.  If you have been to Kathmandu Durbar Square, I think you can skip this as this is probably only 30% the size of Kathmandu Square. The entry fee at Kathmandu Square is Nepali Rupee 750 and here it is 500.  Save your money for a nice cup of coffee or tea and avoid spoiling your holiday by a rude gorilla.  We were informed that the fees are only applicable between 10am to 5pm by the hotel operator later.
I liked the many and varied temples. One of the temples was dedicated to Lord Vishnu. Other temples were dedicated to other hindu gods.

column7: Lots of interesting temples to see
column8: More temples in one place than I have ever seen. The old palace is interesting and the little streets have wholesale traders in Bhudas, Tonkas as well as other interesting take-aways.

The experience of visiting Patan's Durbar square is diluted only if you've been to Bhaktapur or Kathmandu's similar Durbar squares, otherwise, it socks you in the stomach for sheer presence and authenticity. Although the square is relatively small, the buildings are intact and so rich in detail as to keep you busy - especially if you're a photographer - for hours.  Roughly speaking, on one side are the royal palace buildings, and on the other side are the various temples, including one in South Indian or 'shikara' style, built of stone and dedicated to the god Krishna. The other wooden temples are in Nepalese architecture, some with erotic carvings on the roof struts. There are also a couple of metal statues on poles in the square, and plenty of details on the buildings to keep the visitor absorbed.  Various architectural styles are presented, with fascinating stories of various features. Pay for a local guide - it's well worth it, as much of the richness of the site is not apparent otherwise.  This is the authentic Nepal before development and traffic made the Kathmandu valley the sorry mess that it now is.

column7: Together with Kathmandu and Baktipur are the main historical sites in the valley!
column8: Patan Durbar Square is a must! I recomend to devote minimum one day to this historical place. Even if is a public square foreign visitors need to pay entrance, look for the ticket in the counter in one corner of the square. The price is 500 NRP per person. There are also tourist guides, that show you all the details of the temples and palaces in the square. The place is a unique misture of temples, places, the Patan Museum, Cafes, handcraft shops . Go there! Do not miss it!

Darbar Square personifies Kathmandu. It has the hustle and bustle of the city, and the ambling crowds in this area dampen an otherwise unique experience. The good part about the square is the ample historical information on display. Visit the Patan Darbar which is smaller but has better character and a colloquial feel.

I recently stayed for a total of five nights with Lalit, on two occasions as I passed through Patan. The hotel is perfectly located to explore both Paten Durbar Square and the nearby historic lanes. The family that operate Lalit are attentive, interesting and engaging. It was a pleasure to spend a few days with them. I will definitely be staying with them again on my next visit to Nepal.

We have stayed two days in room 201, it is such a nice place , very well located , very comfortable, Nepali people are the kindest event more the family that works here !!! Great roof top with a view to appreciate the sunrise while having a wonderful breakfast !!!

I enjoyed my night's stay here, it's a charming old guest house. Great location. No heating but an electric blanket kept me warm at night. Manju took good care of me and made the best French toast for breakfast, it was delicious!

Looking for guest house style of accommodation in Kathmandu the Hira guest house has the uniqueness that only this style of accommodation can provide. Spent three wonderful night there recently and was extremely impressed by the friendliness of the staff, and it’s central location in Patan. Enjoyed a fantastic Nepali dinner on the night I dined in cooked by the guest house manager, unfortunately I can’t remember her name but she was certainly a delightful host - don’t forget to try the local yogurt, best I have tried. I found Patan to be a really safe location to explore, yes the streets are narrow and there is a lot of motorcycles - but this is part of the overall Nepal experience.

Aman and Ester are wonderful hosts! Their guesthouse is very well located at a beautiful and quiet square next to the Golden Temple and not more than 250m from Durbar Square. I enjoyed having breakfast on the rooftop which was nicely prepared by Ester and Pusa according to my wishes. Highly recommended!!

column7: A great experience and perfect location
column8: Being with Aman Esther and little Naomi at their beautifully renovated newari house is a pleasure. The location in Patan is in a quiet well kept community Square near all the impressive temples and Durban square. They are perfect hosts with so much information about the local ara. Highly recommended!
I was disappointed to find that they have two locations, only one with a garden. The food was average, not as many healthy options as I was expecting. Overall quite disappointed with my experience.
At this relaxing café I enjoyed a very good Americano Coffee. Good atmosphere and nice staff. Prices are okay.

Used to be a big fan of Cafe Soma, but the service has declined. I have had at least 3 horrible experience with their service which includes both of the locations. Cafe Soma is very popular with locals to meet people for coffee/ breakfast meetings, but I avoid going there as much as possible. Food is still good, but the service has disappointingly gone downhill in last 2 years.

Went there with my friend last month.In fact i go to this place very often ...but not a regular tho...had some fish and chips for dinner...obviously it was very good and had some coffee too which tasted heavenly...really appreciate those guys tho...and the waitress is cute too... Anyways great place but if only the servers could be a little more attentive....otherwise must come place

column7: typical expat cafe at its best
column8: just drop in on lunch on a Sunday, got fish and chips, Shelfs filled with books, packed with expats, mostly US, saw good looking burgers (who ever likes such stuff), but fish was fine, could be a bit more remoulade, with home made fine chips, smalll coleslaw at the side. Prices untipicall for Patan include service and tax already,Will return to get more experience

My sister and i recently visited Cafe SOma in Jhamsikhel and it was sucha refreshing experience. We ordered the vegetairan cooked breakfast and cold coffees. Food was decently prepared and portions are massive. They also have wide variety of fresh juices which my sister loved. She tried the kale and apple.  Additionally, the servers are very hospitable and gentle to talk to. Soma is must visit place for anyone who loves a good spread of breakfast as much as i do.  One can visit Soma for quiet alone working time or just read a book by the corner whilst looking out on the hustle bustle of KTM life. Definitely worth a visit

I been there so many times with friends and family. I enjoy the environment. Good coffee, breakfast are amazing. Breakfast for two is the good deal. Mostly I like that. Fresh bread, egg with bandit (may be I miss spell it). Truly breakfast is fantastic....More

column7: great burgers in a lovely garden
column8: The Cafe Soma I am reviewing is actually in Balawatar, Kathmandu, rather than Jamsikhel, Patan. Designed in a rambling house with a lovely garden, there is a comfortable sitting room and also a separate cake shop on the premises, Lakuri Cakes. My friends and I all had the New York burger, which was possibly the best burger I've had in Asia. The wedge like fries were also super! The rest of the menu also looked interesting. We topped off our meal with carrot cake from Lakuri and left perfectly satisfied.

The restaurant has a good variety of menu items and i think all delicious! We ate an early dinner here while in Patan and I enjoyed a lots selections.The restaurant is set kind of back in an alley so it was nice and quiet.I visited several times during my visit to patan, and the food and drinks were always great! It's a nice place to just relax and enjoy time with friends and have a good meal.the staff are friendly and highly recommended!

column7: Great food, Great service, Clean and Consistent
column8: Go here for the food. It is very well done western style dishes. I really enjoy the burgers and fries (all for decent prices) and when I recovered from Kathmandu belly, this is the place I frequented as I trust the hygienic standards and the foods are mild such as there delicious homemade soups. The staff are quiet, polite and accommodating and the food is cooked within a reasonable time and comes out together with the other dishes which is rare so far in my experience in Nepal. I have nothing to offer in ways of improvement, so Cafe Soma please keep doing what you are doing. This is one of our favourite locals.

I am a regular at Cafe Soma since they started and appreciate the consistency in quality and service. The coffee, bakery items, breakfast and sandwiches are the best. I am a vegetarian and find plenty of options. The owners are highly committed to offering a great experience. Prices are lower than similar in establishments in the area.

We often visit Café Soma ( it's close to our appartment). It's always a great experience. It's a cafe which offer quite a wide range of "western fashioned cafe beverage", but it's also one of the best place to eat in the neighborhood. The food is great, they have the best burgers we found in Ktm/Patan so far. The waiters are doing a great job too : quick, smiling service, clear explanation if needed; attention to details. The atmosphere is nice, quite calm. The prices are very reasonable, rather cheaper than in other restaurants of the area, for a superior quality. I recommend it without hesitation !!

Cafe Soma is a MUST for those in Kathmandu. Their signature Soma burger is delicious and it comes with potato wedges that are, (unlike the majority of restaurants I visited in Nepal) not dripping in oil. Their pasta is to die for as well! Their bakery section is wonderful, you'll find croissants, rolls, cakes, muffins that are incredibly pleasing on the palette - top that off with a nice latte and you're sorted! The ambiance is relaxed with nice relaxing music playing in the background as opposed to blaring noise and the staff are all very efficient and helpful and the free wifi is an added bonus! I met one of the owners, Bish, who was very nice with lots of sound advice on what to do in Nepal. Interesting guy, he went to Public school in the UK, as did his sisters, one of whom is also a partner in Soma - If you are ever around the Jhamsikhel area Soma is a must!

column7: By far the best experience in town
column8: I really really love this place. I go to this mall for two reasons: movies and coffee....this place is amazing for coffee .However if you're a foodie,the third floor is perfectly made for you. I love mango chilli the most . A must visit place

A brand new shopping mall in Lalitpur area - lies on the main road of Kupondole to Jawalakhel, just on the turn towards Patan Durbar Square and famous Krishna Temple. Very easily accessible by personal car, bike, taxi and even public transport. Attractive and modern building with great interiors and decors. It has many branded and other range of shops and famous for shopping. Truly attractive restaurants and bars with tempting foods and drinks, from Nepalese, Indian, continental and others. Three movie halls names QFX showing Hollywood, Bollywood and Nepalese movies. A must visit place to spend evening

column7: Enjoying authentic Vietnamese food in Patan
column8: Pho 99 restaurant at Thado Dungha, Patan, Lalitpur is one my favorite place for having meals leisurely in a tranquil atmosphere with greenery around. Visited third time yesterday for dinner with my family. As usual started with a big fresh coconut, my favorite drink. Some of us enjoyed the non vegetarian dishes of duck , pork and chicken. Being a vegetarian, I enjoyed green Papaya salad with Tofu curry and fried veg. wantons. The foods were so delicious, not a small piece was left on the plate after wards. They also serve so good Vietnamese coffee along with other several varieties of hot and cold drinks including fresh fruit juices.

I have had Vietnamese food just the one time at Pho-99, so I don't really have anything to compare with. There were some really interesting flavor combinations in the menu. I guess it caters to the Nepalese people's palate. So far, I like it quite a bit and wouldn't mind going there again.

column7: A far cry from Vietnamese Pho
column8: The restaurant has both indoor and garden seating, pleasant premises. I really looked forward to pho and so ordered a duck one. A bowl of tasteless, luke-warm water arrived. The greens consisted of dry and shrivelled been sprouts and 3 leaves of local small leafed lettuce. The water had slices of undercooked meat in it. Very disappointing. Perhaps their curries were good - I have not tried them. The menu also listed interesting non-alcoholic drinks like plum drink, hot or cold. other restaurants offer these and they are yummy. Toilet was clean, garden was pleasant. but the 'Pho' in the name was a false promise.

Eating pho noodles has always been my comfort retreat. Whenever I'd feel a little under the weather, I'd go for some noodles soup and there is a difference when it is pho (authentic) vietnamese. I'd repeatedly ordered beef pho. I like it best with sweet basil leaves but unfortunately, these are not popular in Nepal and their alternative is lettuce leaves, some overgrown bean sprouts which can be very hard...so last resort- just to finish the bowl without the leaves.
