Kabi and the team in Trekking Guide Team Adventure organised everything for us including airport pickup, hotel accommodation in Thamel (the main tourist centre), a city tour of Kathmandu before we started hiking and all the logistics of the trek itself. The EBC trek is quite challenging but massively rewarding in terms of scenery, wildlife, camaraderie, culture and a bit of craic in the tea houses after long day hikes. Our guide Shambu was very professional, funny, entertaining and an all round legend! He organised absolutely everything including airport transfers to Lukla, meals, accommodation, porters for our heavy bags and the best photo opportunities. Shambu knew every single mountain in the Himalayas, including their heights! His English is excellent and he spent every hour of the day making sure everyone in our group was well fed, comfortable and most importantly, SAFE! I cannot say enough about the man - he was a hero and made the trip an absolute pleasure!  We had 3 porters between 5 people to carry our heavy bags for the 12 days - the lads were great and it was incredible how they ran up and down the steep trails at high altitude with a 25kg bag each, yet never seemed to get tired. All the while, we were gasping for breath! If you are thinking about taking on the EBC, Annapurna or any of the other Himalayan treks, I would highly recommend Trekking Guide Team Adventure.
We had a wonderful experience trekking to Basecamp. Our guide, Shambu made all the difference. Shambu is an excellent guide and a very kind companion to share the trip with. Highly recommend Shambu.

From the day I decided to do EBC solo (but within a group trek), Kabi was super helpful and provided me reassurance that I will be looked after.  Our group of 11 was assigned Mr Shambu, Mr Jit, and a number of wonderful porters to guide us through EBC. The trek wasn't as easy as I expected but I loved every minute of it thanks to the great organisation and guidance from Shambu.  Shambu kept me feeling safe, entertained (ask him to teach you Dhumbal aka Shambu), reassured and never rushed me even though I trailed behind. He was happy to adapt the itinerary to cater to the group's needs and went above and beyond to secure us the best lodges possible. He is a wonderful guide and a wonderful person.  Thank you Shambu, Kabi, Jit and our porters (including Dham and Mantu) for a life-changing experience I will never forget. Resham firiri...!

I would recommend this visit for singles, couples and families. The professionalism and care shown by all the team was second to none.  Our guide, Shambu Basnet and our porter dham Bahadur Rai went above and beyond expectations during our trip. Shambu has a bank of knowledge about Nepal, from its mountains to its flora and fauna. He taught me some key Nepalise phrases and some traditional card games.  The accommodation was clean and of a high standard. The owners of the tea houses being very kind and welcoming.  Having done minimal training before the trek I was concerned about my potential success to reach EBC but having such a supportive core team made the goal manageable.  Thank you so much team!

column7: Trip of a lifetime! You will not be the same after you hike in the majesty of these mountains!
column8: I traveled in May 2018 with two of my girlfriends to Nepal to do the 16 Day Everest Base Camp trek which we booked with Kabi of Trekking Guide Team Adventure. The service that was provided by this company was Superior! We were met at the airport in Kathmandu, and our transfer to the hotel Thamel with our luggage was very easy. Mr. Kabi came and met us personally, and introduced us to our trekking guide Ram. Ram is a very quality person, and obviously has a passion for his job as a guide. He was patient and caring with 3 women who were complete newbies to the whole trekking experience! He even tried to teach us some Nepalese, although we did not prove to be very good students. Ram was cheerful at all times, and greeted us always with a smile and attended to every detail and need we had during our trek.  We needed to make some changes in our itinerary while we were on the trek, and both Ram and Mr. Kabi worked together to make sure everything worked out for us. They are very concerned with safety, which was a good feeling for 3 women on this adventure.  The Tea Houses we stayed in were certainly adequate, and the food was nourishing and tasted good.  The only thing I would advise is that the trek itself is not as moderate a hike as made out to be. It is very steep a lot of the time, and you are going up stone stairs! I would recommend training yourself for some endurance before you go! Coming down the mountain is just as hard as going up! Be prepared for flight delays in Lukla, and the possibility of needing to take a helicopter out of there as we did if your travel is near to Monsoon season.

I went on this trek without any previous trekking experiences nor any proper training. Overall it was a phenomenal experience, all made possible by the staff of the Trekking Guide Team Adventure. Shambu (our guide) was unbelievably helpful with his expertise in trekking (including how to handle altitude sickness) and there was absolutely 0 troubles in terms of communication. I must tip my hat again to Shambu as he knew where we were in terms of our fitness and definitely helped me out by carrying my gear when I was struggling.  In terms of the trek, everything (including the weather) went perfectly for us and words cannot describe how beautiful the landscape was the whole way (which changed almost in align with the seasons).  One thing I would recommend to anyone who is going to embark on this trek (which I hope you do) is to take extra money as food/water can be very expensive as you get further up the mountains. There are also little extra things you might want to spend money on (eg. showers (400 rupees), wifi (600 rupees/200mb), pringles (500 rupees). Also I would highly recommend for everyone to take diamox and water purification tablets up on the trek as well and to avoid all meats.
Great place for inner peace awesome experience, hard to say.. &have mind,body,,& soul, awesome thanks for the session....

column7: Mardi Himal Trek (A virgin trails in Nepal)
column8: It is my second time in Nepal before it was 1 year ago. Last year, I went for Kathmandu City Tour with some hiking around the Nagarkot. This year I planned for short and easy hiking so I read blogs, reviews and articles related to short treks in Nepal and landed on Nepal Hiking Adventure site. After analyzing, I contacted company’s manager Bishnu Lamsal. He was so kind and calming, he answers my question very gentle and provides information on popular Nepal short treks. Finally, I landed on Mardi Himal Trek after listening to the amazing highlights of this trek. After On my arrival to Kathmandu, Nepal there was Ram who was going to be my trek guide to Mardi Himal. I find him very fun and caring type person. He asked how my flight was, did I eat anything or not. After reaching hotel I refreshed up and went to their company to discuss about the trip. They give me brief information about the trip. From the start of this trip, our tour guide Ram starts providing information of beautiful villages, their culture, monastery, Himalayan ranges and more. He showed us what we are looking for. He explore us around these local villages of Gurung and Magars. Truly learned great things from these villages and our guide. The trails was easy to moderate while ascending and descending was easy and fast. Along the way, I used to talk with our guide and porters. At teahouses he used to tell jokes and I have to laugh with them even though I can’t understand them. The great team of Nepal Hiking Adventure makes this trip of mine an unforgettable adventure of my life. I highly recommend this Mardi Himal Trek for those who want to experience Annapurna and Dhaulagiri ranges without spending long days of trekking. A great thank you to Nepal Hiking Adventure team and recommend to you all to visit this agency if you ever made your trip to Nepal.

column7: Great team from Nepal Hiking Adventure Company
column8: Hiring Nepal Hiking Adventure Company was a best way to meet nepalian culture and country. Service of this Company was excellent and we got more then we expected. It was worth of every cent indeed...Our guide Ram together with Bishnu found solutions for every problem we encountered on our amazing trek to Base Camp Everest for we didn't have to worry about anything but enjoy our fantastic journey through astonishing Himalayan range. After this trek we spend some time in Kathmandu valley and team from Nepal Hiking Advanture Company provided the best service here as well. If you want not to worry about anything during your adventure and meet culture and people of this amazing country on the best possible way we would definitely recommend Nepal Hiking Adventure Company to guide you through. Best service ever and great people in the team who responded on our each wish and need quickly and efficiently. We got much more then we paid for...it was a lifetime experience indeed. Thank you guys for everything you did for us. We will surely come back again.

column7: Excellent organisation and very enjoyable trip to EBC
column8: It has always been an ambition of ours to walk up to EBC and after some research online we found NHAC.  A prompt detailed email reply from Bishnu (Managing Director) told us that this was the company to go with. After further email exchanges we booked on to a tour and never looked back.  In Kathmandu we were met at the airport by our guide and later we were met by Bishnu in our hotel. He checked our gear and told us what we did and didn't need.  The tour itself was excellent. Zore was a fantastic guide and pointed out all the interesting viewpoints along the way. You see some stunning scenery along the walk. Each day you walk for 4-6 hours over hilly terrain. Some bits are a slog; some bits are thoroughly enjoyable.  Each day you have three meals provided, which are very tasty and very filling! The biggest surprise to us was the accommodation. Each night we stayed in a small hotel and there is the facility to charge your devices, have a hot shower and get wifi. These do have a small cost to them and get more expensive as you go further up the mountain.  We also spent quite a lot on drinks as these are not included in the price. An extra £200 for all of the above should cover you for the duration of the trek. Water is available at every stop but you will need purification tablets to clean the water. This might sound unappealing but it really is fine.  One thing to be mindful of, if you go in the off-season, you might get stuck in Lukla. At the end of a long trek, stinking in your clothes, you 'll want to get out of Lukla and back to the 'comforts' of Kathmandu. We had to charter a helicopter which set us back another $700 but Bishnu did return us the cost of the flight as this was cancelled. This is your choice as the flights are often cancelled during this time of year. There was a guy in our hotel cabin who had been there EIGHT days waiting for a flight. Didn't quite fancy that...  Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed the trip and Bishnu helped to make it as simple and easy as possible. He provided us with a letter to send off to our insurance company too because of the cancelled flight.  Thank you Bishnu and NHAC!

Overall a second trip with a company that had a few positives but an astounding anoint of negatives  Pre-Tour - great response time and attention to all of our questions from Bishnu - well arranged pickup logistics - excellent support to retrieve coat left on plane - briefing prior to tour departure was not thorough (no discussion on weight for baggage, oxygen measuring, potential health issues, need for crampons or warning of the ice/how to handle the ice on Chola Pass)  Tour Customer Service - Guide (Kamal) focussed on myself a repeat client saying "you're the client and M is just there" several times. After this I spoke to Kamal and said please do not speak about M like this. He said "actually yes I should focus on him and not you as you've already come back", I said "no you need to treat us equally". However from this time onwards the entire focus was on M, to the point of isolating me out of the group - I was the inconvenient woman on the boys trip  Itinerary After loosing the first porter to illness Kamal was forced to carry all the bags (~37kg) on his own for a day - we said we would provide feedback to the company that he should be compensated. We were told that the problem was caused by us choosing to walk from Salleri - we said we followed Bishnu's advice and we cannot be held responsible for the fact that porters can't be found at Salleri.  Later in Gokio I was told there was not enough time to climb Gokio Ri in the itinerary because not enough time had been left to return to Lukla & because I was too slow - why did Bishnu create an itinerary that was not achievable I asked Kamal - he said again it was because we choose to walk from Salleri - do you think anyone could give some sensible advice from this company on what to do on a planning a trek? As for being too slow Chola Pass - Kamal's estimate 10-12hrs - my time 8.5hr; Crossing Gokyo glacier Kamal's estimate 3-4hrs - my time 2.5hrs. I could continue but the reality was being a boring woman I didn't stand a chance of arguing this.  Baggage Kamal had told us in Kathmandu on the morning of departure our bags could not be more than 15kg/person. We borrowed the hotel scales and ensured we met this regulation. The new porter (Kishore) was told by Kamal that the bags were between 26-28kg combined. Kishore complained within a day that the bags were too heavy. Kamal asked us to remove our items from the bags to reduce the weight. We said we were told 15kg in Kathmandu by himself and it's not our fault that he had told the porter a lower number and if he needed to pay more to the porter that was his issue to resolve not ours. We certainly couldn't be expected to throw our personal effects away. On the Chola Pass Kishore had less than 15kg to carry and offered to carry my backpack - taking his load to 20kg. After 10min he dropped my bags and again complained about the weight -  Roles We observed Kamal calling the porters "Assistant Guide" and asking them to do tasks of a guide - we provided feedback to the company that you cannot call someone by a higher title than they are being paid  Drinking The first of several drunken episodes with Kamal - he informed us that he was a very busy man in Kathmandu and had cancelled his training to take our tour. We were told this multiple times and our response was consistently - if you weren't free you should have told Bishnu because we did not specify who should guide us. Upon returning to Kathmandu we checked with the company on this and were told he had confirmed he was free to take the trip. I asked Ram was this to get a better tip? - and he laughed. We never mentioned tips or that there would not be a tip. Where the need to be manipulative and deceitful came from is a complete shock.  Kamal was drunk on a number of evenings. He was more focussed on playing cards, expressing how boring the trip was for him, telling clients to go to bed early (in retrospect that seemed odd to be sent to bed soon after dinner) and commenting on Japanese women. It is not the clients job to entertain the guide and to be continuously told how bored he was - offensive is all that can be said. The height of his issues with alcohol was at Gokyo - the eve of climbing Gokyo Ri I was trying to express I was scared, I could not breath and had not slept. He was so drunk he said to another tourist that Choyong was the highest mountain in the world. He could not be reasoned with nor could he help with the issues I faced. The owners of the Fitzroy Inn (excellent and worth the extra $) also confirmed he had been drinking all afternoon. On communicating this to Bishnu he said he had no idea where this behaviour had come from. Back in Kathmandu speaking to Ram he admitted the company was aware of previous issues. How an organisation can know such information, pretend they don't know and endanger people's lives at altitude is beyond comprehension.  Harassment "Chinese Food, Italian Suit, American Life, Japanese Wife" - "Japanese girls eh eh eh??" I expressed disappointment at Kamal speaking about women in this way. This continued throughout the trip and was even said to a Japanese woman’s face. I understand in this culture similar to my Indian culture - women are not valued. However, when you have international clients where #metoo #timesup is at its height – time to educate yourself Bishnu - it is never acceptable for your staff to speak about women in this way.  The night before reaching Lukla a drunk Kamal and sober Kishore ganged up on me at dinner and said "tomorrow is the last day and porter wants you to know that you have to give a tip. Of course it's your choice but really you have to give a tip." Next morning I told Kamal I have never been spoken to in that way and Kamal said it was his first time a porter has behaved in this way. I responded "it's not however your first time for getting drunk". At Lukla both were told there would be no tip - if I was white or a man no one would dare to speak to me in this way nor would they dare to speak to me drunk. I had to lock myself in my room in Lukla. Bushnu did intervene and I did appreciate that however what he said was that we could discuss everything in Kathmandu, knowing full well he would not be in Kathmandu.  Customer Service Imn fact at the same time he was sitting with my friend (who had evacuated out) at dinner saying he was leaving the next morning to (“check accommodations for upcoming groups of about 20 pax“) as it was almost 2 years since he'd been on the mountain. How can you be in this business and not visit at least yearly? On return to Kathmandu Ram was sent (Bishnu did not admit he was not in Kathmandu or even apologise for not being present until I complained that “clearly as I wouldnt be returning as a client he sees no need to face me and hear any of this”) Ram's response was you've been through a terrible experience and I would have reacted like you to the demand for a tip but please don't put any of this on TripAdvisor. Really? I don't think that it is any organisations gift to ask for. Especially if they do not offer any kind of compensation until challenged and then it's a series of complaints that Kamal did his job by bringing me back to Kathmandu and just because the porter wants a tip and the guide is drunk I want to ruin Bishnu’s company. Seriously I have better things to do and it is irrelevant to me what actions you have taken against the guide – feedback good or bad needs to be accepted particularly if you do not have do not have have the decency to stick around to hear the feedback .

I went to Nepal from Apr.6~Apr.24,and had a awesome experience about "GOKYO,EBC trekking."Nepal Hiking Adventure Company provide complete travel plan including airport pick-up service,city guide-tour in Kathmandu,and the most important of all,I'm satisfied with the guide Ram .He offered me a safe trek and shared the culture of Himalaya.

column7: Done tours all over the world, this was the BEST!
column8: I will cut straight to the point; the tour I have just completed with the Nepal Hiking Adventure Company was the most organised, fun, enjoyable and reasonably-priced tour I have ever been on and likely to experience. The tour organizer (Bishnu) had everything arranged perfectly and in just 6 days we saw all the highlights of Kathmandu (temples, markets etc), went white-water rafting, stayed in the jungle which included an elephant ride, a canoe trip on the river and a trek through the jungle, a cultural dance performance, a hike up Nagarkot with sunset and sunrise views of the Himalayas, a tour of the amazing Bhaktapur and finally a night at a traditional Nepalese restaurant tasting some of the delicious local dishes. Simply amazing. I can not recommend this company and Bishnu high enough. The perfect tour guide and company.

column7: Professional, Attentive and (quite literally) Life-Savers -- SUPERB.
column8: My father and I went with Nepal Hiking on the Jiri to Everest Base Camp trek and everything about the trip was impeccable. We were promptly and warmly met at the airport by the owner who then escorted us back to a good hotel, with clean beds and warm running showers (which is quite a rare commodity in Kathmandu). Starting the trek entailed a lengthy bus trip to Jiri from Kathmandu, which isn't kind on the legs but is very scenic. Even on this bus trip we were welcomed in eating with our guide in the actual kitchens of people's homes, as opposed to cafeterias - which gave us an insight into Nepali life that I'm happy to say continued to be privileged us throughout our trek.  Trekking to Base Camp from Jiri is the only way to do it and if you have the fitness (it is occasionally gruelling) and time, then you HAVE to do it this way. There are fewer people trekking, you get to spend more time with the people (as they are generally more receptive to you sitting in their kitchens when there are fewer tourists), and the scenery is just remarkable. At all points our guides and porters were really supportive and attentive to our needs, and were keen to show us the interesting bits of the various cultures.  It was in the ability of Nepal Trekking to deal with emergencies, however, that really showed the quality of their guides and porters, and the quality of the company as a whole. I was stricken with AMS (acute mountain sickness) at Lobuche and became really ill, really suddenly. As a result of the disorientation I lacked the wherewithal to realise I was dangerously sick and so I probably would have continued trekking. Our guide, however, really took control of the situation - which is exactly what you need in what is definitely a high-risk scenario. He quickly spoke with the owner (who was based in Kathmandu) who then quickly mediated with our insurance company and had an emergency helicopter scrambled for us. The care and concern I was shown by the guide and porter (and indeed many of the other guides and porters convened at Lobuche) was indeed touching and was a further credit to them and the company. The decision and rapid action of the company prevented the situation becoming severe, and I thank and commend them for that.  Overall, the owner, the guide and our porter were a pleasure to be around and took care of everything, and our safety and comfort were always their paramount concerns. In a city that fiercely competes for your custom, I couldn't recommend Nepal Hiking in stronger or warmer terms.

We took a 9 day / 8 night private tour into Tibet, organised end-to-end by Nepal Hiking Adventure Company. The guide, jeep and accommodation are all of great quality which provides you the platform to sit back and enjoy the experience.  Being organised out of Nepal, the agency will arrange a local (English speaking) Tibetan guide which brings a lot more colour and depth to the commentary. Our guide also spoke a decent level of French.  I highly recommend including Everest Base Camp into your itinerary, it is easily accessible from the Tibetan side and the view is spectacular. I would also recommend packing some altitude tablets as a precaution, if you do head up to base camp you'll be sleeping at 5200m.  We organised the itinerary in advance which meant that we could leave the day after arriving into Kathmandu. Bishnu and his team arranged all the necessary paperwork and visas with information provided over email; passports were required one day prior to the tour to process the visas.  This was a great experience. The only way to visit Tibet is through an organised tour and from extensive research Nepal Hiking Adventure Company appears to be the best value for money.

The kathmandu-Bhaktapur- Patan tour with guide was so amazing. Our family had a great time , we viewed all the beautiful an traditional places. We also ate great local food. The guide was really nice and friendly. Will always cherish the beautiful moments of this trip.
Rabina made from this tour a great experience. She has a lot of knowledge an tries to transmit on every visit. Thanks for everything!

I was picked up promptly at the airport by Rabina and started the tour straight. My guide Rabina did a great job explaining the history and culture. It was a great experience to get a feel for Kathmandu. and this tour was really good.

column7: Day Tour of Patan and Bhaktapur
column8: Well organized and reasonably paced tour of the two great places at once, most recommended for those travellers who are time constrained and would like to make it all in one day. The tour guide and driver (both local) were very professional. The tour guide’s details were promptly provided by the office on my request a day in advance, for piece of mind for the morning pick up at the hotel - although I ended up never using those, as the guide was there ahead of time, waiting for me in the lobby. The vehicle was proper and clean. Also, I happened to be the only booked tourist on that day, so I got a private tour for no extra price. Good experience overall, thanks again to the company and the tour crew for supporting that day adventure!
It was an amazing experience. I learned alot about the history behind all the buildings and monuments.
The guide was very friendly. I loved the guidelines and learned a lot of new things. It was a great company to travel with.

column7: Amazing experience with a fantastic guide
column8: If you're after a day-long hike, sunrise views, culture and history then this is the trip for you!  The hike through Nagarkot was beautiful and our guide was super knowledgable of all the different cultures and traditions in the local area, he really made the day special. What was also amazing about him was that whilst by the end of the day my boots (and bum) were covered in mud, our guides shoes was spotless! After a downpour the day before I honestly don't know how he did it. Worth noting here that the local Nepalese on the tour were all lovely, friendly and happy to share their landscape - and even helped me get clean after a tumble into a puddle.  Our guide gave us the option to hike for a further two hours through the jungle after the first two hours, which we happily accepted - it was so worth it.  The Hindu temple at the end of the hike was great - dating back to 300 AD! The way that it has been restored is a testament to the skills of the local people as it has really kept its authenticity.  Needless to say, the sunrise coming up over the Himalayas was stunning, truly breakth-taking.  What was especially great about this tour was the private nature - no tour bus, just us and our private guide!!  Remember to take warm clothes for the morning and that can be stripped off for the heat of the afternoon. Also, remember $15 for breakfast at a mountainside resort.

I’ve had a wonderful two weeks in Nepal. After some sightseeing in Kathmandu we went to Pokhara to explore the city and to start the Nayapul-Ghorepani Gandruk trek. I really enjoyed the trekking and my trekguide Elmi made me feel very safe and comfortable. Also after the trekking he took care of everything that a tourist needs in a foreign country which made my last week touring around the cities another great experience. Elmi is a very professional and reliable guide who is always ready to help. You will not only see the touristic areas but also have the chance to take a close look withing the local culture when you travel with him. Thank you for everything Elmi! Ebru Gezer
great experience in affordable price. Not that far from Thamel area and easy access. But most of the time are relatively crowded and packed of tourist.

Getting to see many cultural sites in and near Kathmandu was an incredible experience! I loved seeing some of the most important spiritual places and getting to know the culture. I highly recommend the Boudhanath Stupa tour, and the Kathmandu Cultural tour.

Roshan is a very thoughtful, knowledgeable and flexible guide. He has accommodated all of our requests and made our experience memorable. I would definitely book with Roshan again next time I'm back in Kathmandu for tours.
We had an amazing day... Beautiful shops and artisan work...Food is amazing... A lot to learn.. A nice experience
